Title: The Analyst Who Predicts Bond Yields Will Hit New Lows; It almost has become an annual rite for analysts to finish the year forecasting the end of the bull run for U.S. government bonds, but one stands away from the pack
ARTICLE:
It almost has become an annual rite to finish the year forecasting the end of the bull run for U.S. government bonds. Steven Major, global head of fixed-income research at HSBC Holdings PLC, has consistently separated himself from the crowd in recent years by predicting lower Treasury yields.
Having been proved right in the past, the London-based analyst is sticking to his position.
The yield on the 10-year Treasury note, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, has climbed to 2.446% from its record low of 1.366% in July, driven in large part by expectations of faster growth and inflationary fiscal policies under a Donald Trump presidency.
Mr. Major, though, is still calling for a 10-year yield of 1.35% by the end of 2017. Among his bets, he is wagering that higher yields in the short term could hurt the economy and that a major stimulus package won't materialize.
The following is a condensed and edited version of a telephone interview with Mr. Major conducted by The Wall Street Journal on Dec. 20.
WSJ: A 10-year yield of 1.35% is a pretty bold bet at this point. How are you feeling about it?
Mr. Major: It's a forecast, isn't it, so it's not wrong or right until you get to the date. I've been here before a few times.
   PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 1 of 1177
Experience says to me that things happen--stuff happens. At some stage financial conditions will start to influence people's expectations. If rates go up [1 percentage point], as they have, that will affect planning and it will affect the way people consume and invest.
There is a lot of debt in the system and therefore the decisions are going to be much more sensitive than in the past.
WSJ: So higher rates lead to lower rates?
Mr. Major: Yes. The Fed's own model that uses long rates would say that, everything else being equal, the current increase in long rates would reduce future growth forecasts. It's very difficult to forecast what everything would say if you combined it, but I think people are missing that tightening financial conditions will matter.
WSJ: People keep expecting yields to go up. You've been among the most prominent people saying you don't quite see it yet.
Mr. Major: I think many people have been guilty of only looking at the U.S. in a closed-economy way. What has helped inform our opinion is taking it more global. When you ask me about last year's forecast and the year before and the year before that, they all would have included some reference to where we saw the [German] bund and [Japanese government bond] yields.
I'm pretty sure for 2017 we'll still see very low bund and JGB yields. The Bank of Japan is effectively running a cap on the 10-year yield and that cap may be around zero still in a year's time.
Think about emerging markets. Think about China. In the last few years, China has on at least two occasions actually influenced the Fed's decision on the fed-funds rate.
WSJ: That gets us to Donald Trump. Can you give your take on what the market is expecting and what you're expecting?
Mr. Major: The market seems to be pricing in a lot of positive news, and we don't have a great deal of evidence to base that on. It's more hope, I think, than anything else.
When you're already starting from a heavily indebted position, historical comparisons are hard to come by, but I suspect the impact of whatever fiscal loosening we have is going to [have a smaller impact.]
There's a reason we've been stuck with very low natural rates for so long, and that's related to very, very long-term, deep structural factors: demographics, excess of debt, productivity, wealth inequality, these type of things.
WSJ: You're also skeptical that Mr. Trump will be able to push through a large fiscal stimulus.
Mr. Major: Last time I looked, the Republican Party hadn't suddenly become Keynesian. We've got people who are fiscal hawks and they're going to look at spending cuts pretty aggressively. That's not going to be very pleasant.
WSJ: If you could make your best bear case for Treasurys, what would it be?
Mr. Major: If you had very clear evidence in the data that productivity was picking up--and that could come--and
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 2 of 1177

you had continuing strength in wages, a Fed that decides that it's going to move like in 1994, whereby they were moving every other meeting just about, that would be pretty bearish.
WSJ: How high do you think the 10-year Treasury yield could get?
Mr. Major: I doubt you'll get to 3%. I can't imagine the forwards getting much above 4% to 4.5%. That takes you back to the post-taper period in 2013. That was a level that was above the longer-term nominal GDP and therefore was something that I took as a signal that we were in severely restrictive financial conditions.
Today I should imagine that you wouldn't need to get the forward rate anywhere near to 4.5% to generate the same kind of downward pressure on future growth forecasts.

Title: World Watch
ARTICLE:
INDONESIA
Fire on Ferry Kills At Least 23 People
A search resumed for 17 people reported missing after a ferry fire off the coast of Indonesia's capital that left at least 23 dead, officials said.
The victims died on Sunday when the vessel, Zahro Express, carrying more than 260 people to Tidung, a resort island in the Kepulauan Seribu chain, from a port near Jakarta caught fire, officials said. Most of the passengers were Indonesians celebrating the New Year holiday, local media reported.
Denny Wahyu Haryanto, head of the Jakarta Disaster Mitigation Agency, said he didn't rule out that those reported missing could be among the bodies found inside the ship.
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 4 of 1177
He said that of the 224 passengers who were rescued, 19 were still being treated at hospitals.
Seply Madreta, an official from the Jakarta Disaster Mitigation Agency, said the fire gutted about half the vessel, and that 23 bodies had been recovered.
Witnesses told MetroTV that the fire broke out about 15 minutes after the ferry left the port of Muara Angke.
The cause of the fire wasn't clear. Some passengers told local media they first saw smoke coming from the ferry's engine.
The director for sea transportation, Tonny Budiono, said the initial suspicion was that the fire was "most probably caused by a short circuit in the engine room."
Associated Press
CHINA
Domestic Ivory Trade To End This Year
Beijing said it would ban all domestic ivory trade by the end of 2017, closing the world's biggest ivory market in a move wildlife conservationists said they believe will help curb elephant poaching in Africa.
The announcement deals a blow to a global ivory industry sustained in large part by Chinese demand, and comes after years of international and domestic pressure on Beijing to interdict a trade that has threatened the extinction of wild African elephants.
"China's announcement is a game changer for elephant conservation," said Carter Roberts, chief executive of World Wildlife Fund. "The large-scale trade of ivory now faces its twilight years."
In a directive published late Friday, the State Council--China's cabinet--said the shutdown of the domestic ivory industry would take place in phases, with an initial group of processing plants and retail outlets due to close by the end of March.
Government agencies will assist ivory-industry workers in their transition to related professions, such as wood and bone carving or artifact-restoration in museums.
Current owners of ivory products will be allowed to keep them, transfer them as gifts, bequeath them to descendants, or sell them at supervised auctions after securing official approval.
Authorities will also step up enforcement against ivory-related businesses and launch campaigns to educate the public on the iniquities of the ivory trade.
Chun Han Wong
CHINA
Factory-Output Data Show Slower Growth
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 5 of 1177

A key gauge of factory output edged down in December, pointing to slowing momentum in China's economy, though leaving it on target to hit the government's growth target of at least 6.5% for 2016.
The official manufacturing purchasing managers index fell to 51.4 in December from 51.7 the previous month, according to official data, indicating the world's second-largest economy continued to expand, though at a slower rate. The index has stayed above the 50 mark that separates an expansion of activity from a contraction for five straight months.
"The momentum is becoming less strong, but it's still in expansionary territory," said HSBC economist Ma Xiaoping. "The momentum will weaken further, but not likely run into contraction in coming months."
The slightly weaker PMI reading for December comes as Beijing pulls back from the easy-money policy on which it depended for much of the year to bolster the economy.
Policy makers are confident the economy will reach the annual growth target of 6.5% to 7%, while they are growing increasingly concerned about rising corporate debt levels, economists said.
China's nonfinancial corporate debt is about 145% of gross domestic product, which is "high by any measure," according to the International Monetary Fund.
Pei Li
POLAND
Manufacturing Grew Faster in December
Expansion in the manufacturing sector accelerated sharply in December, Markit Economics said, reflecting another increase in the volume of new orders, as well as growth of employment and exports.
A survey of 300 industrial companies showed that the manufacturing purchasing managers index, a gauge of manufacturing activity, was at 54.3 in December compared with 51.9 in November.
A PMI figure below 50 indicates a contraction in activity, while a number above that level signals expansion.
Inflationary pressure increased rapidly in December because of a weaker zloty as well as higher prices of metals and oil, Markit also said. Poland's consumer prices rose 0.8% in annual terms in December, the Polish statistics office said.
Martin M. Sobczyk
RUSSIA
Putin Lauds Populace After a Tough 2016
President Vladimir Putin delivered a videotaped address to his countrymen on Saturday evening, congratulating them on the New Year's holiday while acknowledging that 2016 wasn't easy for Russia.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 6 of 1177

"2016 is ending," the Russian president said. "It was not easy, but the difficulties that we faced united us and prompted to open the huge reserves of our ability to move forward."
Mr. Putin was front and center in world affairs in 2016. The Obama administration has accused the Kremlin of orchestrating cyberattacks aimed at influencing the outcome of the U.S. presidential elections.
The U.S. government last week imposed new sanctions on Moscow and expelled Russians it alleged were intelligence operatives serving under diplomatic cover.
But in a surprise move, Mr. Putin said Russia wouldn't retaliate by expelling U.S. diplomats. The Kremlin is hoping for a thaw in U.S.-Russian relations once President-elect Donald Trump takes office.
Russia has also advanced a plan for brokering an end to the war in Syria, hammering out a cease-fire deal there with Turkey backing talks in Kazakhstan in January aimed at ending the fighting.
Nathan Hodge
BAHRAIN
Gunmen Storm Prison, Free 10 Inmates
Gunmen armed with automatic rifles and pistols stormed a Bahraini prison, killing a police officer and freeing 10 inmates convicted on terrorism charges, police said.
The attack on Jaw prison represents a significant escalation of the simmering unrest that has gripped the island nation off the coast of Saudi Arabia since its 2011 Arab Spring protests, which saw the nation's Shiite majority and others demand more political freedoms from the country's Sunni rulers. No group claimed responsibility for the assault.
The attack sparked a manhunt across the island. Confusion about the escape persisted for hours afterward, as the Interior Ministry issued a series of tweets in Arabic and English contradicting each other.
Early Monday, the Interior Ministry said the attack was launched by "a terrorist cell of four to six members armed with automatic rifles and pistols."
It named the dead police officer as Abdulsalam Saif Ahmed and said a second officer suffered moderate wounds in the attack.
Associated Press

Title: Peak Auto Sales Make 2017 a Waiting Game for Investors; Low valuations suggest an earnings downturn is on its way
ARTICLE:
In cyclical industries, the best of times for manufacturers tend to be the worst of times for investors.
The auto sector is a case in point. Car sales are running ahead of their precrisis peak in the U.S., but earnings multiples, even after a postelection bounce, are meager by historical standards. Investors should probably interpret low valuations as a warning flag rather than a discount sticker: A downturn in earnings is surely on its way.
The cycle is most mature in U.S. light-vehicle sales, which doubled over the seven years through November 2015 to an annualized peak of 18.1 million units. In 2016, following the first increase in the federal-funds rate since the recovery started, sales stalled . Now the Federal Reserve is signaling a faster pace of rate increases . More than seven in 10 new cars sold in the U.S. are financed with debt, according to research group IHS, which expects 17.4 million light-vehicle sales in 2017.
As the period running into the 2007 credit crunch showed, the problem with even flattish sales is that it encourages manufacturers to sacrifice their profits in a fight for market share. There are early warning signs that this is happening again: Industry inventories have been rising , and rebates with them. Of the Detroit Three, Ford may be best placed to deal with this more difficult market environment, having called an end to the boom in July and announced production cuts in October--earlier than its peers.
The picture is slightly brighter in Europe, if only because the eurozone crisis delayed the recovery by a few years in parts of the continent. Across the European Union, car registrations for the year through November were up 7.1% from the previous year.
With U.K. sales already running well ahead of the 2007 peak, growth is being driven by pent-up demand in Southern Europe. HSBC said it expects Italian consumers to buy about 1.9 million cars this year, roughly a fifth more than last year but still far below the 2.5 million vehicles sold in 2007. This suggests there is gas left in the tank, which is a boon to local market leader Fiat Chrysler in particular. The not insignificant risk is that consumer sentiment is thrown off course by a political or banking crisis in Italy, or a renewal of the eurozone crisis more generally.
Yet growth hopes are pinned above all on China . After a weak patch in the summer of 2015, a cut in sales tax was spectacularly successful in reviving the world's largest car market . This incentive has been scaled back for 2017 , which is likely to weigh on demand for smaller engines. But the bigger problem for Western car makers is more likely to be supply than demand: Production capacity is rising fast, including by increasingly sophisticated local
  PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 9 of 1177
manufacturers. Whatever its growth path, the Chinese market will become more competitive in 2017.
The year ahead could be a waiting game. Better buying opportunities are likely to emerge when times get a bit worse for car manufacturers.
Write to Stephen Wilmot at stephen.wilmot@wsj.com Credit: By Stephen Wilmot

Title: U.K. Regulator Raises Competition Concerns Over Mastercard's VocaLink Buy; The U.K. watchdog has sought assurances from the two companies
ARTICLE:
LONDON--The U.K. Competition and Markets Authority said Wednesday Mastercard Inc.'s acquisition of VocaLink gives rise to competition concerns, and it is seeking undertakings from the companies to address these issues.
They have until Jan. 11 to offer a solution or the regulator will refer the deal for an in-depth investigation, it said.
Last July Mastercard said it was buying 92.4% of VocaLink Holdings Ltd. in a deal valued around $920 million. If the deal is completed, a majority of VocaLink's current owners will retain a 7.6% stake for at least three years.
Mastercard U.K. Holdco Ltd., a unit of Mastercard, already owns and operates credit- and debit-card schemes Mastercard, Maestro and Cirrus, and has bid to supply infrastructure services to U.K. interbank payment systems.
VocaLink's technology provides the backbone for non-card transactions such as employer-payroll deposits and consumer-bill payments, processing over 90% of salaries, more than 70% of household bills and almost all state benefits in the U.K.
It also unites the infrastructure of Britain's automated-teller-machine network among its participating banks via the LINK network. VocaLink reported $240 million in revenue last year and processed more than 11 billion transactions.
The regulator said its main concern is the LINK ATM network as VocaLink and Mastercard are two of the three most credible providers of infrastructure services to the network across the U.K. As such, it believes the merger
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 11 of 1177
would reduce the number of bidders and limit the ability of the LINK scheme to obtain good value when tendering for an infrastructure provider.
"The LINK ATM network provides an essential service for millions of customers. It's important that LINK has a good choice of providers when it comes to supplying the necessary infrastructure so it can take advantage of the opening up of payment systems to competition," Andrea Coscelli, acting chief executive of the CMA, and decision maker in this case, said.
"These concerns warrant a closer investigation in the event that Mastercard cannot address them at this stage," she said.
Mastercard said it would address this concern within the time frame provided.
VocaLink is owned by a consortium of 18 banks and building societies, with the four biggest being Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC, Barclays PLC, HSBC Holdings PLC, and Lloyds Banking Group PLC.
Last July, after the deal was announced, the U.K. Payment Systems Regulator said the four largest shareholders of VocaLink should sell all, or part of their holdings in the infrastructure provider if its acquisition by Mastercard doesn't go ahead, to open up the market and boost competition.
At the time of the deal, RBS confirmed it would sell its 21.4% shareholding in VocaLink and book a £150 million ($183.6 million) pretax gain in its accounts. Barclays also said it sold 13.68% of its shareholding in VocaLink for £104 million, leaving it with a 1.5% stake.
Write to Ian Walker at ian.walker@wsj.com Credit: By Ian Walker

Title: Deutsche Bank's Anti-Financial-Crime Chief to Quit Post; Peter Hazlewood stepping down after budget dispute over hiring hundreds more workers
ARTICLE:
The head of Deutsche Bank AG's financial-crime-fighting unit is leaving that post after an internal budget dispute over his requests to add hundreds of new employees, according to people familiar with the matter.
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 13 of 1177
Peter Hazlewood, who has been in the job six months, will be replaced as soon as next week, the people said. He might stay at Deutsche Bank in another role, but he will no longer run the group overseeing controls to prevent money laundering and violations of financial laws globally, the people said.
Mr. Hazlewood didn't respond to requests for comment. He was on an initial six-month contract that will expire in mid-January, one of the people said.
The position is central to the lender's relationships with regulators, as well as its ability to avoid legal pitfalls, at a time when it still faces an array of costly regulatory challenges.
Deutsche Bank last month agreed to basic terms of a $7.2 billion settlement with the U.S. Justice Department to end a series of mortgage-securities probes . The bank still faces an anticipated smaller fine from the U.S. government following an investigation of Russian stock trades.
That investigation has raised questions about Deutsche Bank's ability to police potential money laundering. The trades in question occurred before Mr. Hazlewood joined Deutsche Bank.
As the bank's official money-laundering reporting officer, Mr. Hazlewood signs off on documentation with regulators attesting to the bank's controls and compliance.
In December, tensions arose between Mr. Hazlewood and more senior executives about planning for 2017, with Mr. Hazlewood asking for more new employees and other resources than his bosses were inclined to approve, the people said.
At the same time, some executives were unhappy with elements of his management style and leadership of the business, according to one person familiar with high-level discussions inside the bank. Those who expressed dissatisfaction included his supervisor, Sylvie Matherat, Deutsche Bank's chief regulatory officer and a member of its management board.
Tensions flared last week when budgets were being finalized, the people close to the discussions said. Mr. Hazlewood had asked to hire more than 600 people in 2017 to help bulk up compliance and anti-money-laundering efforts and handle financial-crime investigations, people familiar with the matter said.
Senior executives approved close to 400 additional employees, the people said. The hiring will bring the global anti- financial crime unit to about 1,160 people, the people said.
A Deutsche Bank spokeswoman said Wednesday that the bank has committed to increasing its 2016 anti-crime unit headcount by 50% by the end of 2017. The bank doesn't publicly disclose the unit's size or budget.
Mr. Hazlewood and other managers in the group complained that without the 200 more people requested, Deutsche Bank would lag behind competitors and struggle to complete projects and adequately beef up its anticrime teams and technology.
The arguments fueled discussions about whether Mr. Hazlewood should continue in the role, the people said. His planned departure was earlier reported by Germany's Manager Magazin.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 14 of 1177

Deutsche Bank executives plan to name a successor as soon as next week, pending management approval of an internal candidate, one person briefed on internal discussions said.
Mr. Hazlewood previously worked at HSBC Holdings PLC and Standard Chartered PLC. In announcing his appointment in April 2016, Deutsche Bank called him "an experienced career financial crime professional" with 28 years of experience at large financial institutions.
He joined after a high-level management shake-up in 2015 that included the appointment of John Cryan as chief executive and a near-complete makeover of the bank's management ranks. Ms. Matherat joined the management board in November 2015, and she and her colleagues have focused in part on overhauling compliance globally, seeking to end a series of legal missteps that have cost Deutsche Bank billions of dollars.
Write to Jenny Strasburg at jenny.strasburg@wsj.com

Title: Canadian Pension Giant PSP Hires Ex-Goldman Sachs Banker
ARTICLE:
Canada's Public Sector Pension Investment Board has boosted its European private-debt team with the hire of a former banker from Goldman Sachs Group Inc.
David Witkin joined the firm in January 2017 as a senior director after a decade at Goldman Sachs, according to people familiar with the matter.
The new hire comes after PSP announced on July 12 that it was aiming to deploy approximately C$5.6 billion in private debt financing globally over the next three years.
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 16 of 1177
David Scudellari, the head of PSP Investments' principal debt and credit team, told WSJ Pro Private Equity sister publication Private Equity News at the time that the debt and credit team had a 'quite flexible' mandate covering everything from direct lending to secondary portfolio purchasing.
The Canadian pension-fund manager set up a European private-debt team last year, Private Equity News reported in July, citing David Scudellari.
HSBC Bank PLC's former European head of capital financing Oliver Duff was also hired as a managing director of principal debt and credit investments in Europe.
Mr. Scudellari said at the time that the pension fund aimed to grow its European private-debt team to between six and eight investment executives.
The move into European credit came less than a year after PSP announced in September 2015 that it was setting up a European investment team to do direct private-equity deals.
Private Equity News reported in May that PSP had made a series of high profile hires to its private equity deal team--poaching investment executives from buyout firms including CVC Capital Partners, Permira and Bridge

Title: Ex-Barclays Forex Trader Pleads Guilty In Long-Running U.S. Probe; Five banks, including Barclays, had paid penalties to resolve probe into alleged manipulation of foreign-currency prices
ARTICLE:
WASHINGTON--A former foreign-exchange trader at Barclays PLC pleaded guilty Wednesday to conspiring to manipulate currency rates, the first individual publicly charged in an investigation over collusion at top global banks to move the rates.
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 18 of 1177
Jason Katz, who worked on the New York foreign-exchange desk at Barclays and two other banks, admitted to working between 2007 and 2013 with dealers at other institutions to fix prices for currencies in central and eastern Europe, the Middle East, and Africa, the Justice Department said.
A lawyer for Mr. Katz couldn't immediately be reached for comment.
The efforts included coordinating bids and offers, and agreeing to quote certain prices to specific customers, the agency said.
Five banks including Barclays pleaded guilty in May 2015 and paid $5.6 billion in penalties to resolve investigation s into whether the banks worked together to manipulate foreign currency prices.
In a separate case that grew out of the investigations, prosecutors in July charged two HSBC Holdings PLC employees with fraudulently front-running a $3.5 billion currency trade for a client. The HSBC traders have pleaded not guilty.
According to a plea agreement entered in Manhattan federal court on Wednesday, Mr. Katz agreed to cooperate in the ongoing investigation. He faces up to 10 years in prison.
The Federal Reserve separately on Wednesday announced it permanently prohibited Mr. Katz from working in the banking industry.
Write to Aruna Viswanatha at Aruna.Viswanatha@wsj.com Credit: By Aruna Viswanatha

Title: Lawyer Jay Clayton Top SEC Pick | Democrats Gather Ammo On Mnuchin | CFTC's Massad to Step Down | Basel's Uncertainties | CFPB Settlement Over Credit Scores | Deng's Take: Behind China's Tightened Monetary Stance; The Wall Street Journal's financial regulation newsletter for Wednesday, January 4, 2016.
ARTICLE:
Deng's Take: Behind China's Tightened Monetary Stance
Wall Street Lawyer Jay Clayton Emerges as Top Candidate for SEC Chairman
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM
Page 20 of 1177
Democrats Gather Ammo Against Treasury Pick Steven Mnuchin
U.K. Regulator Raises Competition Concerns Over Mastercard's VocaLink Buy U.S., Europe Spat Over Bank Risk Set to Drag On
Behind China's Tightened Monetary Stance
China's top leadership has hinted at a slightly tightened monetary stance in 2017. But bubbling below that seemingly unified goal are long-simmering tensions among various financial regulators, each with its own thoughts on what policy measures are appropriate.
A divergence between the People's Bank of China and the China Banking Regulatory Commission came into focus in a recent speech by an official at the banking regulator.
Yu Xuejun said China should cut the amount of money that banks are required to hold in reserves at the central bank, adding that other financing tools could be used to adjust liquidity after a cut, according to a report last week by state-owned Shanghai Securities News. Reducing the required reserve ratio, or RRR, would let banks lend more.
Tools like medium-term lending facilities, where the central bank agrees to lend to banks at a set rate for a few months, shouldn't be overused before a cut, Mr. Yu said.
But senior party officials at the recent Central Economic Work Conference have called for "prudent and neutral" policy this year. That language, shifting from "accommodative" in their previous statements, implies that the central bank will refrain from cutting RRR for banks, much less lower interest rates, according to analysts.
The dissonance in rhetoric lies in different regulators' priorities. The banking commission looks out for banks, which in China are buckling under a surge of bad loans coupled with slowing economic growth. The central bank looks out for the broader financial system and attempts to address risk wherever it may arise, from trying to deleverage the local bond market to curbing declines in the yuan and arresting capital flight. Increasingly, it is also taking on a coordinator role between China's various lumbering regulatory groups.
Cutting banks' reserve requirement ratios risks adding to the cash flowing out of China--the exact situation the leadership wants to prevent. The last time the central bank cut RRR was in March 2016, when it took the ratio down 0.5 percentage point to 17% for the largest banks. Since then, it has stuck with more flexible money-market instruments to adjust the supply of funds in the financial system, even though such measures are more expensive for banks.
Zhu Chaoping, an economist at UOB Kay Hian in Shanghai, said to "expect more fine-tune measures" this year, but not an RRR cut. The use medium- and short-term lending facilities started in 2015 and authorities are increasingly formalizing them as tools to adjust borrowing costs, he explained.
Given Mr. Yu's relatively narrow role at the banking regulator of overseeing state-owned financial institutions, his opinion might not carry much sway.
But his comments illustrate the need for more coordination between Chinese regulators. Similar policy tussles
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 21 of 1177

have surfaced between the central bank and National Development Reform Commission, the country's economic planner.
Unfortunately, analysts say last year's talk of consolidating regulation has fizzled out. China's undeniable message right now is stability at all costs.
Key Developments in Washington, on Wall Street, and Beyond
Wall Street Lawyer Jay Clayton Emerges as Top Candidate for SEC Chairman By Dave Michaels and Michael C. Bender
WASHINGTON--Wall Street lawyer Jay Clayton has emerged as the leading candidate to be chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission and could be announced as the nominee as soon as Wednesday, according to an official working with the transition team of President-elect Donald Trump.
Mr. Clayton, whose clients have included Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and Barclays Capital Inc., would succeed SEC Chairman Mary Jo White, another lawyer with a history of representing Wall Street banks before becoming a regulator. Mr. Clayton, who met with Mr. Trump on Dec. 22, is a partner at Sullivan &Cromwell LLP, where he also worked on the 2014 initial public offering of Alibaba Group Holding Ltd., according to Sullivan's website.
Mr. Trump has also considered Debra Wong Yang, who served as a U.S. attorney during the administration of former President George W. Bush, for the role of chairman. Mr. Clayton appears to have surpassed Ms. Yang, a partner at Gibson Dunn &Crutcher LLP based in Los Angeles, as the most likely candidate to run the SEC, which oversees the $27 trillion U.S. equity market. Mr. Clayton has spent his career working on the kinds of securities deals that the SEC has a hand in regulating.
Reached on his cellphone Tuesday evening, Mr. Clayton said he couldn't talk and hung up.
Mr. Clayton would become the latest Trump appointee with longstanding Wall Street ties, joining former Goldman executive Steven Mnuchin, Mr. Trump's choice for Treasury secretary; former Goldman President Gary Cohn, who will run the National Economic Council; and private-equity investor Wilbur Ross, the pick to head the Commerce Department.
Mr. Clayton represented Goldman when it received a $5 billion investment from billionaire Warren Buffett's company during the peak of the credit crisis in September 2008, according to his bio on Sullivan's website. He's also represented Goldman in connection with other investments and acquisitions, according to the law firm. Sullivan is a key outside legal adviser for Goldman and is more closely associated with Wall Street than perhaps any other law firm.
Mr. Clayton has a wide-ranging corporate practice spanning mergers and acquisitions, IPOs, corporate governance, and investment advice for high-net-worth families. Other matters that Mr. Clayton has worked on include advising Morgan Stanley on the sale of its physical oil-trading division and Bear Stearns on its sale to J.P. Morgan Chase &Co.--two deals shaped heavily by the financial crisis and its aftermath--and the 2014 IPO of Moelis &Co., a boutique advisory firm. He's also represented an ownership group for the Atlanta Hawks and British Airways in its 2010 merger with Iberia.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 22 of 1177

Mr. Clayton would take over the SEC at a time when congressional Republicans are pressuring the agency to loosen fundraising rules for smaller public companies, lighten its oversight of private-equity firms, and repeal executive-compensation rules opposed by corporations.
He would be one of at least three new members to join the SEC this year. The agency has two unfilled commissioner posts in addition to the chairman's role, which Ms. White will give up on Jan. 20.
Two other securities lawyers who have advised the Trump transition team, Paul Atkins and Ralph Ferrara, also have been viewed as possible candidates to run the SEC. Mr. Atkins, the chief executive officer of Patomak Global Partners, met with Mr. Trump in late November and is also regarded as a candidate to become vice chairman of the Federal Reserve.
--Sara Randazzo and Liz Hoffman contributed to this article. Democrats Gather Ammo Against Treasury Pick Steven Mnuchin By Gabriel T. Rubin
Liberal groups and Democratic senators are zeroing in on the record of Steven Mnuchin, President-elect Donald Trump's pick for Treasury secretary, aiming to pressure Republicans into voting against his nomination. The campaign is part of a larger effort by Democrats to derail some of Mr. Trump's nominees.
The senators and groups are painting Mr. Mnuchin as an executive who oversaw thousands of foreclosures during the financial crisis while at the helm of OneWest Bank. Buying the bank, formerly known as IndyMac, eventually earned Mr. Mnuchin hundreds of millions of dollars. It is now part of CIT Group Inc.
The liberal group Allied Progress is launching a six-figure television ad campaign in Arizona and Nevada to call on Sens. Jeff Flake (R., Ariz.) and Dean Heller (R., Nev.) to vote against Mr. Mnuchin's nomination.
"Mnuchin made millions after his bank foreclosed on homeowners," the ads say. They also accuse the bank of discriminating against prospective Latino home buyers, citing a complaint filed in November with the Department of Housing and Urban Development by two California-based housing organizations.
Both Sens. Heller and Flake criticized Mr. Trump for some of his conduct during the presidential campaign, and both face re-election campaigns in 2018 in states with rapidly growing Latino populations. Both states were hit particularly hard with foreclosures during the financial crisis.
Representatives for Mr. Flake and Mr. Heller didn't respond to requests for comment.
Tara Bradshaw, a spokeswoman for Mr. Mnuchin, said that he had "tirelessly worked to help families stay in their homes" during his time at OneWest. The bank was a "modification machine," not a "foreclosure machine," as Democrats allege, she said.
"The complaints filed by two California housing groups are grossly misleading since they rely on lending figures for time periods after OneWest sold its primary mortgage business," Ms. Bradshaw said. "During the time period the groups focus on, OneWest originated only a very small number of mortgages to anyone, because during that time period OneWest had sold its primary mortgage platform."
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 23 of 1177

Opponents also are poring over records related to OneWest's activities while Mr. Mnuchin was there, particularly with regard to the legality of its foreclosure practices.
OneWest is under civil investigation by HUD for loan-servicing practices. CIT, OneWest's parent company, has said it is "committed to fair-lending and works hard to meet the credit needs of all communities and neighborhoods we serve."
The campaign against Mr. Mnuchin comes as Senate Democrats plan out how to proceed with Mr. Trump's cabinet nominees and try to exact political damage on the new administration, even if they can't block any of the nominations.
"Looking at the cabinet, which is stacked with billionaires, corporate executives, titans of Wall Street, and those deeply embedded in Washington's corridors of power, it seems that many of his campaign themes are quickly being abandoned," Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D., N.Y.) said Tuesday.
Late last year, Senate Democrats--led by Sens. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, Jeff Merkley of Oregon and Bernie Sanders of Vermont--launched a website to solicit the stories of homeowners who were foreclosed on by OneWest during Mr. Mnuchin's time at the bank.
They have drawn attention to particular examples of aggressive foreclosure practices by the bank, including a case in which a Minneapolis homeowner was locked out of her home during a blizzard.
Ms. Warren has been particularly vocal in her criticism of Mr. Mnuchin, writing in a statement last month that "Mnuchin swooped in after the crash to take a second bite out of families by aggressively--and sometimes illegally- -foreclosing on their homes," after "peddling the kind of dangerous mortgage-backed securities that eventually blew up the economy."
Additionally, the top Democrat on the Senate Banking Committee, Sherrod Brown of Ohio, wrote to Mr. Mnuchin asking him questions on a variety of banking and housing policies, including several related to his time in the financial services industry.
Mr. Mnuchin won't be providing written answers to those questions, Ms. Bradshaw said.
"The American public deserves to know where Mr. Mnuchin stands on these basic, straightforward questions about important housing and finance issues that he'll oversee," a spokesman for Sen. Brown said.
Mr. Brown will have an opportunity to question Mr. Mnuchin as a member of the Finance Committee, which has jurisdiction over the Treasury secretary's nomination.
CFTC Chairman Timothy Massad to Step Down Jan. 20 By Dave Michaels and Andrew Ackerman
WASHINGTON--Timothy Massad plans to step down as chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission on Jan. 20, after nearly three years at the helm of the top U.S. derivatives regulator, the agency said Tuesday.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 24 of 1177

The departure, which was expected, is set to coincide with the end of the Obama administration. Mr. Massad, a Democrat, has sought to complete stricter rules for the multitrillion-dollar swaps market. His departure opens the door for a Republican successor who could ease or unwind some of his efforts.
President-elect Donald Trump will appoint the CFTC's next leader, adding to the bounty of financial appointees who could loosen the reins on Wall Street after years of tighter supervision under Democrats. Mr. Trump also is expected to appoint a new SEC chairman, a vice chairman for supervision at the Federal Reserve as well as a new comptroller of the currency.
J. Christopher Giancarlo, the CFTC's sole Republican member, is expected to succeed Mr. Massad, at least on an interim basis. Mr. Giancarlo is also under consideration to fill the top CFTC role on a permanent basis, according to people who have spoken with the Trump transition team.
Mr. Massad's resignation plans mirror the exit of Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Mary Jo White, who announced in November that she would leave the top U.S. markets regulator at the close of the Obama administration.
Mr. Massad has said the CFTC is underfunded given the scope of its oversight. His departure will leave the agency with just two commissioners: Mr. Giancarlo and Sharon Bowen, a Democrat. That will make it even harder for the undermanned agency to get anything done, given government sunshine laws that prevent commissioners from making decisions outside of public meetings.
The remaining commissioners will at least have a neighbor for a bit longer. While Mr. Massad plans to step down as chairman, he will stick around for a "few weeks in order to close out his office and handle administrative matters," the agency said in a news release.
In the press release Mr. Massad laid out a number of policy priorities he spearheaded, including the regulatory framework for trading and reporting swaps, products that accelerated the damage from the 2008 financial crisis. "I came to the CFTC with a number of priorities, and I am proud we have made significant progress in every area," he said.
Mr. Giancarlo may seek to ease some of the CFTC's postcrisis rules--particularly swaps-trading requirements that he says have sent trading business overseas. But he has backed broad mandates for overhauling the swaps market, including the requirement that many be processed through clearinghouses, entities that guarantee trades in case one side defaults. He also could push for the introduction of examinations for swaps traders and brokers.
Mr. Massad took over the CFTC in June 2014, succeeding Gary Gensler, a former Goldman Sachs Group Inc. executive who gained a reputation as an aggressive regulator. European policy makers repeatedly chafed at Mr. Gensler's efforts to quickly and aggressively impose U.S. rules for derivatives overseas. Mr. Massad made smoothing those relations a priority after he took over.
In one of his biggest accomplishments, Mr. Massad succeeded last year in ending a lengthy impasse between the U.S. and Europe over the regulation of clearinghouses.
But in other areas he fell short of his own expectations. Last month, for instance, he failed to complete controversial curbs on commodities trading. Instead of finishing the position-limit rules, Mr. Massad opted to rewrite the proposal for the third time since 2011. That will allow the Trump administration, which has said it would
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 25 of 1177

dismantle the Dodd-Frank law calling for the rules, to finish them.
Mr. Massad told reporters he didn't want to complete rules that a commission under Republican leadership would be unlikely to implement or enforce.
Republican lawmakers were cordial with the CFTC chairman but refused to boost the agency's budget above $250 million for the past three years. Mr. Massad has said the agency lacks the resources to advance priorities such as testing the cybersecurity controls of firms it oversees.
He also clashed with members of his own party over bank-safety rules completed a year ago. The measure eased proposed requirements that banks set aside cash to offset the risk of losses on certain swaps trades, bucking objections from Sen. Elizabeth Warren and other Democrats who wanted a stricter approach.
Mr. Massad defended the rules, which covered collateral known as margin, as "very strong," and said they were nearly identical to restrictions imposed by fellow U.S. regulators and similar to those imposed overseas.
Fidelity International Gets Nod to Sell Investment Products in China By Rachel Rosenthal
Chinese financial regulators have given Fidelity International the green light to offer local investment products to wealthy mainland investors, making it the first major foreign fund manager to get such a permission.
The company's Chinese operation, FIL Investment Management (Shanghai) Co., has this week registered with the Asset Management Association of China as a private fund-management company. That step allows the firm to create investment products to sell to Chinese institutional and high-net-worth investors, the firm said Wednesday.
The move marks China's latest effort to open up its financial markets to foreigners, and could herald further opportunities for global money managers to set up shop without an onshore partner.
"This is a very significant milestone in our expansion into the world's second-biggest economy," said Daisy Ho, managing director, Asia Pacific ex-Japan, at Fidelity International. "The potential for the onshore market is huge."
To date, only a handful of global investment firms have gained approval to operate wholly-owned investment companies in China, allowing them to operate as stand-alone money managers. The list includes J.P. Morgan Asset Management, U.S. hedge fund Bridgewater Associates and U.K.-based Aberdeen Asset Management. Fidelity's registration with AMAC, an industry body that is supervised by the country's securities regulator, will allow it to actually sell products in China, the next step in the process.
Since 2001, most asset managers looking to do business in China have set up joint-venture arrangements with partners onshore. Roughly 40 fund managers have established such relationships.
The benefit of going solo is that "you finally get to control your own destiny," said Peter Alexander, founder and managing director of Shanghai consultancy Z-Ben Advisors. "You can hire who you want to hire, and won't have to spend time on negotiating politics. What you can do in your businesses in Boston, New York or Hong Kong, you can now do in Shanghai."
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 26 of 1177

Fidelity International has a six-month window to launch its first product onshore. The platform will be available only to institutional clients and high-net-worth investors, which includes individuals with financial assets of no less than 3 million yuan ($430,000) or personal annual average income of no less than 500,000 yuan for the past three years.
The firm's registration is the latest development in China's recent effort to welcome foreign investors to its markets. In December, China launched a trading link between the Hong Kong and Shenzhen stock markets, and last February officials lifted restrictions on foreign investors in China's main bond market.
Still, investors have met these efforts with caution. China's yuan has weakened sharply against a resurgent U.S. dollar--falling nearly 7% against the greenback in 2016, and is approaching the psychologically important level of 7 yuan per U.S. dollar. China's bond market has been rattled by regulators' recent campaign to deleverage and tighten monetary conditions, and its stock market was one of Asia's worst-performing last year.
"We understand there will continue to be volatility in China's markets," said Ms. Ho. "But because of our nature, our vision is for long-term growth."
Fidelity International will have to compete with Chinese peers, who have a well-established presence on the ground. Still, the firm has more than a decade of experience operating in China, with a staff of 400 employees there.
The firm has mainly offered domestic institutional clients and retail investors the ability to invest offshore. The firm also has a quota of $1.2 billion under the Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor Scheme, a program that allows international investors to buy Chinese stocks and bonds with yuan raised outside China. That is one of the largest amounts held by any fund manager globally.
Established in 1969 as the international arm of Fidelity Investments, Fidelity International split from the U.S. organization in 1980, and is today owned mainly by management and members of the original founding family.
WSJ Pro: U.K. Regulator Raises Competition Concerns Over Mastercard's VocaLink Buy By Ian Walker
LONDON--The U.K. Competition and Markets Authority said Wednesday Mastercard Inc.'s acquisition of VocaLink gives rise to competition concerns, and it is seeking undertakings from the companies to address these issues.
They have until Jan. 11 to offer a solution or the regulator will refer the deal for an in-depth investigation, it said.
Last July Mastercard said it was buying 92.4% of VocaLink Holdings Ltd. in a deal valued around $920 million. If the deal is completed, a majority of VocaLink's current owners will retain a 7.6% stake for at least three years.
Mastercard U.K. Holdco Ltd., a unit of Mastercard, already owns and operates credit- and debit-card schemes Mastercard, Maestro and Cirrus, and has bid to supply infrastructure services to U.K. interbank payment systems.
VocaLink's technology provides the backbone for non-card transactions such as employer-payroll deposits and consumer-bill payments, processing over 90% of salaries, more than 70% of household bills and almost all state benefits in the U.K.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 27 of 1177

It also unites the infrastructure of Britain's automated-teller-machine network among its participating banks via the LINK network. VocaLink reported $240 million in revenue last year and processed more than 11 billion transactions.
The regulator said its main concern is the LINK ATM network as VocaLink and Mastercard are two of the three most credible providers of infrastructure services to the network across the U.K. As such, it believes the merger would reduce the number of bidders and limit the ability of the LINK scheme to obtain good value when tendering for an infrastructure provider.
"The LINK ATM network provides an essential service for millions of customers. It's important that LINK has a good choice of providers when it comes to supplying the necessary infrastructure so it can take advantage of the opening up of payment systems to competition," Andrea Coscelli, acting chief executive of the CMA, and decision maker in this case, said.
"These concerns warrant a closer investigation in the event that Mastercard cannot address them at this stage," she said.
Mastercard said it would address this concern within the time frame provided.
VocaLink is owned by a consortium of 18 banks and building societies, with the four biggest being Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC, Barclays PLC, HSBC Holdings PLC, and Lloyds Banking Group PLC.
Last July, after the deal was announced, the U.K. Payment Systems Regulator said the four largest shareholders of VocaLink should sell all, or part of their holdings in the infrastructure provider if its acquisition by Mastercard doesn't go ahead, to open up the market and boost competition.
At the time of the deal, RBS confirmed it would sell its 21.4% shareholding in VocaLink and book a £150 million ($183.6 million) pretax gain in its accounts. Barclays also said it sold 13.68% of its shareholding in VocaLink for £104 million, leaving it with a 1.5% stake.
U.S., Europe Spat Over Bank Risk Set to Drag On By Julia-Ambra Verlaine and Max Colchester
BRUSSELS--A fight between U.S. and European authorities over how banks should calculate the riskiness of their assets will drag out into 2017, extending lingering uncertainty over the health of lenders' balance sheets.
After months of intense lobbying by European banks, the international standards setter, the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, Tuesday delayed a key meeting.
European authorities complained that new proposed rules would force their banks to thicken capital cushions and stymie lending.
"The committee came to recognize the initial set of proposals was an overshoot," said a person familiar with the discussions.

Indonesia's Message to J.P. Morgan: Accentuate the Positive By Carolyn Cui, Emily Glazer, Ben Otto and Rachel Rosenthal
Indonesia's decision to cut business ties with J.P. Morgan Chase &Co. after a downgrade highlights the fine line banks and ratings companies walk.
In the banking world, securities analysts are supposed to provide independent, unvarnished investment advice to their commission-paying clients, but a negative word can alienate clients on the other side--the stock and bond issuers that pay banks large fees to help them raise capital. That can cost bankers' access to corporate executives or government officials, and lose them business from the offended issuers.
Emerging-country governments often react strongly to sovereign-ratings downgrades, which can raise the cost of borrowing in international capital markets. The offense in this case, though, was a downgrade of Indonesia's stocks, partly occasioned by Donald Trump's U.S. election win--a ratings change that the country's finance ministry said could destabilize the financial system.
The ministry responded by ending all partnerships with J.P. Morgan as of Jan. 1, including the bank's role as a government-appointed primary dealer in certain bond auctions. For a nation to completely cut off a bank that way appears rare. It was a first for Indonesia.
The decision was the product of several run-ins between Southeast Asia's biggest country and the largest U.S. bank by assets, the ministry's director of debt portfolio and strategy, Schneider Siahaan, told The Wall Street Journal.
It was the third time a J.P. Morgan ratings call threatened to exacerbate selloffs, Mr. Siahaan said--in 2008 and 2015 Indonesia issued warnings to the bank after its research division downgraded the government's rupiah bonds--and the government believes J.P. Morgan has a conflict of interest.
"As a bonds dealer, J.P. Morgan was tasked to find buyers, but at the same time they issued a recommendation to sell," Mr. Siahaan said. "We see they're no longer effective in carrying out their obligations."
J.P. Morgan reiterated that its Indonesia business is operating as usual and that it is working for a resolution with the finance ministry. It declined to comment on possible conflicts of interest.
The bank was working toward improving its relationship with the country, according to a person familiar with the matter, when U.S. voters elected Mr. Trump. Then, in a Nov. 13 report about the global repercussions of Mr. Trump's victory, J.P. Morgan downgraded Indonesian equities to underweight from overweight, saying that a rise in bond-market volatility "increases emerging-market risk premiums."
The report, authored by six analysts led by veteran Asian strategist Adrian Mowat, also made smaller downgrades to Brazilian and Turkish equities.
Mr. Mowat wasn't available for comment.
The next day, the yield on Indonesia's 10-year government bond shot up 0.466 percentage point, its biggest intraday jump since January 2011, to 7.895%. Yields rise as prices fall.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 29 of 1177

While Indonesia's debt leverage is relatively low for Asia, its external debt is among the highest when measured against foreign-exchange reserves, according to Standard Chartered. That essentially makes Indonesia more vulnerable than other Asian countries to a stronger dollar and higher U.S. interest rates, as does the relatively high proportion of government debt held by foreigners--nearly 40% of rupiah bonds and almost 90% of U.S. dollar bonds.
In some cases, banks under fire for negative opinions have sought to placate issuers--or make amends for analysis that could be seen as unfair--by firing employees or rewriting reports after publication.
Ratings firms can face similar heat.
The U.S. Treasury called Standard &Poor's decision to strip the country of its top credit rating in 2011 "flawed." When Standard &Poor's cut Poland's credit rating to BBB-plus from A-minus a year ago, citing its new government's radical policies, the finance minister at the time, Pawel Szalamacha, called the decision "incomprehensible...from economic and financial-analysis point of view."
'It is nonsense that Japan's national strength is lower than African countries to which Japan is providing assistance.'
--Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi in 2002
When Moody's Investors Service downgraded its outlook for China's sovereign rating last March, citing a slowing economy and shrinking foreign reserves, state-run news agency Xinhua answered with an editorial accusing it of "practices that are damaging its own reputation"--namely, holding emerging and developed economies to different standards. Moody's declined to comment.
In the early 2000s the government of Japan blasted all three of the major credit-rating companies for downgrades, including one from Moody's that rated the country's yen debt riskier than Botswana bonds. "It is nonsense that Japan's national strength is lower than African countries to which Japan is providing assistance," said then-Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi at the time.
A government outcry over an equities call, like Indonesia's response to J.P. Morgan, is much rarer.
"There's instances of sovereigns railing against rating agencies where formal ratings are applied, which do have more real financial or economic consequences," said Mark Baker, emerging-markets portfolio manager at Standard Life Investments in Hong Kong. "I don't ever recall seeing an instance where a change of outlook from a bank elicited such a response."
--I Made Sentana contributed to this article.
Equifax, TransUnion Settle CFPB Claims of Deceptive Marketing
By Rachel Witkowski
WASHINGTON--Top credit-reporting companies Equifax Inc. and TransUnion have agreed to pay more than $23 million over federal claims that they deceptively marketed and sold credit scores to consumers.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 30 of 1177

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said Tuesday that Atlanta-based Equifax and Chicago-based TransUnion--two of the three largest credit-reporting firms--falsely advertised how lenders use credit scores and deceptively charged consumers for subscriptions to check their own score.
Credit reporting firms are required by law to provide one free credit report to consumers every year. Consumers typically end up seeing their credit score or report when applying for a loan, and some banks now offer the score free as part of a bank account.
Equifax and TransUnion collectively have agreed to pay more than $17.6 million in restitution to consumers and $5.5 million in fines, without admitting or denying the CFPB's findings.
"TransUnion and Equifax deceived consumers about the usefulness of the credit scores they marketed, and lured consumers into expensive recurring payments with false promises," CFPB Director Richard Cordray said in written statement.
Equifax and TransUnion in separate statements said they already have fixed many of the issues raised by the CFPB. The cited activities occurred as early as July 2011 for both companies, and for Equifax continued through March 2014, according to the CFPB.
The CFPB said both companies and their subsidiaries falsely advertised a credit score to the consumer as the same score lenders use when underwriting a loan. A lender typically uses several different scores that can sometimes include those provided by Equifax and TransUnion to determine the interest rate and eligibility for a consumer credit.
The CFPB also accused Equifax of offering a free credit-score trial and TransUnion of offering a similar trial for $1

Title: When Jamie Dimon Met François Hollande: Inside France's Secret Plan to Lure Brexit Bankers; As they seek to capitalize on the fallout from Brexit, Europe's political leaders must navigate a minefield as they seek to lure banks from London
ARTICLE:
PARIS--French President Franc?ois Hollande met with J.P. Morgan Chase &Co. Chief Executive James Dimon in late October and asked how France could lure finance jobs away from London after Brexit.
Mr. Dimon's message was blunt: The chances that banks would move more employees to France were slim unless the country softens its strict labor laws.
Mr. Hollande--who had yet to announce he wasn't seeking re-election --reassured Mr. Dimon that change would come. But it would happen under his successor , he said.
"We understand," Mr. Hollande said, according to people familiar with the matter. "It's complicated."
The exchange at the E?lyse?e Palace illustrates the minefield Europe's political establishment is navigating as it seeks to capitalize on the U.K.'s June vote to leave the European Union . Cities across the continent are jockeying to lure jobs away from London , Europe's financial center. But with elections on the horizon in France, Germany and the Netherlands --and populist parties like Marine Le Pen's National Front gaining in the polls --governments are afraid to publicly court big banks with promises of favorable treatment.
Instead, Paris and other capitals have embarked on a round of quiet diplomacy with the financial industry to provide assurances that--whatever the results of this year's elections--the world's biggest banks can begin relocating their businesses from London.
In France, for example, Mr. Hollande's government has tapped Christian Noyer, former governor of the Bank of France, to act as a bridge to the next administration in negotiating and implementing new incentives to entice banks, according to people familiar with the matter.
Franc?ois Fillon, the conservative Les Re?publicains party's candidate to replace Mr. Hollande in the May presidential elections, has also met with banks to discuss their proposals, according to people familiar with the matter. On the campaign trail, Mr. Fillon has been a staunch critic of France's job protections.
Representatives of the French president's office and Mr. Fillon declined to comment. A spokeswoman for J.P. Morgan declined to comment.
Banks can't wait around. Brexit negotiations are due to start early this year , and executives have begun drawing up detailed plans that can be executed quickly if it looks as if the U.K. won't secure access to the EU's financial markets .
   PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 39 of 1177
Competition is heating up, and even scooping up a few thousand jobs would have an outsize effect on cities like Paris, Frankfurt or Dublin, whose financial centers are a fraction the size of London's. Their hand is strengthened by incoming rules that may force big non-EU banks to set up subsidiaries and hold extra capital if they want to be based in the trading bloc. This could force big lenders to set up substantial operations in the EU to service clients there regardless of what Brexit deal the U.K. strikes.
Meanwhile, uncertainty over the U.K. government's negotiating position has weakened the U.K.'s ability to entice banks to stay put, Andrew Bailey, a senior British finance regulator, recently told British lawmakers .
So far banks have largely concentrated on scaling up where they already have some operations. HSBC Holdings PLC has said it is focusing on Paris , where it already has a retail presence. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. officials say the bank is scoping out Frankfurt, where it has a banking license, and Citigroup Inc. is exploring moving several hundred jobs from London to Dublin if the U.K. loses access to the single European market, according to people familiar with the matter.
The political climate in France, however, is a stark example of the hurdles facing banks and the political establishment. Bankers in London worry Ms. Le Pen, an anti-immigrant euroskeptic, could win the French presidential election this year.
Mr. Hollande, a Socialist who once branded finance as his "true adversary," knows the national labor code is contentious in France. Before the Brexit vote, the French leader tried to overhaul the labor system but was forced to water down the measures in the face of massive street protests .
In the wake of the Brexit vote, Mr. Hollande's finance minister, Michel Sapin, has rejected any talk of relaxing labor laws for banks, telling a conference on Oct. 27 that the government refused to create a "special status for finance."
Behind the scenes, however, French officials are looking at ways to accommodate lenders. Since mid-September, senior executives from banks in the U.S., Asia and the Persian Gulf have held confidential talks with French government officials about relocating some businesses after Brexit, according to the people familiar with the matter.
During the meetings, U.S. banking executives shared their concerns about the country's strict labor laws, which would make it hard for them to hire and fire high-paid bankers and traders, according to these people.
One option, a French official said, would involve allowing banks to easily fire employees that fall into certain European Banking Authority classifications.
"It's necessary if we want to be attractive," the official said. Inti Landauro contributed to this article.
