from the lack of applying the rules.
Berlin and Rome have repeatedly sparred over Italy's attempts to inject capital into its struggling banks without imposing losses to junior bondholders first, losses that would be dictated by recently introduced European bank- resolution rules.
SEC Blesses Negotiable Mutual-Fund Fees
By Jason Zweig
Ever since 1940, mutual-fund commissions have been non-negotiable. That could soon change.
Capital Group Cos. of Los Angeles, which runs $1.4 trillion largely in mutual funds, got approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday for a novel way of selling funds that it calls "Clean Shares." The structure would get fund companies out of the business of setting commissions and fees. Instead, brokerage firms would set their own charges.
It works like this. Say you want to put $10,000 into Capital Group's Investment Company of America mutual fund. For decades, its Class A shares have charged 5.75% up front, or $575 on a $10,000 investment -- regardless of which broker sells them to you.
If, instead, you were to buy the new Clean Shares, it would be up to the broker, not the fund company, to determine how much you pay.
The move was prompted largely by the Department of Labor's so-called fiduciary rule, said Matt O'Connor, head of North American distribution at Capital Group. That rule, imposed last year, requires brokers offering individualized advice on retirement accounts to minimize their conflicts of interest. Under the rule, brokers are discouraged from favoring funds that charge higher commissions.
Under the new fee structure, Capital Group would introduce a class of shares equivalent to a no-load fund, carrying no sales commission and no distribution or marketing fees. As a result, a broker selling those shares will collect fees directly from clients rather than from the fund company. And the brokerage firm could assess the same fees on such funds as it would on the exchange-traded funds that have been competing so fiercely for investors' dollars.
"We hope this will be a pivotal moment in moving toward transparency on what investors are paying for advice," said Mr. O'Connor.
Robert Plaze, a partner specializing in investment-management law at Stroock &Stroock &Lavan in Washington, said the proposed structure echoes so-called mutual fund supermarkets such as those run by Charles Schwab, where any participating fund is available at the same charge.
"How these shares are priced will be a business decision on the part of the broker, not the fund company," said Mr. Plaze. "The forces of supply and demand will operate on that fee schedule, and that should lead to greater competition."
For decades, mutual-fund sales charges have remained stubbornly high, often as high as 5.75% today. And
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 91 of 1177

distribution fees have run as high as 1%. Capital Group's initiative is another sign that is changing, said Barry Barbash, a former head of mutual-fund regulation at the SEC who now is a partner at Willkie Farr &Gallagher in Washington.
"In reaction to the Department of Labor rule, the mutual fund industry is redoing the landscape so as not to use distribution fees," he said.
WSJ Pro: Fed's Dudley Says More Rules Alone Won't Cure Bank Culture Problems By Katy Burne
Federal Reserve Bank of New York President William Dudley said Wednesday that more rules alone wouldn't cure the banking industry's culture failings and that what is missing is more personal accountability and bankers' calling out others' bad conduct.
In remarks at a financial services culture symposium in Manhattan, posted to the New York Fed's website, he said he was disappointed at the scale of recent market-manipulation cases and they laid bare how the lessons of the initial interest-rate rigging scandal weren't properly learned.
"I was particularly struck by how the manipulation of foreign exchange rates occurred even after the Libor fixing was widely known," said Mr. Dudley in the speech, referring to the London interbank offered rate that banks were charged with rigging in the years surrounding the financial crisis.
He said the New York Fed started a review of banks' culture problems in the wake of the Libor and foreign exchange manipulation probes. "The appropriate lessons from the Libor scandal did not seem to have been learned," he said, adding, "That was both surprising and profoundly disappointing to me."
Banks collectively have paid billions of dollars in fines stemming from those market manipulation probes. Some lawsuits from private investors are pending.
The recent sales scandal at Wells Fargo &Co. is the latest example of bad banking culture, he said. That probe included a $185 million settlement over the bank opening as many as 2.1 million accounts using fictitious or unauthorized customer information, as well as new restrictions on the bank. Former Wells CEO John Stumpf also stepped down.
Mr. Dudley has given a series of speeches on what he sees as a widespread problem in banking culture that drove the sorts of behavior evident in those cases. In those speeches, he lays out how banking is a critical profession and how greater trustworthiness is needed for the public to restore its faith in the industry.
"When each new scandal emerges, the industry is painted with the same broad brush," he said. "This underscores the importance of taking both individual and collective responsibility for reform. You have a personal stake in improving bank culture. Your firms have a stake too. And so does the industry."
Senators Seek More Information About Wells Fargo's Overdraft Income By Emily Glazer

A group of Democratic senators asked Wells Fargo's chief executive for more details about the bank's recent boost in income from overdraft charges and whether it is related to its sales-practices scandal, according to a letter reviewed by The Wall Street Journal.
Senate Banking Committee Democratic senators led by Ohio Sen. Sherrod Brown and Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren asked why the San Francisco bank's income from overdraft fees increased at a rate roughly five times higher than its peers as noted in a recent Financial Times article.
"Wells Fargo's overdraft income has increased disproportionately to the rest of the banking industry in the same way that Wells Fargo's cross selling exceeded that of its competition," according to the letter. It added that compensation incentives for overdraft services in some cases were structured similarly to those for banking accounts and credit cards.
A Wells Fargo spokeswoman said the bank hasn't made any changes to its practices that would result in more or higher overdraft fees for customers. She added that the bank hasn't had any banker incentive compensation or sales goals related to overdrafts.
The bank paid a $185 million settlement in September for opening as many as 2.1 million accounts using fictitious or unauthorized customer information. It has been in the spotlight for the past four months over its sales tactics and faces a spate of federal and state investigations.
Overdraft protection allows customers to complete a transaction even if they don't have enough money in a checking account. The largest banks charge a fee, typically about $35 per overdrawn debit-card or automated- teller-machine transaction.
The senators, who include Sen. Jack Reed (D., R.I.), Sen. Bob Menendez (D., N.J.) Sen. Mark Warner (D., Va.), Sen. Brian Schatz (D., Hawaii) and Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D., MD.), also cited reports from The Wall Street Journal that former and current employees detailed improper sales tactics related to overdraft protection services. In October, the article highlighted instances of managers pushing bankers to sign up customers for potentially costly overdraft protection that they didn't always need or realize they were getting.
The Wells Fargo spokeswoman reiterated Wednesday that the bank has adhered to a 2010 regulation that requires customers to opt into overdraft protection. The bank won't charge an overdraft fee on a one-time debit card transaction or ATM withdrawal without specific customer consent, she added.
The senators asked Wells Fargo for a host of information by Feb. 14.
They seek specific information related to overdraft-protection products, including sales goals, amounts of overdraft fees charged to customers and company policies related to overdraft, saying a response to a similar question asked in late September was "vague and incomplete."
They also asked for a breakdown from 2007 to present of the monthly income Wells Fargo has received from overdraft fees; customers signed up for overdraft protection without their consent; and employees who received increased pay for meeting sales goals related to overdraft products or those disciplined for not meeting those goals.
The senators, among seven other requests, also asked for information related to policy changes regarding fees,

refund requests or other issues in the last 18 months.
The spokeswoman said the bank made two changes in 2014 to "reduce overdraft incidents" but also lowered its overdraft fee income in 2015. From 2015 to 2016, Wells Fargo's total overdraft fee income grew, she said, "due to a number of factors, including primary customer growth and increased account transaction activity," according to the statement.
UniCredit Hit by $8.6 Billion Bad-Loan Charge By GiovannI Legorano
ROME--Italian lender UniCredit SpA said Thursday it will book [euro]8.1 billion ($8.57 billion) in provisions for bad loans, as part of a balance-sheet cleanup it unveiled in December.
The bank said last month it planned to launch a [euro]13 billion rights issue by the end of March--one of the largest Italy has seen--as well as cutting thousands of jobs and selling a large chunk of bad loans.
The move follows a tumultuous year for Italian banks, which have been battered by investor anxiety about the solidity of a sector that struggles with bad loans and low profitability. Italian banking stocks have fallen more than 30% in the past year.
At the end of last year, the Italian government set up a fund to prop up the banking sector, setting the stage for a bailout of Europe's most troubled lender, Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena SpA.
In remarks issued before the start of a shareholders assembly called to approve the plan, UniCredit said the measures weren't requested by any supervisory authority. The bank will book the provisions in its fourth-quarter earnings.
In December, the bank said it planned to shed [euro]17.7 billion of gross bad loans by bundling them into securities to be sold to investors.
The bank also said last month it would cut an additional 6,500 jobs by 2019 on top of those already planned, bringing the total reductions to 14,000, or 10% of its workforce.
The redundancies will require the booking of [euro]1.7 billion in costs for the last quarter of 2016, UniCredit said Thursday.
Shares in UniCredit were down 1.2% Thursday morning. Market Talk: Daily Analysis Roundup

Don't Expect Big Bank Relief Under GOP Plan
Financial stocks have rallied since the election in hopes of a big rollback of postcrisis regulations. Jeb Hensarling, chairman of the House Financial Services Committee. The report concludes that the trade-off embedded in the bill -- a requirement that big banks maintain more capital to escape some red tape-- would be a net negative. "For U.S. global systemically important banks... the incremental capital needed would likely outweigh the benefits of material regulatory relief." The Fitch report estimates the banks would have to raise about $400B more in capital "to qualify for the exemption under the CHOICE Act, an increase of around 43% compared to capital levels today." Analysis: As Crisis That Vexed Obama Fades, Trump Will Benefit
In ways that few appreciate , the financial crisis that ushered Barack Obama into office in 2008 shaped all eight years of his presidency. It drove his regulatory and economic agenda, polarized politics and policy, hobbled output and wage growth, and ultimately helped make Donald Trump president.
Ironically, Mr. Obama steps down as the recovery from that crisis is largely complete, which could leave Mr. Trump to preside over the longest expansion since World War II.

Title: Argentina in $6 Billion Repo Loan Deal With Six Banks; Repo loan deal reduces Argentina's need to sell bonds In 2017
ARTICLE:
BUENOS AIRES--Argentina on Thursday closed a deal to borrow $6 billion in 18-month loans from six international banks, Finance Minister Luis Caputo said.
The deal, which substantially reduces the country's need to sell bonds this year, comes just before Mr. Caputo and other officials will travel abroad to promote the issuance of up $7 billion next Thursday.
Under the deal, Argentina will borrow $1 billion each from Santander, BBVA Frances, Citibank, Deutsche Bank, HSBC and J.P. Morgan, paying an interest rate of Libor plus 290 basis points.
The deal helps assure the government can cover most of this year's financing needs in the first month of 2017. It also takes pressure off officials to issue more debt next week at higher rates than they might otherwise prefer.
"This is very, very positive news for us," Mr. Caputo told a news conference. "This lowers our need to tap the market by $6 billion."
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 98 of 1177
Mr. Caputo said his team has been working to guarantee this year's financing needs--about $20 billion in new debt- -while reducing exposure to potentially higher interest rates that some economists say could result from the election of Donald Trump in the U.S.
"Nobody knows what's going to happen," Mr. Caputo said. "But our job is to minimize risk. This clears a potential cloud and helps reduce uncertainty so people can say that this year won't be tough."
Argentina plans to sell up to $5 billion in dollar-denominated bonds and up to $2 billion in peso-denominated debt, Mr. Caputo said. He added that the government plans to keep investors hungry for additional debt and won't likely issue as many bonds as possible next week.
Mr. Caputo said Argentina's debt to GDP ratio is among the lowest in Latin America and easily sustainable compared with other countries that have issued debt at lower rates than Argentina.
"Most of the time we're not issuing debt to pay for spending but to replace maturing bonds," Mr. Caputo said. "Expectations are that demand will be very good."

Title: Gold on Course for Weekly Gain
ARTICLE:
LONDON--Gold prices ticked higher on Friday, helped by a weaker dollar, and were on course to record a 2% gain for the week.
The precious metal gained 0.2% to $1,197.18 a troy ounce in late-morning trade, just shy of the $1,200 level breached for a while in Thursday's session. Other precious metals markets were mixed.
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 100 of 1177
The WSJ Dollar index was down 0.2% at 91.92, deepening its losses for the year to date to 1.1% as the post-U.S. election rally across financial markets has stuttered.
Gold plunged after Donald Trump's election as expectations of corporate tax-cuts, higher inflation and a faster escalation of U.S. interest rates pulled money into riskier assets and sent the dollar soaring.
HSBC Securities wrote that a sharp upward move in gold on Wednesday--credited by many analysts to investors' disappointment at Mr. Trump's first post-election press conference, which yielded little detail on policy--might have had a different cause.
"The main move higher in gold came after the briefing and may not have been in reaction to anything Mr. Trump said," wrote HSBC analyst James Steel. "A 10-year U.S. Treasury auction was well received and U.S. bond prices eased lower. In turn, the USD fell more steeply and gold surged higher."
Analysts at Citi, meanwhile, said they expect to see "gold price pain before gains," saying the impact of rising rates, which weigh on gold, will likely outweigh demand stemming from persistent political risk.
Silver was recently down 0.1% at $16,81 an ounce, and palladium fell 0.2% to $755.33. Platinum was up 0.1% at $976.25 an ounce.

Title: China December Exports Tumble More Sharply Than Expected; The country is bracing for further difficulties this year given the prospect of a more protectionist U.S. administration
ARTICLE:
BEIJING--Chinese exports fell sharply last month owing to weak demand in many major markets, and the government and economists are bracing for further difficulties this year given the prospect of a more protectionist Trump administration .
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 102 of 1177
Exports slipped 6.1% in December from a year earlier compared with a 0.1% gain in November , China's customs administration said Friday. December's decline was steeper than the drop of 3% that was the median estimate of 11 economists polled by The Wall Street Journal. It also made December the eighth month out of the past nine in which exports fell, with November's small increase the exception.
Imports in December rose 3.1% from a year earlier, roughly in line with expectations, compared with a 6.7% gain in November. China's trade surplus narrowed last month more than expected to $40.82 billion from $44.61 billion in November.
Overall in 2016, exports fell 7.7% and imports declined 5.5%, resulting in an annual trade surplus of $510 billion, below the $594.5 billion trade surplus in 2015 .
Chinese exports saw slipping demand across all major regions except the U.S., which saw a 5% increase, according to the customs data. Though economists said the weaker numbers also reflected a less favorable comparison with year-earlier data, when exports were relatively strong, anemic demand and trade tensions cloud the outlook for a return to more robust trade.
"Overall, exports will face challenges over the next couple of quarters," said RHB Group economist Fan Zhang. He said it is very likely a Trump administration will "play hardball" with China.
Chinese officials are sounding sober about the economic and political headwinds China is facing. Customs spokesman Huang Songping at a briefing on Friday called China "the biggest victim" in the anti-globalization trend.
Ministry of Commerce spokesman Sun Jiwen, a day earlier, cited mounting protectionism as a challenge and said that Beijing will "try all methods" to stabilize trade, including steps to help exporters expand foreign markets and become more competitive.
Companies too said that they're feeling the pinch and are concerned that trade tensions lie ahead.
Hejian Yongxing Tableware Factory, which exports knives, bowls and pots to the U.S. and Europe from its base in the northern city of Hejian, said sales are down while labor and raw material costs are up a total of 30% in recent months, forcing it to increase prices.
"That's led to an obvious decline in orders and our profits are squeezed a lot," said Chu Liping, the company's general manager. "And if Mr. Trump increases trade tariffs, business will be even tougher."
Beijing has allowed China's currency to fall against the dollar--it depreciated 7% last year --but the yuan appreciated 1% in 2016 against a trade-weighted basket of currencies. Mr. Huang said Friday the impact on trade of the yuan's depreciation against the dollar is limited.
Economists said any higher tariffs or related policies enacted by the incoming Trump administration that reduce U.S.-China trade could undercut broader growth in the world's second-largest economy, which has been steady.
"More protectionist trade policies, including higher tariffs or trade tension, could weigh on sentiment as well as economic activity," said HSBC Holdings PLC in a report. It said that China is likely to respond to any trade tensions with the U.S. by accelerating trade and investment links with other emerging markets.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 103 of 1177

December's uptick in imports was due in part to higher global commodity prices, economists said, and that too could moderate in coming months.
Some economists said China is unlikely to issue a foreign trade growth target this year for the second year in a row after missing its benchmark by wide margins in 2013, 2014 and 2015.
Pei Li and Liyan Qi contributed to this article. Write to Mark Magnier at mark.magnier@wsj.com Credit: By Mark Magnier

Title: To Win Back Customers, Fashion House Fendi Thinks Small; Bag charms, interchangeable straps, pompoms prove popular with shoppers tired of cookie-cutter accessories
ARTICLE:
ROME--Fendi, the Italian fashion house that shot to fame and fortune on the Baguette bag only to be laid low by mismanagement, is hot again. And it is thanks to pompoms and shoulder straps.
The Rome-based house has regained its buzz with new products conceived by chief designer Karl Lagerfeld and Silvia Venturini Fendi, creative director of accessories. One is interchangeable straps that customers can use to personalize their Fendi purses or even other brands' bags. The straps--made in python, suede, fur or leather and costing as much as $2,400 each--are geared toward shoppers tired of cookie-cutter accessories.
Mr. Lagerfeld also is offering colorful pompoms to adorn bags. One pompom made of fur and leather costs $900; another is adorned with a cartoonish image of Mr. Lagerfeld himself. Fendi is courting cost-conscious customers with straps as low as $500 and bag charms costing $350. Olivia Palermo and Jessica Alba are among the celebrities often photographed with Fendi straps or bag charms.
"Who...would have thought a customer would spend thousands adorning their bag in straps and pompoms?" said Josie Gardner, Selfridges' buying manager for accessories.
Analysts say the new accessories are catching on. "Fendi is getting a great traction with consumers and has consistently posted double-digit growth in the last quarters," said Mario Ortelli, an analyst at Bernstein.
Fendi has struck a sweet spot many fashion houses are betting on: customization. Other brands such as Gucci, Prada and Burberry are now offering a range of products that can be personalized. Gucci, for instance, has started
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 105 of 1177
offering shoppers the option to have a Gucci emblem or their initials stitched on bags or shoes.
"[Customization] serves a double function" by appealing both to shoppers who are new to the brand and fashionistas who can't yet afford the house's pricier products, says Fendi Chief Executive Pietro Beccari.
Such products are helping some houses combat a slowdown in luxury-good sales that will likely make this year the worst for the sector since 2009, analysts say. "There is new purchase behavior" now, said Carlo Alberto Beretta, chief client and marketing officer at Kering SA, owner of Gucci. "Millennials are more individualistic. They want unique things, not mass products."
Founded in 1925, Fendi became known for bags and fur coats worn by celebrities such as Jacqueline Kennedy and Sophia Loren. In the 1990s, Ms. Fendi, the founder's granddaughter, invented the Baguette bag, a global success that spurred the brand's popularity and also figured in a plotline on "Sex and the City."
In 1999, LVMH Moe?t Hennessy Louis Vuitton SE and Prada SpA bought a majority stake in Fendi , valuing it at about [euro]1 billion ($1.06 billion), which analysts at the time considered rich for a business of Fendi's size.
The new owners wanted to make it the next Prada, but the popularity of the Baguette soon cooled and other products struggled to take off. In the 2000s, the Roman brand repeatedly struggled to deliver goods to stores on time and opened several shops in a short time, many of which were soon closed. As four CEOs headed the firm in as many years, the company lacked continuity.
LVMH later bought out Prada and proceeded to broaden the firm's store network, production systems and product lineup.
Fendi has gained momentum and buzz since Mr. Beccari took over in 2012, after his predecessor Michael Burke streamlined the supply chain and improved financials, in part by playing down its logos as customers tired of megabrands. Mr. Beccari also changed the design and introduced on-site made-to-measure services.
The chief executive struck on a winning digital strategy. For example, it reached the highest engagement rate in 2016 with its Instagram followers and increased popularity on Snapchat by making content--which would normally disappear soon after being posted--always available on its website. The company is now working to offer one-day delivery service and is pushing shop assistants to also suggest that customers place online orders while in the store.
"I came at a time when Instagram and Snapchat were exploding," says Mr. Beccari. "The brand needed to speak to a younger audience but at the same time become more sophisticated."
All this helped push Fendi's revenue last year up more than 50% from 2012, according to an HSBC estimate.
LVMH now is heavily investing in Fendi to squeeze out even more growth, people familiar with the matter say. Analysts expect Fendi to reach [euro]1 billion in annual revenue this year.
"It's not El Dorado anymore," says Mr. Beccari. "Everyone is fighting very hard." Write to Manuela Mesco at manuela.mesco@wsj.com

Title: Asian Shares Weaker as Uncertainty Ticks Higher; Nikkei Stock Average hit 2017 lows in falling 1.1%
ARTICLE:
Shares in Asia were broadly lower on Monday, with Japan among the biggest losers as a stronger yen weighed on the Nikkei.
More of the choppy trading conditions from last week were present, with skittish investors showing their nerves ahead of U.S. President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration Friday. Market volumes were also likely to be leaner with traders in the U.S. offline Monday for the Martin Luther King holiday.
"What was initially observed to be market euphoria following Trump's U.S. election victory has gradually transitioned to mounting caution as the markets watch if Trump will follow through with his business-friendly promises," said Woon Tian Yong, an investment analyst at Phillip Futures.
In Europe, the pound's continued slide added to market unease. The currency slid more than 1% as investors fretted over the likelihood of a "hard-Brexit" scenario ahead of a key speech on Tuesday by U.K. Prime Minister Theresa May.
Japan investors came back from their lunch break in a selling move, with the Nikkei Stock Average hitting 2017 lows in falling 1.1%. With a stronger yen, export-reliant companies were seeing their shares underperform; Mitsubishi Motors fell 2.2% while Sharp slid 4.2%.
The weakness comes as early Monday, the Bank of Japan said an index measuring the prices of goods being traded between Japanese companies fell 1.2% from a year earlier in December, the smallest decline in nearly two years.
Across the region, Korea's Kospi was off 0.4%, the Taiex in Taiwan slipped 0.9% and the Hang Seng Index was 1% lower.
According to Andrew Sullivan, managing director of sales trading at Haitong International Securities, U.K. fund managers might offload some of their Hong Kong stocks to bring repatriate money. This thesis appeared to divide the Hong Kong market, with blue-chip British bank HSBC down 0.9% while rival Standard Chartered rose 0.6%.
In China, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.4% as institutions have been cutting positions in small-caps, some analysts say. The index has fallen six of the past seven weeks and was set for a fifth-straight daily decline on Monday.
But Jacky Zhang, an analyst at BOC International, said things were likely to bottom out soon though. "The market has very little further downward momentum, and the sluggish performance in smaller caps since last week was largely due to mutual funds dumping growth stocks," said Mr. Zhang.
Bucking the regional trend, Australia's S&P/ASX 200 rose 0.4%, buoyed by strong gains in utilities stocks and higher commodity prices. That includes big gains in Chinese futures markets for steel rebar and iron ore.
Investors are taking cues from Beijing's sustained efforts to reduce capacity, as a top official from the coal-mining hub of Shanxi province pledged to eliminate around 20 million tons of coal and 1.7 million tons of steel capacity.
Yifan Xie and Takashi Nakamichi contributed to this article.

Title: U.K. Pound Falls to Three-Month Low on Brexit Concern; Investors fret over the likelihood of a hard Brexit ahead of a key speech by Theresa May
ARTICLE:
The pound traded at three-month lows against the dollar on Monday as investors fretted over the likelihood of Britain pulling out of the European Union's single market.
The fall came ahead of a key speech by U.K. Prime Minister Theresa May on Tuesday, in which she is expected to elaborate on her government's priorities in negotiations over Britain's exit from the EU.
Despite the pound's recent decline, many investors believe that the currency has yet to fully reflect the political risks facing the British economy.
For many investors, the biggest concern would be if the U.K. left the single market, its main trading partner. Over the weekend, several British newspapers reported that Mrs. May will point toward a clean break from the single market in her speech on Tuesday.
Reacting to this, the pound fell as much as 1.6% against the dollar late Sunday before rising slightly in Asian trading hours on Monday. As European markets closed, the pound changed hands at $1.205, down 1.1%. The pound fell by around 0.6% against the euro, to [euro]1.138.
The plunge against the dollar leaves sterling at its weakest levels since October's "flash crash," when a combination of illiquid markets and bearish sentiment around the pound sent the currency plunging 9% in a matter of minutes, to below $1.15.
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 113 of 1177
"Even after a 30-cent fall, the pound still hasn't fully priced the reality of Brexit," said Sean Callow, senior currency strategist at Westpac. Mr. Callow said that the pound's steep fall following weekend news reports reflects this.
A Downing Street spokeswoman declined to comment on those reports or the pound's decline.
Sterling will drop to parity with the euro, or around $1.10 to the dollar, "if the market was to fully price hard Brexit," said Oliver Harvey, a strategist at Deutsche Bank. Mr. Harvey defines a hard Brexit as leaving the single market without a transitional deal.
Many investors and people in Britain hoped, even following last June's referendum, that the U.K. could leave the EU but stay in the single market. But European leaders have told the U.K. several times that it can't have membership in this tariff-free market without allowing free movement of EU citizens, something that many who voted for Brexit are against.
The U.K. economy has recently outperformed expectations . But many analysts say leaving the single market will hit economic growth.
Analysts at HSBC and Goldman Sachs predicted the pound will fall to $1.14 and $1.10, respectively, by the end of 2017.
Westpac's Mr. Callow believes that speculative selling of the pound could force it to around $1.18 in the coming weeks.
Speculators including hedge funds held 65,831 more short than long contracts on the pound in the week to Jan. 10, according to the U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Investors use short contracts to bet on a currency's decline.
Investors are focusing on commentary from British politicians, promising volatile trading in the coming weeks.
Senior government ministers have started to openly talk about how Britain will respond to any loss of access to the single market.
In recent days, the government has hinted that it will lower business taxes if the EU treats it too harshly in trade negotiations.
"If we are forced to do something different because we can't get the right deal, then we stand ready to do so," Mrs. May's spokeswoman said on Monday
Not everyone is buying into a scenario of doom and gloom.
Stephen Innes, senior currency trader at Oanda, cautioned against taking statements on the negotiations at face value.
"Negotiations of this size and importance are bound to involve an element of bluff to ensure that the U.K. would get the best possible deals," he said. "Without actual confirmation of these 'hard' measures, we could be viewing little more than 'sell the rumor,' and we may end up buying the fact."
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 114 of 1177

Some businesses also point out the benefits of a weaker currency, which while raising the cost of exports boosts the competitiveness of some exporters.
Mrs. May also received a boost late Sunday from U.S. President-elect Donald Trump. In an interview with The Times newspaper, Mr. Trump said that his administration was going to work hard to forge a quick trade deal with the U.K.
James Glynn and Hiroyuki Kachi contributed to this article.
Write to Mike Bird at Mike.Bird@wsj.com and Nicholas Winning at nick.winning@wsj.com Credit: By Mike Bird and Nicholas Winning

Title: Strong Dollar Steps In to Bolster Some Economies; U.S. currency's surge aids efforts to raise growth and spark inflation, goals that have proven difficult to achieve despite years of stimulus policies
ARTICLE:
The stronger dollar is giving some economies a boost that stimulus measures struggled to deliver, even as the U.S. currency's rally threatens commodity prices and emerging markets.
By weakening other currencies, the dollar's surge has aided the efforts of governments and central banks to raise growth and spark inflation, goals that have proven difficult to achieve despite years of easy-money policies.
In Europe , the euro's 2.7% decline against the dollar since Nov. 9 helped push consumer prices up at their fastest annual rate in three years in December.
A weaker currency tends to push up inflation by making imports more expensive, while benefiting exporters by making their goods more competitive abroad.
As the dollar rises against the Japanese yen, it has fanned an 18% rally in the Nikkei since early November and bolstered growth expectations. The Bank of Japan last month raised its assessment of the economy for the first time since May 2015, citing improving sentiment and a weaker currency.
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 116 of 1177
"These countries want growth. Negative rates and stimulus haven't done the trick, and they figure a weaker currency may help," said Robert Savage, chief executive of the currency hedge fund CCtrack Solutions LLC. "The world can wake up and say a euro below $1.00 is not actually a bad thing."
A dollar that rises too high or too quickly can become a problem. A strong U.S. currency tends to create headaches for emerging markets and others who have borrowed heavily in dollars by making their debt more difficult to service. Commodities, which are priced in dollars, come under pressure as they become more expensive to foreign buyers. U.S. growth tends to suffer too as the burgeoning currency hurts corporations. For some countries, weaker currencies have provided a tailwind.
The yen's unexpected burst of strength early last year hit the profits of Japan's big exporters, dragged down stock prices and pushed the BOJ to abandon its goal of pushing inflation up to 2% from subzero levels. But a reversal in the yen's climb in the fourth quarter sent Japanese shares to a year high.
The yen's nearly 8% drop against the dollar since early November will help strengthen Japan's economy and improve inflation sentiment, BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said last month. Tokyo now sees the economy picking up speed to 1.5% growth from an estimated 1.3% in the year ending in March.
The falling yen "helped unlock value in Japan's stock market," said Vinay Pande, head of short-term investment opportunities at UBS Wealth Management. "If you can put away the deflation monster, there is plenty of upside in that market."
Mr. Pande has owned and sold Japanese stocks last year and is looking to purchase them again if the Nikkei dips.
Weaker domestic currencies have also helped Russia and Brazil shore up growth after commodity prices plunged in recent years, propelling their equities to outsize gains in 2016. Russia's stock market rose 52% last year, while Brazil's notched a 39% return.
The cheaper ruble helped offset falling prices for the country's oil producers, cushioning the impact of a nearly 80% drop in crude from 2014 to 2016, Mr. Pande said.
"Russia's market was destroyed, and now they are seeing upside," said Mr. Pande, who holds Russian equities. "A weaker currency helped unleash that value."
The International Monetary Fund expects Russia's economy, which has suffered falling oil prices and sanctions, to grow 1.1% this year after a 0.8% contraction in 2016.
Meanwhile, some believe that the stronger dollar's harmful effects may already be manifesting, especially in emerging markets, where rising consumer prices are already high and a falling local currency risks sparking capital outflows.
Central banks in emerging markets such as Brazil will be limited by how much monetary easing they can deliver, as lower rates make their currencies less attractive to investors while U.S. rates are rising, HSBC said in a report.
China raised interbank rates to their second-highest level ever in early January in a bid to support the yuan and stanch capital outflows. Central banks in Mexico and Turkey have also raised rates to defend their falling
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 117 of 1177

currencies.
For now, "most central banks would rather have a weaker currency than a stronger one," said Kit Juckes, a strategist at Socie?te? Ge?ne?rale. "However, you can have too much of a good thing."
Write to Ira Iosebashvili at ira.iosebashvili@wsj.com Credit: By Ira Iosebashvili

Title: Investors See Big Gains Outside U.S. Monetary policy is looser and valuations lower in many global stock markets; strong dollar could cap American equities
ARTICLE:
U.S. equity markets have raced higher , but some investors are betting the rest of the world is about to catch up.
Investors have piled into U.S. stocks since the election of Donald Trump, pushing up share prices in so-called cyclical sectors such as banks and industrials, which tend to benefit from a pickup in economic growth.
Some now believe the next spur in global stock markets will come from outside the U.S., where monetary policy is looser, valuations are lower and shares have more room to rise.
There are reasons for caution on international stocks, from Europe's fractious politics to frailties in
emerging economies and lackluster growth in Japan . That helps explain why stocks in these regions look relatively cheap.
Still, international markets may now advance as investors look for cheaper stocks and move out of U.S. shares that now look expensive, some analysts and investors say.
"We would expect areas outside of the U.S. to outperform," said Supriya Menon, senior multiasset strategist at Pictet Asset Management.
Global economic growth should continue to improve and further fuel the so-called reflation trade "that will see Japan and Europe benefiting and catching up with the U.S.," Ms. Menon said.
   PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 119 of 1177
In recent months, the reflation trade has seen investors sell bonds and buy more stocks across the developed world on expectations that Mr. Trump will boost U.S. growth by cutting taxes and regulation and increasing fiscal spending. International stocks have risen, too, as investors look for a rebound in global growth.
Economists at HSBC recently raised their two-year global growth forecast for the first time since early 2012, projecting 2.5% for 2017, up from a September forecast of 2.3%.
Investors have sold safer defensive companies in sectors such as health care--which provide steady streams of income when growth is low--in favor of morecyclical stocks such as banks, which should benefit from a pickup in growth and inflation. The S&P 500 Financials subindex is up about 22% over the past three months, while its Health Care counterpart has gained about 1.2%.
Since Mr. Trump's election on Nov. 8, the Dow Jones Industrial Average has gained 8.5% and the S&P 500 is up 6.3%. For dollar investors, the Stoxx Europe 600 has risen about 5%, and the Nikkei Stock Average has gained about 2.3%.
One reason for U.S. outperformance is that for dollar investors, the value of European and Japanese shares have fallen as local currencies have declined. In local currency terms, the Stoxx Europe 600 is up more than 9% while the Nikkei has gained more than 12%. But the S&P 500 has gained even more sharply for overseas investors--about 10.6% in euro terms and about 16.7% in yen.
Despite the recent surge, U.S. stocks are facing potential headwinds, analysts say.
That includes the dollar, which in early January hit its highest level since 2002. In the past, a strong dollar has eaten into earnings of U.S. companies that sell overseas. The dollar's strength is a competitive advantage for many European and Japanese exporters.
U.S. stocks have also been gaining as investors bet on a continued improvement in corporate earnings, analysts say. So any earnings undershoot could dent share prices, especially given the prospect of higher U.S. interest rates. When looking at a company, the amount investors are willing to pay per dollar of earnings tends to decline when rates rise.
Recent gains in U.S. equities mean the market looks expensive compared with the rest of the world. Pictet's Ms. Menon said the U.S. is close to the most expensive it has ever been, compared with Europe and Japan across a range of valuation gauges.
On one metric, stocks listed on the Stoxx Europe 600 index have a price-to-book value of 1.9, making them far cheaper than the 3.2 value of the Dow.
"The U.S. will do OK, but I think it's running out of headroom," said Guy Miller, chief market strategist at Zurich Insurance Group Ltd. "We've seen a market that has done very well but is now looking quite expensive."
The recent outperformance of U.S. equities is unusual--international markets have tended to do better when cyclical stocks are favored over so-called defensive shares, according to analysis from Absolute Strategy Research.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 120 of 1177

David Bowers, head of research at ASR, said investors tend to hold U.S. companies when the global economy is weak because many consider them to be safer, more defensive investments, and then shift into cheaper non-U.S. companies when growth picks up.
Mr. Bowers attributes the recent outperformance of U.S. markets to big gains in bank shares on investor hopes of deregulation of that sector.
There are, though, reasons for investors to be cautious about shifting into international markets. Chief among those are European elections, from the Netherlands to France, whose outcomes could challenge eurozone unity and spark political and economic turmoil across the continent.
Also, the U.S. has a "significantly" higher economic growth potential than either Europe or Japan, said Isabelle Mateos y Lago, chief multiasset strategist at BlackRock Inc.
That won't stop some investors from increasingly looking outside the U.S. for returns. Brent Schutte, chief investment strategist at Northwestern Mutual Wealth Management Company, has been reducing holdings in U.S. stocks and adding to international shares in recent months on prospects for higher global growth.
"We're looking for cheaper valuations and where pessimism is highest. That's overseas now," Mr. Schutte said. Write to Christopher Whittall at christopher.whittall@wsj.com and Riva Gold at riva.gold@wsj.com

* The Global Elite Face a World of Uncertainty
* Xi Jinping in Davos, Making the Most of a Waning Era Credit: By Christopher Whittall and Riva Gold

Title: Pound Drops to 31-Year Low Against Dollar; Theresa May expected to say in speech that U.K. is seeking a clean break from European Union
ARTICLE:
The pound settled at a 31-year low against the dollar Monday as investors fretted over the likelihood of Britain pulling out of the European Union's single market.
The move came ahead of a speech by U.K. Prime Minister Theresa May on Tuesday, in which she will say that Britain is seeking a clean break from the EU , in remarks that are expected to provide the most significant indication yet about her government's plans for Brexit.
Despite the pound's decline--off 19% since the U.K.'s vote in June to leave the EU--many investors believe the currency has yet to fully reflect the risks facing the British economy from Brexit.
For many investors, the biggest concern would be if the U.K. does leave the single market, its main trading partner.
The pound fell as much as 1.6% against the dollar late Sunday. In New York late Monday, the pound was at $1.2046, down 1.1% on the day and its lowest level since April 1985. Reports over the weekend in several British newspapers said that Mrs. May would say the U.K. will leave the single market in her speech on Tuesday. Sterling briefly fell below $1.15 in intraday trading during a "flash crash" in October but recovered.
The pound fell 0.7% to [euro]1.1363 on Monday.
"Even after a 30-cent fall, the pound still hasn't fully priced the reality of Brexit," said Sean Callow, senior currency strategist at Westpac. Mr. Callow said the pound's fall following weekend news reports reflects this.
A Downing Street spokeswoman declined to comment on the pound's decline.
Sterling will drop to parity with the euro, and about $1.10 to the dollar, "if the market was to fully price hard Brexit," said Oliver Harvey, a strategist at Deutsche Bank AG.
Mr. Harvey defines a hard Brexit as leaving the single market without a transitional deal.
Many investors and people in Britain hoped, even following last June's referendum , that the U.K. could leave the EU but stay in the single market. But European leaders have told the U.K. several times that it can't have membership in this tariff-free market without allowing free movement of EU citizens, something that many who voted for Brexit are against.
In her speech Tuesday, Mrs. May will reiterate earlier comments that Britain won't seek to "hold on to bits of membership" as it leaves the EU.
"Not partial membership of the European Union, associate membership of the European Union or anything that
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 123 of 1177
leaves us half-in, half-out," she will say, according to excerpts from her office.
The U.K. economy has recently outperformed expectations. But many analysts said leaving the single market will hit economic growth.
Analysts at HSBC Holdings PLC and Goldman Sachs Group Inc. predicted the pound will fall to $1.14 and $1.10, respectively, by the end of 2017.
Westpac's Mr. Callow believes that speculative selling of the pound could force it to about $1.18 in coming weeks.
Speculators such as hedge funds held 65,831 more short than long contracts on the pound in the week to Jan. 10, according to the U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Investors use short contracts to bet on a currency's decline.
Investors are focusing on comments from British politicians, promising volatile trading in coming weeks.
Senior government ministers have started to openly talk about how Britain will respond to any loss of access to the single market. In recent days, the government has hinted that it will lower business taxes if the EU treats it too harshly in trade negotiations.
"If we are forced to do something different because we can't get the right deal, then we stand ready to do so," Mrs. May's spokeswoman said Monday
Not everyone is buying into a scenario of doom and gloom.
Stephen Innes, senior currency trader at Oanda, cautioned against taking statements on the negotiations at face value.
"Negotiations of this size and importance are bound to involve an element of bluff to ensure that the U.K. would get the best possible deals," he said. "Without actual confirmation of these 'hard' measures, we could be viewing little more than 'sell the rumor,' and we may end up buying the fact."
Some businesses also point out the benefits of a weaker currency, which while raising the cost of exports boosts the competitiveness of some exporters.
Mrs. May also received a boost late Sunday from U.S. President-elect Donald Trump. In an interview with the Times newspaper, Mr. Trump said that his administration was going to work hard to forge a quick trade deal with the U.K.
Jenny Gross, James Glynn and Hiroyuki Kachi contributed to this article.
Write to Mike Bird at Mike.Bird@wsj.com and Nicholas Winning at nick.winning@wsj.com Related
* U.K. Leader to Seek Clean Break From EU
Credit: By Mike Bird And Nicholas Winning

Title: Malaysia Central Bank Expected to Keep Policy Rate Unchanged: WSJ Poll; Bank Negara Malaysia is also widely expected to maintain the statutory reserve requirement ratio at 3.5%
ARTICLE:
KUALA LUMPUR--Malaysia's central bank is expected to keep its benchmark interest rate unchanged on Thursday, a poll showed.
All of the 11 economists surveyed by The Wall Street Journal this week expect Bank Negara Malaysia's monetary policy committee to hold its overnight policy rate at 3.00%.
"Rising commodity prices and decent strength in industrial activity should keep Bank Negara Malaysia on the sidelines," Harish D. Gupta, economist with Barclays said.
Stronger economic data in the Southeast Asian nation since the new year has started to ease worries over a slowing economy plagued by weaker oil prices since mid-2014. Earlier this month, Malaysia released November data showing stronger exports, growth in retail sales and industrial production.
The stronger data comes as the ringgit has weakened over 6% against the U.S. dollar since Donald Trump's U.S. election victory in November. The ringgit has been among the worst-hit currencies since Mr. Trump's presidential win.
"The pressure to ease rates are somewhat limited by the volatile financial markets and weaker ringgit," said Julia Goh, an analyst at Singapore's United Overseas Bank.
Bank Negara Malaysia's governor Muhammad Ibrahim said Friday the central bank may introduce more measures to deal with foreign-exchange volatility if necessary, following the slide in the ringgit.
Last month, the central bank announced several measures to support the ringgit including allowing better hedging flexibility in its onshore currency market.
   PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 126 of 1177
"Nevertheless, there is still room for further rate cuts should growth fall below expectations in 2017, and if the ringgit stabilizes at a stronger level," BIMB Securities economist Imran Nurginias Ibrahim said.
Bank Negara Malaysia is also widely expected to maintain the statutory reserve requirement ratio at 3.5%.
However, the likelihood of keeping the overnight policy rate unchanged is expected to reopen the possibility of further cuts in the statutory reserve ratio in the coming quarters, particularly if interbank rates start to rise again, according to HSBC Global Research.
The central bank had reduced the rate to 3.5% from 4.0% in January, 2016 to boost liquidity.
Mohd Afzanizam Abdul Rashid, chief economist at Bank Islam Malaysia, expects Bank Negara Malaysia to maintain the overnight policy rate at 3.00% throughout 2017.
Write to Yantoultra Ngui at yantoultra.ngui@wsj.com Credit: By Yantoultra Ngui

Title: Bank of Canada Expected to Hold Key Rate Steady; Bank Governor Stephen Poloz suggested in October further easing wasn't necessarily off the table
ARTICLE:
OTTAWA--Canada's central bank is widely expected to leave its key interest rate unchanged this week following encouraging economic data and signs the business outlook may be improving.
Ten out of 11 primary dealers of Canadian government securities surveyed by The Wall Street Journal predicted the Bank of Canada would maintain its current rate of 0.5% during a scheduled announcement on Wednesday.
A majority of those economists also said they expected the key rate to remain unchanged until at least the end of
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 128 of 1177
2017.
"The bar to actually cut interest rates again is quite high," said Avery Shenfeld, chief economist for CIBC World Markets. "But the slack in the economy also means we would have to have a spectacular surprise on the plus side for them to think of raising rates in 2017."
The Bank of Canada cut interest rates twice in 2015 in response to the sharp drop in global commodity prices, which hurt Canada's energy exports and prompted many businesses to cut jobs and investment plans. The central bank held the key rate at 0.5% throughout last year, but Governor Stephen Poloz suggested as recently as October that further easing wasn't necessarily off the table.
Bank of Nova Scotia economist Derek Holt said the central bank may use the policy report that accompanies its rate announcement to highlight the stronger jobs and export data that was released earlier this month, along with signs of an improving outlook for business investment. However, Mr. Holt said any optimism will have to be balanced against the risks of greater protectionism in the U.S. and relatively weak inflation in Canada.
"I think you want to signal a little bit of encouragement, but you don't want to risk taking the punch bowl [of low interest rates] away anytime soon," he said. Mr. Holt said he doesn't anticipate a rate increase until mid-2018, at which point he expects the central bank may begin to raise the key rate.
David Watt, chief economist at HSBC Bank Canada, was the only economist surveyed who called for a rate cut on Wednesday. He said his firm had raised its forecast for U.S. growth, but is skeptical that president-elect Donald Trump's new administration will be able to do much in the short-term. At the same time, Mr. Trump has championed protectionism in the U.S., which Mr. Watt said could hamper Canada's exports and make it more difficult for Canada to benefit from a possible boost in U.S. infrastructure spending.
"It's this uncertainty that makes me think that we should be taking a cautious view about the potential impact," of Mr. Trump's presidency, Mr. Watt said.
Write to Kim Mackrael at kim.mackrael@wsj.com
Related
* Bank of Canada Says Economy Growing as Expected as It Holds Rates Steady * Bank of Canada Survey Suggests Improved Business Sentiment
* Canada Job Market Sees Surprise Growth
Credit: By Kim Mackrael

Title: For British Pound, Politics Matters More Than Economic Data; Investors focus on Britain's negotiations to leave the European Union; positive economic data has done little to boost sterling
ARTICLE:
Politics is replacing economic data as the main driver of daily moves in the British pound.
In a reversal from how most developed-world currencies mainly trade, good economic news often hits the pound while bad data can boost it. These moves come as investors second-guess how economic news could affect Downing Street's thinking on Brexit.
The pound surged 3.1% against the U.S. dollar late Tuesday in New York, rising to $1.2414, its biggest daily percentage gain in eight years. Sterling gained 2.1% against the euro to [euro]1.1587. Though a weaker dollar played a role, the big gains followed a speech in which Prime Minister Theresa May set out her negotiating position on Britain's expected exit from the European Union.
Ms. May's speech offered greater clarity on Britain's position while promising Parliament a vote on the final Brexit deal, a detail that sent sterling soaring because U.K. lawmakers have been mainly against the country leaving the EU.
"The speech has reduced some of the worries that things can go more extreme and the government's approach would be more aggressive," said Themos Fiotakis, co-head of foreign-exchange strategy at UBS Group AG.
On Monday, the pound had closed at a 31-year low on reports that Ms. May would say the U.K. is leaving the single market, the EU's tariff-free trade bloc and Britain's biggest trading partner.
While Ms. May confirmed in her speech Tuesday that the U.K. plans to leave the single market, many investors had already taken this into account. Instead, they focused on the greater clarity on Britain's position, Ms. May's mainly diplomatic tone toward her European neighbors, and the fact that a parliamentary vote could either derail Brexit or force the government into greater accommodation with Brussels.
Rupert Harrison, a strategist at BlackRock Inc. and former senior U.K. Treasury official, tweeted that the pound's move was logical given that the "bad news" had been discussed and Mrs. May was now adding relative certainty. Britain's economic performance has consistently surprised analysts since the country's vote to leave the EU last June. But positive data has done little to boost sterling. Instead, some investors believe that good economic news could encourage Britain to push for a more complete break from Brussels, a scenario that they argue will eventually harm the U.K.
"Sterling is almost negatively correlated with the economic data," said Oliver Harvey, a strategist at Deutsche Bank AG. "The market sees that the better the data is, the less incentive both sides have for a constructive deal."
Earlier on Tuesday, unexpectedly strong U.K. inflation data pushed the pound briefly higher against the dollar and euro, but the rise was erased after less than an hour. Higher inflation would typically boost the pound because it could push the Bank of England to increase interest rates, which would likely draw money to the country.
The pound should move relatively closely with economic data. A stronger economy often means more demand for the currency, better returns for investors and higher interest rates. Currencies in emerging markets will often closely track politics, but exchange rates in more stable developed-world economies mainly focus on data and central-bank pronouncements.
Sterling's trade against the dollar has been moving in the opposite direction to Citigroup Inc.'s Economic Surprise
   PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 131 of 1177
Index for the U.K., according to Paul Hollingsworth, an economist at Capital Economics. The index measures whether U.K. economic data is better or worse than analysts' forecasts. When it is better, the measure rises. The index climbed from a score of 2, when the U.K. voted to leave the EU on June 23, to as high as 87.1 in October. Over the same period, the pound had fallen 17% against the dollar.
"The fact that we've had stronger economic data perhaps bolsters the case for a hard Brexit," said Mr. Hollingsworth. "It allows policy makers to be bolder with their ambitions."
The shifts don't mean that economics doesn't matter for the pound. Investors are judging that the long-term impact on the U.K.'s relationship with its major trading partners in Europe is more important than short-term economic performance. Brexit supporters believe that the U.K. economy will thrive outside of the EU, unhampered by EU bureaucracy and as the country is able to seal its own trade deals elsewhere in the world. Analysts and investors said an exit risks hampering trade with Britain's biggest trading partner.
"It used to be a very cyclical currency responding to small changes in expected interest rates," said Dominic Bunning, strategist at HSBC Holdings PLC, referring to the pound. "It's now a political and structural currency." One factor is the Bank of England. Since the Brexit vote, central-bank officials have said that they are willing to tolerate higher inflation. That means that good economic data doesn't have the immediate effect it once did, because the inflation it could stoke may not be as important to the central bank. "You're interested in whether the economy is picking up and what the Bank of England will do, but now the [the bank] says it'll look through inflation," said Mr. Bunning.
Write to Mike Bird at Mike.Bird@wsj.com
Read More
* Theresa May Says U.K. Won't Seek Membership of EU Single Market
* Pound Jumps as U.K. Prime Minister Promises Parliamentary Vote on Brexit
Credit: By Mike Bird

Title: ECB: Going Nowhere Despite German Inflation Anxiety; The focus for investors should be on Washington, and not the ECB and its battles with its German critics
ARTICLE:
Even when the European Central Bank does nothing, it can still move markets. The euro fell half a cent against the dollar Thursday as ECB President Mario Draghi delivered a dovish take on the apparent pick-up in eurozone growth and inflation.
The ECB is sticking with its December plan : bond purchases will be scaled back from April 2017 to [euro]60 billion a month from the current pace of [euro]80 billion, but will carry on until at least the end of 2017, and beyond if necessary. It said it could still increase purchases again if economic conditions deteriorate.
But Mr. Draghi did face questioning about rising eurozone inflation, which reached 1.1% in December, having hovered around zero for the early part of the year. HSBC economists think it could be 1.8% by February, approaching the ECB's target of "below, but close to" 2%. The pick-up is causing disquiet in Germany, where inflation reached 1.7% in December, a concern that was reflected in many of the questions Mr. Draghi faced.
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 133 of 1177
Mr. Draghi emphasized that the rise in inflation has to be "durable" and "self-sustained". A rise in energy inflation alone will not be enough for that. And most importantly, it should be reflected across the whole eurozone - not just in a few member states. German gripes should count for little. After all, during the early years of the euro, the inflation target for the eurozone was only achievable because higher inflation elsewhere offset subdued price pressures in Germany, which was undertaking economic reforms. It is Germany's turn to run hot.
The overall message is clear: the ECB is going nowhere in a hurry. In conjunction with a more hawkish tone from the U.S. Federal Reserve , that could weaken the euro. But the driver of that exchange rate lies on the U.S. side. The focus for investors should be on Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen and President-elect Donald Trump, not the ECB and its battles with its German critics.
Write to Richard Barley at richard.barley@wsj.com
Credit: By Richard Barley

Title: Notable &amp; Quotable: China as a 'Global Leader'; 'Do not let fake news or well crafted press release outshine reality.'
ARTICLE:
Economist Christopher Balding of Peking University HSBC Business School writing on his blog, baldingsworld.com, on Jan. 18:
I want to briefly address the laudatory statements about Xi and China as the global leader. Rather than focusing on the press release differences between Xi and Trump let's focus on facts.
1. As of a couple of years ago, there were less than 650,000 foreigners living in China and only 1,200 had received a Chinese "Green Card" granting permanent residency. China is now the largest sender of immigrants to the United States due to concern about a variety of issues.
2. China is the world's largest user of coal, the dirtiest energy source, and plans to use more.
3. Wind power generation, as a share of all power generation, is roughly 50% higher in the United States than in China.
4. Average US internet speeds topped 50 MBs while in China that number just passed 10MBs and for accessing foreign sites it is significantly slower due to the Great Firewall.
5. The China plans to shut down Chinese access to non-Beijing controlled websites. This is on top of their enormous censoring work and rumored work on their tests to disable the entire internet or their nearly half trillion fake social media posts to push the Party line.
6. An average Chinese tariff rate of 19.6% compared to the US rate of 2.6%. China maintains a 9.6% average rate for other WTO members while the US has a 2.5% weighted average for WTO members.
7. China maintains an [sic] long "negatives" list of industries in which foreigners simply cannot invest. This includes such high tech national security industries as cotton. Even the recent roll back still includes "2 entries, down from 93 ones in the previous version." Even now, most investors require a Chinese joint venture partner and are simply prohibited from having a wholely [sic] owned Chinese subsidiary.
8. China recently denounced judicial independence telling judges they were to do what the Party wanted.
9. China openly admits to imprisoning critics and political enemies of the Great Leader.
10. China continues to restrict international capital flows despite joining the IMF SDR and promoting RMB
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 135 of 1177
internationalization. Excluding flows within China controlled territory, the RMB ranks below the Danish krone for international payments and transactions.
I could do this all day long pointing out the facts that paid consultants and press shills for China are required in their contract to abide by, but we should make sure that we do not let fake news or well crafted press release outshine the reality.

Title: U.K.'s Theresa May Meets With Wall Street Bank Chiefs; Meeting with prime minister follows lenders' warnings about moving jobs from London after Brexit
ARTICLE:
U.K. Prime Minister Theresa May met Thursday with the chief executives of several Wall Street banks, following further warnings by lenders that they would shift jobs out of London to continental Europe after Brexit.
Mrs. May met with J.P. Morgan Chase &Co. Chairman James Dimon, Goldman Sachs Group Inc. Chief Executive Lloyd Blankfein and Morgan Stanley Chief Executive James Gorman in a meeting at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland , according to people familiar with the matter.
The executives talked with Mrs. May about implementation periods and the status of some of their decision making, according to a person familiar with the matter.
Some executives discussed how moving certain functions such as trading out of London would also mean moving compliance and other staff, the person said.
Downing Street declined to confirm whom the prime minister had met, saying the meeting with representatives of financial services companies was private. A spokesman did confirm that Mrs. May had met with senior representatives of other companies including Siemens AG, British Telecom PLC, and WPP PLC, during her visit to the Swiss town.
Speaking to Bloomberg Television in Davos, Mrs. May said she had positive meetings with bank CEOs and other executives. She said she had brought a message to Davos that she wanted to build a global Britain outside the EU that advocates free trade and that she wanted to negotiate an agreement that allows British companies the best possible access to trade with and operate within the bloc.
"I value financial services in the City of London and I want to ensure that we can keep financial services in the City of London and that global Britain, I believe, will do just that," she said, referring to London's financial district. Earlier Thursday, Mrs. May delivered a speech at the Davos gathering where she emphasized that Britain was open for business. The message comes two days after the prime minister confirmed that the U.K. would be leaving the European single market and wanted to be excluded from parts of the bloc's customs union.
Since the U.K.'s June vote to leave the European Union, banks have been drawing up contingency plans to ensure that they can still service clients inside the trading bloc once the U.K. departs.
Mrs. May said earlier in the week that her government would push for a transition period after the Brexit deal was reached. Several bank executives welcomed having more time to adjust their operations. Wall Street employs thousands of people across the U.K.
In Davos, several bank chiefs said they would continue to wait and see how Brexit negotiations progressed before
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 137 of 1177
making definitive decisions on whether and how many staff to move from Britain.
Executives at UBS AG said that around 1,000 jobs in the U.K. would be affected if the country lost its ability to freely sell financial services into the EU. HSBC Holdings PLC Chief Executive Stuart Gulliver reiterated that as many as 1,000 jobs could be moved to the bank's Paris office. However, he added that this wouldn't be until after the negotiations, which are due to last two years, are complete. J.P. Morgan warned before the Brexit vote that as many as 4,000 jobs could leave the country.
Other banks are cutting their presence in London. Credit Suisse Group AG Chief Executive Tidjane Thiam told CNBC Thursday that the bank was aiming to cut head count in London from 8,000 to 5,000 over the medium term. He added that this had nothing to do with Brexit.
Jenny Strasburg contributed to this article

Title: Argentina Sells $7 Billion of Bonds, Moves to Meet 2017 Financing Needs; Finance minister says demand 'confirms trust investors have in capacity to control inflation, spur growth'
ARTICLE:
BUENOS AIRES--Argentina sold $7 billion in five- and 10-year bonds on Thursday as government officials moved to meet most of their 2017 financing needs this month on expectations interest rates will rise after U.S. President- elect Donald Trump takes office.
Argentina sold $3.25 billion in five-year bonds at an interest rate of 5.625% and $3.75 billion 10-bonds at 7%. That puts the government's financing costs down about 200 basis points from April, when it issued $16.5 billion in debt .
The country received offers to buy $22 billion in debt, the Finance Ministry said.
"We're very happy with the results of this issuance because we've significantly lowered our financing costs even as we face an outlook of much more adverse rates than a year ago," Finance Minister Luis Caputo said in a statement. "This confirms the trust that investors have in our capacity to control inflation and spur economic growth," he
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 139 of 1177
added.
Annual inflation totaled about 40% in Argentina at the end of last year, though central bank officials hope to lower that to between 12% and 17% by the end of 2017.
Economists expect the inflation rate to decelerate to about 22% this year while they see the economy expanding about 3% after shrinking more than 2% this year.
The bond sale comes a week after the government agreed to borrow $6 billion in 18-month debt from a group of international banks including Santander, BBVA Frances, Citibank, Deutsche Bank, HSBC and J.P. Morgan.
Taken together, the bond issuance and the short-term loan deal allow Argentina to meet about 65% of its need to issue fresh debt this year, Mr. Caputo said last week.
Write to Taos Turner at taos.turner@wsj.com
Credit: By Taos Turner

Title: Wall Street Struggles to Cash In on Yuan's Swoon; High cost of borrowing in China, country's effort to punish short sellers are cited
ARTICLE:
Across Wall Street, many see further declines in the Chinese yuan as a nearly sure thing. But making money on them is proving anything but.
Investors and analysts widely expect that the yuan will fall against the dollar this year, extending a 6.6% drop in 2016 that was the largest in two decades. The bearishness reflects China's slowing economy, rising debt and volatile capital outflows, as well as concern that the world's most-populous nation could be headed for a trade showdown with the Trump administration.
China reported Friday that its economy grew by 6.8% in the fourth quarter and 6.7% for 2016. While it met China's target, the annual rate is the lowest in a quarter of a century.
But bets on yuan declines generally have performed poorly in recent years, reflecting factors including high borrowing rates in China and Hong Kong. In addition, aggressive efforts this year by Chinese authorities to punish short sellers are discouraging some yuan bets.
Valentina Chen, a Zurich-based emerging-market bond manager at Vontobel Asset Management, said she is "very comfortable" that the yuan will depreciate against the dollar over time, but "in the short term it is very difficult to trade."
In part, that is because so many hedge funds and other asset managers have been shorting the yuan, pushing up trading costs.
Foreign investors typically use forward contracts or put options in the offshore market, centered in Hong Kong. Holding a 12-month forward contract costs 4.8% annually, after reaching as high as 6.6% in early January, up from 2.5% last year. Holding an option to sell yuan is also expensive, recently costing 5.1% annually.
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 141 of 1177
Denver-based Crescat Capital has been betting against the Chinese currency in recent years but trimmed its short position late last year by letting two of its three put options expire, said Chief Investment Officer Kevin Smith. Instead, the company has begun to focus on bets against Chinese banks on the idea that a credit crisis is likely to emerge before a currency crisis.
Colin Harte, a multiasset portfolio manager at BNP Paribas Investment Partners in London, said he is betting on a decline in the new Taiwan dollar instead, since it is cheaper. Desmond Soon, head of investment management for Asia, ex-Japan, at Western Asset Management in Singapore, has been holding fewer Chinese bonds rather than shorting yuan.
Shorting the yuan is "not as easy as you would think," said Mr. Smith of Crescat Capital. The firm's bearish bets against China returned 0.2% in 2016.
This week, the People's Bank of China didn't roll over its expiring medium-term lending facility to banks as many had expected, adding to concerns about a liquidity squeeze and sending the one-day funding cost to as high as 2.7%. Some short sellers in the currency were forced out due to higher funding costs.
Some investors are also constrained by factors that increase the effectiveness of official interventions, in which authorities drive up borrowing costs in Hong Kong in a bid to force those betting against the yuan with borrowed money to close out their trades at a loss.
Many hedge funds and other traders trade on margin, using borrowed money that can become more expensive in a short squeeze, or must report their results periodically to investors, raising the prospect of unhappy questions when results are negative.
China first allowed the yuan to trade outside its borders in 2010, creating a parallel exchange rate known as CNH. Average daily spot volume in the CNH market is about $10 billion to $12 billion, roughly one-third of the $35 billion within mainland China, according to HSBC estimates.
But that market's activity has been declining amid rising borrowing costs, exacerbating some of the swings in short-term yuan funding costs. Yuan deposits in Hong Kong stood at 627.6 billion yuan in November, down 37% from a peak of 1 trillion yuan at the end of 2014, according to the Hong Kong Monetary Authority.
"It's quite clear now that the Chinese are very active in the offshore market, if and when they want to be," said Dwyfor Evans, head of Asia-Pacific macro strategy at State Street Global Markets. "It's not as freely traded as we initially thought," he added.
Everyone isn't squeezed equally. Some groups such as affluent investors with long time horizons can maintain the trade if it pays out modest but regular returns over time, said Sharmin Mossavar-Rahmani, chief investment officer of Goldman Sachs Private Wealth Management Group.
Ms. Mossavar-Rahmani's group has been recommending that clients short the yuan against the dollar since mid- 2015, contending China could face a financial crisis spurred by heavy capital outflows and a sharp increase in debt. She said the trade has been profitable.
Citing the risk of further interventions, Goldman recommends that clients limit their exposures relative to the size of their portfolios and diversify by holding options to exit from the trade at various levels and times.
Axel Merk, chief investment officer at Merk Investments LLC in San Francisco, said he has added to his short position on the yuan recently. He holds longer-dated forwards in the offshore market that are less affected by spikes in short-term rates and is waiting for China to focus more on economic reform than on punishing short sellers.
"The way you fight capital flight is to make your country more attractive to investors," he said.
Write to Saumya Vaishampayan at saumya.vaishampayan@wsj.com and Carolyn Cui at carolyn.cui@wsj.com Credit: By Saumya Vaishampayan and Carolyn Cui

Title: Finance Watch
ARTICLE:
HSBC
Investment Bankers
To Face Job Cuts
HSBC Holdings PLC is cutting around 100 senior investment bankers, adding to staff reductions last year from a restructuring in its global banking business.
HSBC said the bank reviews performance in its Global Banking and Markets business annually and makes "appropriate changes to strengthen and grow the business."
In June, several top bankers departed as part of a reorganization of the global banking division under new co-head Matthew Westerman.
HSBC has been cutting tens of thousands of jobs across its operations as part of a broader effort to improve returns. The bank is scheduled to disclose its results for the fourth quarter on Feb. 21.
Margot Patrick
Guotai Junan
IPO Could Raise
$2 Billion or More
Guotai Junan Securities Co., China's third-largest brokerage firm by assets, has filed for a Hong Kong initial public offering that people familiar with the situation say could raise $2 billion or more by midyear.
The Shanghai-based firm filed for its IPO with the Hong Kong stock exchange on Friday. A spokeswoman for Guotai Junan didn't respond to a request to comment.
Chinese brokerages have been tapping the offshore market to fund expansion plans. Citigroup Inc.'s China securities joint-venture partner, Orient Securities Co., China Merchants Securities Co. and Everbright Securities Co., all launched multibillion-dollar offerings in Hong Kong last year. All three companies are trading marginally below their listing prices.
Guotai Junan, which listed in Shanghai in 2015, plans to use proceeds from the IPO to develop its prime brokerage, personal-financial services and investment-management businesses, as well as for overseas expansion and the growth of other divisions within the firm, according to the filing.
Alec Macfarlane and Ese Erheriene
SOCIE?TE? GE?NE?RALE
Lender to Settle Mortgage Claims
Socie?te? Ge?ne?rale SA has agreed to pay a $50 million civil fine to settle federal claims that it defrauded investors, including financial institutions, in the marketing and sale of a residential mortgage-backed security, the Brooklyn U.S. Attorney's office said Friday.
As part of the settlement, the French bank admitted that it didn't tell investors that loans underlying the security were underwritten outside of the loan originators' underwriting guidelines. The bank also falsely told investors that none of the values of mortgages on properties within the security exceeded the value of these properties, according to the agreement.
"Socie?te? Ge?ne?rale is pleased to have resolved this legacy matter involving a business that the firm exited in 2008," said James Gavlion, a spokesman for the firm.
Erica Orden
