The Depository Trust &Clearing Corporation hosts a financial technology conference in New York. Officials from the OCC and FINRA are speaking as well as industry leaders at IBM and Amazon.
The ECB's Stress Test Framework
In a posting on VoxEU , European Central Bank President Vitor Consta?ncio lays out a new framework for designing the stress tests used to inform macroprudential policies at the eurozone regulator. In keeping with the eurozone's love of acronyms, the new framework will be known as STAMP[euro], short for Stress Test Analytics for Macroprudential Purposes in the euro area. The framework sets out five requirements for successful stress tests.
Tom Perez's Bank-Friendly Record a Bad Fit for DNC
Tom Perez, the former Labor Secretary and current candidate to chair the Democratic National Committee, could "kneecap" the Democratic Party's quest to return to power with his "established record of not taking on the banks," writes Matt Stoller for the Intercept . During his time as a high-ranking Justice Department official and as Labor secretary, Mr. Perez repeatedly declined to prosecute financial executives accused of wrongdoing, Mr. Stoller writes. The Obama administration's Justice Department focused on financial settlements rather than criminal prosecutions in these cases, a position that is out of step with the opinions of the Democratic Party's base, he says.
Over the past six months , traders of corporate loans--one of Wall Street's most manual businesses--have shaved more than 20% off the average time it takes to settle trades. This occurred without a major technological disruption to the business.
Standard Chartered PLC said its troubled principal finance unit toted up a $650 million loss last year, weighing on the bank's efforts to improve returns.
Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC reported its ninth straight annual loss but pledged an extra £750 million ($951.6 million) of costs cuts this year and said it hoped 2017 would mark the end of its decadelong restructuring.

Title: Deng's Take: China's Open Markets--Much Talk, Little Action; Foreign banks must create separate companies to operate in China and face difficulties opening branches.
ARTICLE:
After agreeing to uphold the "One China" policy in a phone call with Chinese President Xi Jinping, U.S. President Donald Trump is moving closer to finally starting a discussion with Beijing over its trade and currency practices. As relations between the new administration and China take hold, however, there are several areas that Mr. Trump has yet to recognize publicly as sore points for the U.S. One of them: Wall Street firms' limited access to China's financial sector.
China joined the World Trade Organization in 2001. After a five-year grace period, the country was supposed to open its doors wider to foreign banks. While that happened on paper, in reality rules have made it difficult for foreign banks to penetrate the market. The share of foreign banking operations amounted to just 1.4% of China's total banking assets in 2015, according the China Banking Regulatory Commission. It was 2.4% in 2007.
In practice, foreign banks must create separate companies to operate in China and face difficulties opening branches.
"As a result, foreign banks have almost no retail banking business, and they can't utilize their more efficient banking services to compete head to head against China's own banks," said Scott Kennedy of the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a Washington think tank. "There are similar constraints still in place for the securities business, credit ratings, insurance and credit cards."
Discussions about a bilateral investment treaty started in 2008 and have dragged on without a deal. It isn't clear whether such talks will continue under Mr. Trump.
Meanwhile, repeated assurances by Chinese regulators to allow the world greater access to the country's finance industry are getting stale.
The National Development and Reform Commission made such a promise in December. Then, the State Council
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 287 of 1177
said it would ease investment curbs, including in banking, securities, futures, fund management and insurance. Its statement was published Jan. 17, the same day President Xi Jinping took to the stage at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. Critics quickly pointed out the irony of an economic nationalist declaring China's openness to the world.
Beijing has kept its finance sector well protected because banks are its major conduit for implementing economic policy. By and large, funds flow to China's corporate sector through state-owned banks, not the securities market. A foreign commercial bank can own up to 25% of a domestic commercial bank, while a foreign investment bank can own up to 49% of a securities joint venture. For example, HSBC Holdings PLC has a 19.9% stake in Bank of Communications Co., while UBS Group AG and Morgan Stanley have been looking to increase stakes in their securities joint ventures to 49%, from about 25% and about 33%, respectively.
Other areas of finance are up for review. A December draft of revised rules for opening up markets loosened restrictions on the credit-rating industry.
Currently, foreign firms can rate domestic securities only through joint ventures--something the likes of Moody's Investors Service, Fitch Ratings and S&P Global Ratings have been reluctant to do.
Most China observers aren't hopeful about meaningful change to the finance sector, given that Mr. Trump has focused his complaints toward China on its trade and currency practices.
"I don't see China taking a pre-emptive action to further open up its banking market to foreign banks at this stage, given already heightened trade tensions, particularly with the U.S." said Matthew Phillips, a Hong Kong-based financial-services partner at PwC. "Trade is going to drive the dynamic between the two countries and until China sees the lay of the land, it might not want to show its hand and further open access to a critical area."

Title: World Trade Flows Grew at Slowest Pace since Financial Crisis; Signs of a modest pickup toward year-end
ARTICLE:
International trade flows grew at the slowest pace since the financial crisis in 2016, but there were signs of a modest pickup as the year drew to a close.
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 289 of 1177
The Netherlands Bureau for Economic Policy Analysis said on Friday that the volume of exports and imports of goods was 1.2% higher than in 2015, marking a slowdown from the 2% rate of growth recorded in the preceding year and the smallest rise since volumes crashed in 2009.
However, there were signs exports and imports might be reviving, with volumes up 1.1% in the final three months of the year compared with the third quarter, almost double the rate of increase in the three months to September. The sluggishness of trade in 2016 partly reflected broader weakness in the demand for goods, with developed economies recording their slowest expansion since 2013 and some large developing economies still contracting. But many economists believe there are other reasons for low rates of trade growth since 2012, including the increased use of trade barriers other than tariffs and a reversal in the creation of so-called global value chains--the process by which large companies moved parts of their production and associated jobs overseas.
While trade flows are driven by global economic growth, economists have long believed they in turn boost growth and worry recent weakness is contributing to the anemic nature of the global expansion. There is growing concern about the impact on the global economy should U.S. President Donald Trump proceed with his pledge to remake trade relationships in an effort to protect jobs.
Speaking at a news conference Thursday, the head of Germany's central bank warned that protectionism would undermine prosperity everywhere .
"It is international trade and interaction that underpins our prosperity," Jens Weidmann, president of the Bundesbank, said. "Trade promotes the spread of fresh, productive ideas and new, improved products. It is therefore trade which stimulates productivity, which in turn is what drives wages higher."
Over the longer term, world trade has usually grown at 1.5 times the rate of total economic output. During the period of rapid globalization in the 1990s, trade grew at twice the rate of economic output.
However, it appears to have grown more slowly than total output in 2016.
Despite the end-of-year pickup, trade experts see little prospect of a significant revival in trade flows in 2017.
"The rise of protectionism is more likely to accelerate than slow down," Raoul Leering, head of international trade research at ING Bank, said. "The uncertainty around possible import tariffs by the U.S. also leads to a 'wait and see' attitude of companies with regard to offshoring, another driver of trade."
Mr. Leering expects trade flows will again grow more slowly that broader economic output in 2017.
Amid much gloom, there are some positives for world trade. An international agreement to streamline the movement of goods across borders came into force Thursday, cutting trade costs by 14.3%, according to the World Trade Organization. The Trade Facilitation Agreement should make it more affordable for smaller firms to engage in trade.
"By cutting red tape and making global supply chains more secure, the TFA will undoubtedly increase flows of cross-border business, enabling more small and mid-sized businesses to reap the benefits of trade, helping to boost economic prosperity and potentially adding $1 trillion to global merchandise exports," Natalie Blyth, global head of trade finance at HSBC, said.
William Mauldin in Washington, D.C., contributed to this article.
Write to Paul Hannon at paul.hannon@wsj.com
Related Articles

* Confessions of a Free-Trade Lobbyist
* HSBC Feels Chill Wind From Trump on Trade
Credit: By Paul Hannon

Title: Standard Chartered and HSBC: Small Dividends From Rising Rates; Both banks are struggling for growth; interest rates will only help a little.
ARTICLE:
U.S. interest rate rises are good for Asia-focused banks, HSBC and Standard Chartered, but they probably won't deliver the punch that investors might hope.
When the Federal Reserve raises interest rates, both banks get a boost to net interest income because they do a lot of international lending in dollars and have large businesses in Hong Kong, which follows U.S. interest rate policy directly because its currency is pegged to the dollar.
Banks globally have rallied since President Donald Trump's election win on hopes of expansionary economic policies and rising rates. Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen lifted rates in December. HSBC expects two more rises in 2017. But while this will help both banks, rate rises alone are likely to add only 1% to 2% to their total revenues. Like HSBC, Standard Chartered's problem is where to find growth without taking excessive risk , or offering too much low-return corporate credit that doesn't also bring other more profitable business, such as selling bonds or cash management. Standard Chartered had a better year in 2016 than 2015, though it still reported a small full- year net loss on Friday. Bad-debt charges dropped 40% while revenues were down 11% compared with 2015. They at least rose quarter by quarter through 2016.
Profitable growth isn't easy, so higher rates are the surest route to better revenues for now. At Standard Chartered a half-point rate rise globally would add about $300 million to $400 million in net interest income, but if only U.S. rates move, the gain would be smaller. For HSBC, U.S. rates alone rising half a point would add more than $500 million in revenue.
With the Standard Chartered's 2016 revenue being $13.8 billion and HSBC's $48 billion, such additions are small beer. For investors in both banks, growth will remain hard to find.
Write to Paul J. Davies at paul.davies@wsj.com

Title: The World's Most Radical Experiment in Monetary Policy Isn't Working; A generation of Japanese accustomed to falling prices have diminished the impact of negative interest rates and other stimulus policies that were supposed to spur wage and price increases; 'people love to save'
ARTICLE:
During Japan's go-go 1980s, Hiromi Shibata once blew a month's salary on a cashmere coat, wore it a few times, then retired it. Today, her daughter's idea of a shopping spree is scrounging through her mom's closet in Shizuoka, a provincial capital.
"About a third of my wardrobe is hand-me-downs from my mom," says 26-year-old Nanako Shibata, who lives in Tokyo. To save on the 112-mile trip home, she rides the bus instead of the speedy bullet train, once a symbol of Japan's rise.
The U.S. appears to be leading other parts of the globe out of an extended era where central banks relied heavily on low and negative interest rates and stimulus to jump-start growth and keep prices from falling. The Federal Reserve has raised U.S. interest rates , and the European Central Bank is considering easing its stimulus.
Japan remains definitively stuck, despite a long and aggressive experiment with ultralow rates. A quarter-century after its property bubble burst, a penny-pinching generation has come of age knowing only economic malaise, stagnant wages and deflation--a condition where prices fall instead of rise.
The belief that deflation will continue has become so ingrained it has presented seemingly insurmountable challenges to monetary policy, a lesson for other countries that are traveling a similar path.
"It is hard to change the deflationary mind-set even with radical policies," says Frederic Neumann, co-head of Asia economics for HSBC. "I would argue Japan will remain in its funk and will remain there for many years."
Japan is nearly four years into a Central Bank stimulus effort involving printing trillions of yen and guiding interest rates into negative territory, perhaps the globe's most aggressive such efforts under way. Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda's shock-and-awe stimulus , launched in April 2013, fizzled after a short-lived spurt of growth and rising prices. Japan fell back into deflation last year. More recently, the inflation rate has been bouncing around near zero.
   PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 294 of 1177
In November, Mr. Kuroda postponed his goal of reaching 2% inflation , all but admitting he is out of ideas. He said in a series of speeches last year that an entrenched "deflationary mind-set" stifled hope that wages or prices will rise, limiting the impact of monetary policies such as negative rates. Mr. Kuroda declined to comment through a spokesman.
Japan's inflation rate has ticked above zero in recent months, which economists attribute to the election of U.S. President Donald Trump, a stronger dollar and higher oil prices--not economic fundamentals in Japan. Few see Japan returning to robust growth and rising prices.
Deflation is bad for an economy because it undermines economic growth. Businesses earn less, so they invest less, cut wages and stop hiring. Amid the economic uncertainty, consumers stop spending, furthering the downward spiral.
The idea behind ultralow rates is that they jolt consumers and businesses into spending by kindling inflation. But Japan's deflationary expectations have become so routine that consumers and businesses refrain from spending no matter how low the central bank goes. There is evidence, in fact, that rock-bottom rates are backfiring by frightening consumers into saving for perilous economic times, not spending.
In an era of central-bank improvisation, no other nation has pushed the envelope as much. The Bank of Japan was the first to lower its benchmark rate to near zero in 1999, long before Europe, the U.K. and the U.S. did so in response to the 2008 financial crisis. In 2001, Japan began flooding its financial system with cash to try to spur inflation and growth, a practice called quantitative easing that was later adopted in the West.
Mr. Kuroda in 2013 began pumping so much money into the financial system--eventually around $700 billion a year--that some investors worried hyperinflation or asset bubbles would form. That hasn't happened. Last year, the Bank of Japan followed the European Central Bank in guiding rates into negative territory, a radical attempt to force banks to lend more money by making it costly if they don't.
Japan's predicament today was almost unthinkable during its 1980s boom, when Japanese tycoons bought trophy properties such as New York's Rockefeller Center and Tokyo real-estate prices were the world's highest. In 1989, Japan initiated interest-rate hikes that popped real-estate and stock-market bubbles.
Since then, annual growth has averaged less than 1% amid periodic recessions. Prices began falling in the late 1990s.
Japan's economy dropped to the world's third-largest after fast-growing China surpassed it as No. 2. The Nikkei stock-market average is around half its 1989 peak. Property prices have fallen broadly for a quarter of a century. Frozen-dessert maker Akagi Nyugyo ran an apologetic advertisement last year after implementing a 9 cent increase, its first in 25 years. Japanese companies are sitting on nearly $2 trillion in cash, idle money that officials contend should be invested in Japan.
The deflationary landscape is deeply imprinted on the 20 million Japanese between ages 20 and 34 who grew up after prices started falling. Wage increases, rising stocks or banks that pay decent interest on deposits are all hypotheticals to them. They live in a world where anything they buy today might be had for less tomorrow. Their instinct is to do the safe thing and economize.
They reject the consumerism of their parents' generation as excess. Some live with roommates in group homes, a new phenomenon for Japan, and dine on $3 beef bowls. If they spend on anything, it is travel. In a deflationary society, experiences don't lose value, while anything you buy does.
Some older Japanese who knew the privations of the postwar years see a worrisome lack of ambition in younger people. Japan uses the term "neets" to describe young people "not in education, employment or training," while "freeters" work unstable part-time or contract jobs. Japanese "parasite singles" never leave their parents' home, and women complain about "herbivore men" uninterested in the opposite sex.
"Their problem is they are too comfortable," says Heizo Takenaka, a former economy minister. "Their expectations are low. We wanted to own the excellent cars. But they don't seem to want to."
Many economists believed the Bank of Japan's 2013 stimulus would be enough to jolt the nation out of its downward spiral of weak growth and falling prices. Mr. Kuroda and others in Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 295 of 1177

government point to an initial burst of inflation and growth as signs the stimulus will eventually work. Others say the monetary policies worked until they were undermined by a 2014 sales-tax increase.
A Bank of Japan survey in October found only 5% of respondents planned to spend more next year, while 48% intended to cut.
Keita Kameyama, a 30-year-old civil servant in Kagawa, a rural province, has been saving around 25% of his $40,000 salary each year to eventually marry his longtime girlfriend. He lives at home with his mother, drives an old Honda and rarely shops.
The central bank's stimulus measures had no effect on Mr. Kameyama's spending. He still salts away his money in plain-vanilla bank accounts. He fears Japan's long stagnation will wipe out his pension, and worries he won't have enough money to care for his mother--a growing concern in a country with twice as many people over 60 than between 20 and 34.
He sees bank accounts, which offer minuscule interest rates on deposits despite negative short-term rates, as the only way to save. Hyakujushi Bank, Ltd. the biggest in Kagawa, pays only 0.05% on deposits and has paid less than 1% since 1995.
"People in Kagawa love to save," says Mr. Kameyama. "I have heard [the Bank of Japan] is trying very hard to get people to spend their money, but I don't think I will be opening my wallet."
Many young Japanese economize because they simply don't have enough money. More are working low-paying and temporary jobs with no benefits.
"Companies aren't growing, and they have aging workforces that they can't fire," says Takuji Okubo, an economist and founder of the Japan Macro Advisors research group. "So there's no room to hire young people."
Automobile, beer and cosmetics firms have slashed young-adult advertising and market to retirees instead, says Yohei Harada, head of the youth-marketing unit at Tokyo advertising agency Hakuhodo Inc. "The role of parents and children is getting reversed, where the parents from the bubble generation still act like children and want to buy the fancy car, while their children in the post-bubble generation worry about their parents' spending," he says. Takashi Saito, a 33-year-old unmarried entrepreneur, was living in group apartment in Tokyo in 2015 when he decided to start a business. His idea: an online clothing-rental company for women who want a varied wardrobe but don't want to pay for it. For $45 a month, clients rent three articles of clothing at a time, which they can return for others when they like.
Mr. Saito thought it would be easy to get a loan because Japan's low-rate policies are meant to spur banks to lend more to small businesses. It wasn't.
He asked Japan Finance Corp., a state-owned institution set up to lend to small businesses, for $200,000. After much haggling, he got less than $50,000. A year later, as the business grew, he asked for more. He was rejected. Japan Finance Corp. declined to comment.
Bank analysts say Japanese lenders have become more conservative, particularly with startup companies that have no collateral, because low rates cut into profits. In the 11-months after Japan's rates went negative last year, Japan Finance Corp.'s loan portfolio shrank.
Mr. Saito raided savings, borrowed from family and is hoping for venture capital.
Japanese clothing brand Uniqlo became a hit in the deflation era, appealing to a nation of penny pinchers with inexpensive casual wear. But customers stopped buying Uniqlo after price increases in 2015, forcing the retailer to cut prices to win back sales.
Uniqlo founder Tadashi Yanai blames negative rates and other central bank policies, such as quantitative easing, for worrying consumers. "It's anxiety about the future," he said in an interview. "They have to stop negative rates. That's idiotic."
J.P. Morgan Chase &Co.'s Japan economist, Masaaki Kanno, says the deflation mind-set is entrenched because it is rational. With wages unchanged for 25 years, young adults don't believe they will earn more in the future.
Some economists contend the government should try even more fiscal stimulus and monetary easing. Others argue the stimulus has already saddled Japan with so much debt--now 230% of gross domestic product--that it
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 296 of 1177

could end in an economic collapse.
Ms. Shibata, the Tokyo resident who raids her mother's closet, recently cut her hours at a job-placement service to three days a week. To do so, she moved into an apartment that rents for half what she was paying. She has stopped shopping altogether. She sees no point in pouring her time into a career. She is pursuing contemporary dance instead.
"I think it's not fair if I get consumed completely by a company," says Ms. Shibata. "Nowadays, we can hardly expect a raise."
Atsuko Fukase and Megumi Fujikawa contributed to this article.
Write to John Lyons at john.lyons@wsj.com and Miho Inada at miho.inada@wsj.com
Credit: By John Lyons and Miho Inada

Title: Lafarge Holcim Rally Could Rock On
ARTICLE:
LAFARGEHOLCIM'S SHARES HAVE JUMPED more than 50% since Barron's wrote a positive piece on the global cement and aggregates giant a year ago ("European Cement Giant LafargeHolcim Looks Rock- Solid," Feb. 20). The stock, now 55.65 Swiss francs ($55.24), could rally another 25% if management maintains its focus on capital discipline and keeps a pledge to return more cash to shareholders.
LafargeHolcim (ticker: LHN.Switzerland), based in Jona, Switzerland, could also get a liftfrom an upturn in global cement markets in 2017. HSBC forecasts cement volumes will be "meaningfully higher" this year in emerging markets, North America, and Europe, the first time since 2008-09 that all three regions could be headed in the same direction. Lafarge- Holcim might be a big beneficiary of a U.S. construction boom inspired by the policies of President Donald Trump.
HSBC analyst John Fraser-Andrews expects LafargeHolcim to have a freecash- flow yield of more than 12% by 2019, up from a projected 6.6% last year. The company could have an estimated CHF1.97 billion in surplus cash in 2018-19, which could help fund a planned CHF1 billion stock buyback and special dividends, together totaling 6% of its market capitalization.
LafargeHolcim management, led by CEO Eric Olsen, has wrung synergies ahead of schedule from the 2015 merger of France's Lafarge and Switzerland's Holcim. The company achieved its 2016 synergy goal of CHF450 million in the third quarter, and then added another CHF100 million to the annual target. LafargeHolcim is expected to report next week that it earned CHF1.49 billion, or CHF2.52 a share, for 2016, on revenue of CHF27.43 billion. Earnings could rise to CHF3.06 a share this year, and CHF3.88 in 2018, buttressing the case for more stock market gains. -

Title: Growth Is in the Cards-and Chips, and Phones
ARTICLE:
The decline of cash has created lucrative new opportunities for Global Payments,aprovider of payment-processing technology and services.Memoto shareholders: The party isn't over.
DESPITE THE PROLIFERATION OF CREDIT cards and mobile-payment apps, 85% of the world's transactions still rely on cash. That is a potential gold mine for companies such as Global Payments, which are facilitating the shiftaway from paper money. McKinsey Global Institute expects the global payment industry to generate $2.2 trillion in revenue by 2020, up 22% from 2015.
Global Payments (ticker: GPN) provides technology and services to help small and midsize merchants process more than seven billion electronic transactions a year. The Atlanta-based outfit has grown in recent years through acquisitions and partnerships, and generates about 30% of its revenue outside North America, including 9% in the United Kingdom.
Global Payments shares have more than tripled in the past five years, to $78, although the stock has been flat for nine months, partly due to concerns about the impact of the U.K.'s pending exit from the European Union. Yet some analysts see potential upside of 15% in the year ahead, based on industry trends and the company's integration of Heartland Payment Systems, a smaller rival that it purchased in early 2016 for around $4 billion.
Global Payments is expected to earn $543 million, or $3.56 a share, in the fiscal year ending in May, on revenue of $3.3 billion, with earnings jumping to $4.20 a share in 2018. (The company converted on Jan. 1 to a calendar year, but analysts won't update estimates until it files an amended 10K, probably this week.) Shares trade for 18.6 times
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 300 of 1177
Wall Street's 2018 consensus earnings estimate, just above rival Vantiv's (VNTV) price/earnings ratio of 18.2. First Data (FDC), another rival, fetches 10 times 2018 estimates; it has a wider range of businesses.
Steven Kwok, an analyst at Keefe Bruyette&Woods, thinks that Global Payments could command up to 22 times his fiscal-2018 earnings target of $4.15 a share in the next year, implying a stock price around $90.
Kwok argues that currency fluctuations are masking the underlying growth of the business, and notes that the midpoint of management's 2017 earnings-guidance range assumes a 24% increase, year over year, excluding currency effects. Much of the advance stems from the Heartland deal, which could lead to cost savings of $135 million and help Global Payments add new customers and services.
Until five years ago, Global Payments and its rivals chiefly provided merchants with software to connect to credit- card networks. The business, facilitated by independent sales organizations, was easy to replicate, and vendors competed largely on price. With margins eroding, the company switched to a direct-sales model, allowing for closer relationships with clients. Global Payments also beefed up its investment in technology and data analytics, to help merchants better handle e-commerce and mobile payments and run loyalty programs.
To aid the transition, CEO Jeffrey Sloan, a former Goldman Sachs banker, bought up smaller payment-technology companies. With the Heartland deal, Global Payments acquired a large direct-sales organization, swelling its sales team to 1,500 people from fewer than 100. Today, the wholesale business accounts for less than 10% of revenue, while direct sales contribute 60%. Merchants typically pay Global Payments a fee per transaction, or a percentage of the amount processed.
The rest of Global Payments' revenue comes from integrating payment-processing systems into software used by customers to handle routine financial tasks, such as billing and inventory management. This business, which involves partnerships with more than 2,000 software vendors, didn't exist five years ago, but is critical to the company's future, not least because it facilitates customer retention. The softwareintegration business has been expanding at a midteens rate, and analysts expect it to generate about half of total revenue in a couple of years.
Global Payments' transition has led to a steady increase in operating profit margins. It forecasts a near-1% improvement this year, suggesting margins of 30%-plus. "We are just getting going," Sloan says.
An investment in more services and a hefty sales force looks well timed. If the U.S. economy continues to strengthen, transaction volume could grow, encouraging smaller and midsize businesses to invest in payment- processing upgrades that larger merchants already have undertaken, says Moshe Katri, an analyst at Wedbush.
Global Payments also could enjoy more pricing power. Heartland typically operated as the low-cost option for customers such as restaurants, leaving room to liftprices gradually. Stifel Nicolaus analyst Christopher Brendler estimates that repricing could add up to four percentage points of revenue growth a year through 2019. The Heartland deal also will boost Global Payments' e-commerce business, which accounts for about 10% of U.S. sales. Sloan says he wants to double it in the next few years.
While investors have penalized Global Payments for international exposure, that gives the company a long-term advantage over rivals such as Vantiv, which has yet to push abroad. Global Payments has focused on striking deals with large non-U.S. banks, including HSBC (HSBC) in the U.K. and Asia, and Erste Group Bank (EBS.Austria) in Eastern Europe, to gain market share. Sloan wants to expand in India and China, and also move into Japan.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 301 of 1177

Global Payments could produce $773 million of free cash flow this year. While the company pays a dividend of four cents a share, it has used its cash chiefly to trim net debt, now around $3.8 billion, and make acquisitions. Analysts expect Global Payments to strike more deals in 2018, possibly for non-U.S. companies. That could liftrevenue and ignite the shares.
Sidebar
The Bottom Line
Global Payments could have 15% upside, to $90, as revenue and profits increase. The company is expected to benefit from cost savings and pricing power.
"We are just getting going," says CEO Jeffrey Sloan of Global Payment's rising profit margins.
Moneymakers
Global Payments' international exposure gives the company an advantage over U.S.-centric rival Vantiv. First Data has a wider range of businesses, and a customer base of larger merchants.

Title: British Land, Oxford Properties Close to Selling London's 'Cheesegrater' Skyscraper; The companies are in advanced talks to sell the Leadenhall Building
ARTICLE:
British Land PLC and Oxford Properties Group are close to completing the sale of a prominent London skyscraper in what would be one of the city's biggest ever property deals.
The companies on Tuesday said they were in advanced talks to sell the Leadenhall Building, known as the Cheesegrater for its triangular shape. The building is a joint venture between British Land, one of the U.K.'s biggest landlords, and Oxford Properties, the real-estate arm of Canadian pension fund OMERS.
Analysts for months have expected British Land to sell its 50% stake in the building to fund other projects and lower its level of debt. But now both owners are discussing a sale. Chinese buyers reportedly have been leading in
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 303 of 1177
the bidding process.
Britain's decision to leave the European Union has contributed to a collapse in property transactions over the past year. But investors from China and Hong Kong have become increasingly active.
A fall in the value of sterling against the yuan, as well as relatively strong returns in London, have made London real estate more attractive to Chinese investors .
Economic and political factors in China and Hong Kong--such as worries parts of the property market are overheated, and the possibility Beijing could impose more stringent curbs on outbound capital flows--have also spurred the buying spree.
British Land and Oxford Properties "are in advanced discussions regarding the possible sale of their interests in the Leadenhall Building," a statement from the U.K. real-estate investment trust said.
"It is not certain that these discussions will lead to a sale of the building," the statement said.
A sale could be the biggest real-estate transaction in London since Qatar's sovereign-wealth fund bought the London headquarters of HSBC Holdings PLC for over £1.1 billion in 2014. The deal, for a skyscraper in the city's Canary Wharf financial district, was the biggest-ever sale of a single building in the U.K. capital.
Olga Cotaga contributed to this article.
Write to Art Patnaude at art.patnaude@wsj.com
Credit: By Art Patnaude

Title: London's 'Cheesegrater' Sold to Chinese Firm for $1.4 Billion; Weaker pound against the yuan reignites Asian interest in property in the city
ARTICLE:
CC Land Holdings Ltd, backed by a Hong Kong property tycoon, has agreed to pay £1.15 billion ($1.42 billion) for a London skyscraper in one of the city's biggest ever real estate deals.
British Land PLC and Oxford Properties Group, the real-estate arm of Canadian pension fund OMERS, said Wednesday that they sold the Leadenhall Building, known locally as the Cheesegrater for its triangular shape. Investment in London property from China and Hong Kong has surged in recent months. A weak pound versus the yuan, alongside economic and political pressures at home , have been driving the acquisition spree.
CC Land Holdings, controlled by Cheung Chung Kiu, bought a different London office building for £292 million earlier this year.
At 736 feet, the Cheesegrater is the tallest tower in London's main financial district. It was valued at £915 million at the end of September.
The deal is the biggest transaction of a single London building since Qatar's sovereign-wealth fund bought the London headquarters of HSBC Holdings PLC for over £1.1 billion in 2014.
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 305 of 1177
Investors from China and Hong Kong bought more than £3 billion of central London property last year, more than those from the U.S. or Europe, according to real-estate broker JLL.
The influx stands out because U.K. property transaction volumes have fallen sharply in the last year. Britain's decision to leave the European Union , as well as high prices following a multi-year property boom, have made some overseas investors wary of current values.
But for Chinese investors, London property looks much different.
Currency has been a big factor. While the yuan has lost value against the dollar, it is up 12% versus sterling since the Brexit vote last June, making assets in the U.K. a bargain.
Yields on London property are also attractive relative to those in Hong Kong, a boon for investors hunting for returns in an environment of ultra-low interest rates at global central banks.
The average capitalization rate--a measure of yield--on offices in the City of London was 4.6% at the end of last year, according to Real Capital Analytics. In Hong Kong, the yield on offices was just 2.6%.
Worries that the Chinese property market is overheated , and the possibility that Beijing could impose more stringent curbs on outbound capital flows from China is also speeding efforts to invest overseas, further driving demand for London property.
Analysts for months have expected British Land to sell its 50% stake in the Cheesegrater. British Land said Wednesday it will use the money from the sale to pay down its debt.
The Cheesegrater's 46 floors of office space are fully let. Completed in the summer of 2014, the building's angled design stems from local planning requirements that preserve views of St. Paul's Cathedral from certain vantage points.
"This sale shows continued investor appetite for best in class, well located property in London," said Tim Roberts, head of offices and residential at British Land, in a statement.
Olga Cotaga contributed to this article.
Write to Art Patnaude at art.patnaude@wsj.com
Credit: By Art Patnaude

Title: Eurozone Inflation Rises Above ECB's Target; Consumer prices were 2.0% higher in February
ARTICLE:
The annual rate of inflation in the eurozone rose above the European Central Bank's target for the first time in four years during February, driven higher by another rise in energy prices.
The move above the ECB's target of close to, but below, 2% completes a big turnaround for the inflation measure.
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 307 of 1177
As recently as May of last year, consumer prices were below their levels of a year earlier, and the 1% level was breached for the first time in more than three years as recently as December.
However, the surge in inflation is unlikely to prompt a big change soon in the ECB's policy . Policy makers, including ECB President Mario Draghi, have been at pains over recent weeks to stress that they have yet to be convinced that the current rate of inflation will be sustained when the rise in energy prices comes to a halt.
"If oil prices stay at the current levels, February should mark the peak in inflation for this year," said Fabio Balboni, an economist at HSBC. "So Mario Draghi should be able to fend off pressures for the ECB to start tapering QE at the upcoming ECB meeting on 9 March."
In December, the ECB announced an extension of its bond-buying program, which is known as quantitative easing, to the end of this year from a tentatively scheduled conclusion in March, though it reduced the monthly value of purchases.
The European Union's statistics agency Thursday said consumer prices were 2.0% higher in February than in the same month a year earlier, the highest rate of inflation since January 2013 and a pickup from 1.8% in January 2017.
However, that acceleration was mostly down to a 9.2% rise in energy and a 5.2% rise in food prices over the year. The core measure of inflation--which strips out items such as energy and food--was unchanged at 0.9%, while prices of manufactured goods rose at a slower pace than in January.
The rise in the headline rate of inflation will likely amplify calls from some parts of the eurozone for an unwinding of the stimulus measures launched since June 2014, when the currency area seemed at risk of slipping into long period of deflation.
German politicians and economists have been lining up in recent weeks to call for a policy change from Frankfurt, worried that the combination of higher inflation and rock-bottom interest rates will hurt the nation's savers. Speaking Wednesday, Bundesbank President Jens Weidmann suggested he would prefer that less stimulus were deployed , and urged his fellow policy makers not to wait too long before removing it.
"The hawks on the council will point to the headline rate of 2% and suggest that it is sufficient justification for a less accommodative stance of monetary policy," said James Athey, a money manager at Aberdeen Asset Management. "Conversely, Draghi and some of the more dovish council members will reference core CPI at a mere 0.9% and suggest that the headline rate overstates the health of the economy so should be looked through." Important in translating the recent rise in energy prices into a sustained boost to inflation is what central bankers call "second-round effects," which occur when businesses raise their charges to cover higher costs, and when workers secure higher wage increases to protect their real spending power.
There are some signs that businesses are beginning to respond to a rise in their energy bills. According to a survey of 3,000 companies by data firm IHS Markit, eurozone manufacturers raised their prices at the fastest rate in over 51?2 years during February as their costs jumped.
"Not only are higher commodity prices and the weak euro pushing up firms' costs, but there's also growing evidence of a sellers' market developing for many goods as demand exceeds supply, which suggests core inflationary pressures may be starting to rise," said Chris Williamson, IHS Markit's chief business economist.
The February pickup in the eurozone is a fresh sign that the global economy is emerging from a long period of deflationary pressure marked by excess capacity in factories and labor markets. On Wednesday, the U.S. Commerce Department reported the Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure rose to 1.9% in January, the highest level since 2012.
Figures also released by Eurostat Thursday showed the prices of goods leaving the eurozone's factory gates were 3.5% higher than a year earlier, the largest annual rise since March 2012. Excluding energy providers, prices rose by 1.5%, a sign that underlying inflationary pressures are building, if modestly.
With unemployment still high, a significant rise in pay deals seems unlikely over coming months. Eurostat Thursday said the jobless rate was unchanged at 9.6% in January, although 56,000 fewer people were without work. Over the 12 months to January, the number of unemployed workers fell by 1.1 million, but that still left 15.6
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 308 of 1177

million without jobs, roughly equivalent to the population of the Netherlands, the eurozone's fifth largest member. The ECB may need to see a further strengthening of the jobs market before it can be sure that inflation is on course to rise to and stay at its target. And that may take a while.
"Unemployment is so high, it could take years to get down to a level consistent with inflation rising," said David Owen, chief European economist at Jefferies.
Write to Paul Hannon at paul.hannon@wsj.com Credit: By Paul Hannon

Title: Lotte Group Revives Malaysia IPO Plan for Petrochemical Unit; South Korean conglomerate aims to raise $1.5 billion to $2 billion from listing Lotte Chemical Titan
ARTICLE:
Lotte Group, South Korea's fifth-largest conglomerate, is reviving plans for an initial public offering of its petrochemical unit in Malaysia that could raise between $1.5 billion and $2 billion, people familiar with the process said Thursday.
The South Korean company is looking to list its Malaysian subsidiary, Lotte Chemical Titan, in the late second quarter or early third quarter of this year. If successful, the IPO will be the biggest such offering in nearly two years. Plans to list Lotte Chemical Titan last year were delayed after South Korean prosecutors charged the parent's chairman and four of his family members with tax evasion, embezzlement and illegal business deals . The chairman's sister was sentenced to three years in prison in January. The conglomerate was also forced to scrap the IPO of the group's hotel unit, Hotel Lotte Co., last year. The planned listing was expected to raise as much as $4.5 billion, which would have made it South Korea's largest-ever IPO.
A spokeswoman for Lotte Group declined to comment on the Malaysia IPO.
One of the people familiar with the process said the corruption scandal won't necessarily hurt the planned IPO of the petrochemical unit, given that its operations aren't linked to the problems at the parent. Credit Suisse AG, J.P. Morgan Chase &Co. and Malayan Banking Bhd. have been appointed to manage the IPO. CIMB Group Holdings Bhd., HSBC and Nomura Securities Co. are also involved in the deal.
Lotte's Malaysian petrochemical operations include 11 process facilities, two cogeneration plants and three tank farms, located in the southern state of Johor bordering Singapore, according to its website. The company produces plastics, including polyethylene, which is used in shopping bags and toys, and polypropylene, found in battery casings and car parts. The company also makes olefins, which is used in the manufacturing of detergents
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 310 of 1177
and rubbers.
Lotte Group is a diversified business empire whose interests span duty-free stores, luxury hotels and insurance. The conglomerate boasts annual sales of about $74 billion, and has been run by the Shin family since it was established by Shin Kyuk-ho in 1948 as a maker of chewing gum.
Lotte's troubles escalated last year when authorities in South Korea launched an investigation into alleged financial wrongdoing at the parent. In a statement released October , Lotte apologized for "causing concern" and said the company would cooperate with the trial process.
The planned listing could help revive the IPO market in Malaysia, which has faced a drought of such deals. The country's biggest IPO to date is the nearly $800 million raised by power producer Malakoff Corp. Bhd. in May 2015 . Jonathan Cheng in Seoul contributed to this article.
Write to Yantoultra Ngui at yantoultra.ngui@wsj.com and P.R. Venkat at venkat.pr@wsj.com

Title: Foreign Investors Spurn China's Markets; Concerns ranging from tight capital controls to a lack of transparency to expensive valuations have kept money managers on the sidelines
ARTICLE:
SHANGHAI--China is opening its financial markets more than ever to global investors, hoping the charm offensive will attract more money just as it struggles to stem heavy capital withdrawals.
The expected gusher of funds hasn't materialized.
In just over 12 months, China has opened its $9 trillion bond market to overseas investors and launched a trading link between the Shenzhen and Hong Kong stock markets that allows foreigners to trade the shares of some of the country's fastest-expanding companies. This week, Chinese regulators allowed overseas investors in its bond
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 312 of 1177
market to buy financial products traded domestically that will let them hedge currency risks.
But while foreigners may have long sought to invest in stocks and bonds in China, where annual economic growth is near 7%, as the last great frontier in global markets, they have so far been hesitant.
Overseas investors' Chinese bondholdings dropped to 1.3% of the total outstanding by the end of last year, a fall from 1.4% before the market's broad opening in February 2016. Money flowing into Shenzhen stocks from Hong Kong has been tepid, averaging just 5% of the daily 13 billion yuan ($1.89 billion) quota allowed in February. The trend is similar for a trading link between Shanghai and Hong Kong set up in 2014.
Investors cite several worries, including time-consuming registration processes and confusion over the tax rules on capital gains. Some said markets in China are too expensive. Shares on Shenzhen's small-cap ChiNext board trade at 71 times earnings. The yuan's slide in the past year has put off many, even though the slump has paused recently.
Others refer to regular state interventions in markets, such as the heavy share-buying by government-backed funds whenever Chinese stocks dip. Another worry: whether, given China's tight capital controls, investors will be able to get their money out of China as readily as it is being welcomed in.
"There's a risk that at any point the authorities can step in. That risk must be compensated for foreign investors, for example, by a cheaper market," said Lukas Daalder, chief investment officer at Robeco Investment Solutions in Rotterdam, the Netherlands.
For China, where monthly capital withdrawals are roughly $30 billion to $60 billion, according to Goldman Sachs Group Inc. analysts, there is a big potential prize from further opening up its markets.
Stock-index provider MSCI Inc. has kept mainland-listed Chinese stocks out of its key indexes, citing concerns such as restrictions on capital withdrawals. Some $500 billion could in time pour into Chinese shares, about 10% of the market's total value, if they were included in the MSCI Emerging Markets Index, HSBC Holdings PLC analysts estimated last summer.
Chinese bonds, meanwhile, aren't included in major bond indexes run by banks like J.P. Morgan Chase &Co. and Citigroup Inc. that are commonly tracked by global fund managers, partly because of concerns about issues like market regulation and capital controls. Goldman reckons some $250 billion could eventually flow into Chinese debt markets if the bonds were admitted.
Some investors who have been eager to jump into China said regulators' latest move to give them more ability to hedge risks resolved a big hang-up.
"Now we are ready, we are finalizing" plans to invest in the onshore market, said Jean-Charles Sambor, deputy head of emerging-market fixed income at BNP Paribas Investment Partners in London, which manages [euro]560 billion ($591 billion). "Regulatory issues are gradually being clarified; we are much more comfortable."
Still, few foreign asset managers have created funds dedicated to China's onshore bond market, said Chantal Grinderslev, senior adviser at Z-Ben Advisors, a Shanghai-based strategic consultant, given a lack of demand from investors. Exceptions include U.S.-based hedge fund Bridgewater Associates LP, which has registered seven products to invest in Chinese bonds. A Bridgewater spokesman said the fund is "looking forward to investing in China and are moving forward to do that.".
"No one wants to be at a cocktail party saying they don't have a China strategy," said Ms. Grinderslev. "But for the majority of firms, it's more lip service than action."
U.K.-based Standard Life Investments is typical of major investment funds keeping their China powder dry. A big turnoff is Chinese regulators' lack of transparency, said Mark Baker, an emerging-market portfolio manager at the firm in Hong Kong, adding that currently unfavorable market conditions--from rising inflation, which hurts bondholders by eating away at the value of future payments, to a weakening currency--have taken away any urgency to invest in China.
"It doesn't really feel like a slam-dunk trade at the moment," said Mr. Baker. "We're just not there banging the table asking for access on the basis of the investment opportunity alone."
Wayne Bowers, executive vice president of Northern Trust Asset Management, which manages $942 billion, said
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 313 of 1177

another concern is the absence of a level playing field between domestic and foreign firms in the country. "One of the questions we ask on a regular basis is how I am going to be treated both in terms of liquidity, withholding tax and underlying regulatory oversight," said Mr. Bowers.
Write to Shen Hong at hong.shen@wsj.com , Anjie Zheng at Anjie.Zheng@wsj.com and Rachel Rosenthal at Rachel.Rosenthal@wsj.com
Credit: By Shen Hong, Anjie Zheng and Rachel Rosenthal

Title: The Big Losers From Investment Banking's Shrinking Pie; The banks still reshaping their books and strategies are falling behind
ARTICLE:
The global investment banking pie is shrinking and what is worse, Europeans are getting a thinner share. Investment banking and trading revenue fell in 2016 for the fourth year in a row, according to Coalition, an independent research firm. Revenue has shrunk on average more than 3% a year since 2012.
But many of Europe's biggest investment banks are doing worse than this. They may have reported big recoveries in fourth-quarter activity, but the last three months of 2015 were a washout, so the comparison was generous. More importantly, the Europeans still lagged behind U.S. rivals, suggesting they continue to lose market share. Part of the problem is that they are still shrinking their balance sheets or increasing their capital--or both--long after their U.S. rivals have made these adjustments.
The European investment banks that were biggest in the past are still struggling most with profitability. It is the second-tier investment banks that are reporting better returns, according to Goldman Sachs analysts: BNP Paribas, HSBC and Socie?te? Ge?ne?rale. One big reason: they are paying out less in penalties for past wrongdoing. In revenue terms, the picture is more mixed, but one thing is clear: almost all the Europeans are finding it tough to attract business while being stingier with their capital, or taking less risk.
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 317 of 1177
One way to track this is to look at the amount of quarterly revenue they produce per dollar, or euro, or Swiss franc of risk-weighted assets they have in their investment bank and markets divisions.
The bigger investment banks, Barclays, Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank and UBS, all finished 2016 producing less revenue per unit of risk than they did at the start of 2015. Deutsche did by far the worst with the last quarter of last year being almost 40% worse than the first quarter of 2015. The German bank has by far the largest restructuring job on its hands and has lost clients due to concerns about its stability.
Credit Suisse and UBS, lost 24% and 31% respectively. They had a particularly strong start to 2015 due to activity generated by the Swiss National Bank's shock move to delink its currency from the dollar. But take the second quarter of 2015 as the starting point to adjust for this and both banks' revenue per unit of risk is still down more than 20%.
In fact, of all seven banks, only HSBC did better in the final quarter of 2016 than at the start of 2015, suggesting it is capturing investment banking activity from rivals.
U.S. banks are helped by America's capital markets being bigger, deeper and recovering more rapidly, while Europe's remain slow and Asia's more dependent upon a fickle class of wealthy individuals. President Donald Trump looks likely to loosen regulatory reins, giving U.S. banks even more boost. Unless Europeans get better at sweating the capital they have, they will continue to lose ground.
Write to Paul J. Davies at paul.davies@wsj.com
