Title: SEC's Piwowar Blasts Fiduciary Rule | Fed Approves Morgan Stanley's Revised Capital Plan | CFPB Raps Credit-Reporting Firms | Texas AG Scores Win Against SEC | Rubin's Take: Hurdle to Deregulation--Banks Are Doing Well; The Wall Street Journal's financial regulation newsletter for Friday, March 3, 2017.
ARTICLE:
Rubin's Take: Hurdle to Deregulation--Banks Are Doing Well
SEC's Piwowar: Obama-Era Retirement-Savings Rule Boon for Trial Lawyers Morgan Stanley's Revised Capital Plan Approved by Fed
CFPB Chief Puts Credit-Reporting Firms on Notice
Foreign Investors Spurn China's Markets
Note to Readers
Starting the week of March 6, this newsletter will appear in your inbox from WSJ Pro Financial Regulation, replacing the current "from" name of Jacob Schlesinger, WSJ Pro. The newsletter will continue to be delivered from access@interactive.wsj.com.
Hurdle to Deregulation--Banks Are Doing Well
Republicans have been waiting since 2010 to make wholesale changes to the Dodd-Frank Act--but now, when they finally control both the White House and Congress, they are running up against an unexpected political challenge: a good portion of the financial sector is doing just fine.
For years, Republicans' case for major changes to financial regulatory policy has been buoyed by adverse lending and credit conditions. But of late, many banking indicators have been quite positive.
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. released data this week showing the U.S. banking industry's annual profits hit a record in 2016 . A survey from the National Federation of Independent Business , cited by Federal Reserve Chairwoman Janet Yellen in her testimony on Capitol Hill last month, found that just 2% of small business owners surveyed cited credit access as a problem. And U.S. bank-loan growth has outpaced GDP growth since 2011, according to Fitch Ratings.
"We have seen healthy growth in actual lending in the economy," Ms. Yellen said at the hearing .
Of course, the picture isn't all rosy. Small-business lending in June 2016 was down by nearly $100 billion from
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 320 of 1177
June 2008. The number of community banks, which provide more than half of small-business loan volume, has declined by roughly 28% since the financial crisis.
Based on that, Paul Kupiec of the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative think tank, reaches a profoundly different conclusion than Ms. Yellen: "The data tell us that, overall, bank lending growth remains anemic."
It's true the available data allow for different, but both fact-based, conclusions about the current overall credit landscape.
Still, even the most vociferous defenders of Dodd-Frank--including the Senate Banking Committee's top Democrat, Sherrod Brown--support tweaking aspects to provide for community-bank relief.
It will be far more difficult to win support for changes to the regulatory regime for large banks, for several reasons: Democrats, including red-state senators who are up for re-election in 2018, have little to gain by supporting such changes. Additionally, the banks themselves are lukewarm toward--if not opposed to--a large-scale overhaul of regulations they have spent millions to comply with over the past several years. And with a ready-made attack-ad soundbite about how banks had record profits in 2016, many Republicans may find that their energy is better spent on more popular priorities, like revamping the tax code or making changes to the Affordable Care Act.
It's already becoming clear that financial deregulation isn't a top priority for Congress or the White House. It went unmentioned during President Donald Trump's address to Congress this week, and Republican leaders on Capitol Hill continue to delay their plans to introduce Dodd-Frank overhaul legislation.
Republican leaders are well aware that the window for passing major legislation is short and political capital is not unlimited. It's unclear whether financial deregulation will make the cut.
Key Developments in Washington, on Wall Street, and Beyond
SEC's Piwowar: Obama-Era Retirement-Savings Rule Boon for Trial Lawyers
By Dave Michaels
WASHINGTON--The acting head of the Securities and Exchange Commission blasted a regulation opposed by stockbrokers and the Trump administration, saying the rule was written to "increase profits" for trial lawyers.
Michael Piwowar Thursday added his voice to a strident debate over the future of the retirement-savings regulation known as the "fiduciary" rule. The Labor Department plans to delay the rule by 60 days, setting the stage for its repeal or considerable revision.
Mr. Piwowar said the rule was "highly political" and was "never about investor protection."
The regulation, widely opposed by Republicans in Congress, would hold brokers to a higher standard when they advise investors saving for retirement. Under the rule, investors using individual retirement accounts would have a new right to sue brokers who don't adhere to the best-interest standard. Wall Street groups have said the SEC should have written the rule because the agency oversees all of Wall Street, not only retirement accounts such as IRAs and 401Ks.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 321 of 1177

"I have a very nuanced view of the DOL fiduciary-duty rule," Mr. Piwowar said at a conference sponsored by the Investment Adviser Association. "I think it is a terrible, horrible, no good, very bad rule."
Mr. Piwowar's comments show how unlikely the SEC is to propose stricter standards for brokers even if the Labor Department's effort is rescinded.
If the SEC were to draft its own version of the rule, the commission should focus its efforts much more narrowly, perhaps by restricting the practice of brokers holding themselves out as "financial advisers," Mr. Piwowar said. The title may confuse investors who don't understand that the person might be a broker, not an investment adviser, who is held to a higher standard under the law, he said.
"If someone calls themselves a financial adviser, that means absolutely nothing," he said.
Under federal law, investment advisers must put their clients' interest ahead of their own financial gain. Brokers are held to a lower standard of care, known as suitability, that says investment recommendations must fit a client's goals or risk tolerance.
Mr. Piwowar also said he wasn't "enamored with" a proposal--floated by former Chairman Mary Jo White--to outsource some exams of investment advisers.
Lacking enough manpower, the SEC only examines about 11% of all advisers annually for compliance with federal securities laws. The SEC has never examined thousands of money managers it oversees, despite adding scores of examiners and doubling its spending over the last 13 years.
Using outside examiners, such as audit firms, would require the SEC to beef up its own oversight of those third parties, he said.
"It's not a free lunch," he said.
Morgan Stanley's Revised Capital Plan Approved by Fed By Ryan Tracy
WASHINGTON-- Morgan Stanley received approval from the Federal Reserve for a revised plan to return capital to shareholders, a positive development for the bank after the central bank rebuked its planning processes in last year's "stress tests."
The bank was the only top U.S. firm in 2016 not to receive full approval from the Fed for its plans to return capital to shareholders as part of the annual tests. The Fed gave Morgan Stanley a "conditional non-objection" to its capital plan, meaning the firm had to resubmit a plan to address the regulator's perceived shortcomings. The Fed said at the time that Morgan Stanley's capital planning process "exhibited material weaknesses."
On Thursday the Fed said it had approved the resubmitted plan "as a result of progress made by the firm in addressing deficiencies." The stress-testing exercise is already under way again this year for Morgan Stanley and other banks, with results likely in June.
WSJ Pro: CFPB Chief Puts Credit-Reporting Firms on Notice
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 322 of 1177

By Yuka Hayashi
WASHINGTON--The head of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau on Thursday urged credit-reporting companies to improve how they resolve disputes with consumers and vowed to keep scrutinizing the accuracy and quality of credit reports.
CFPB Director Richard Cordray said credit-reporting firms as well as companies that furnish information to them, such as banks and credit-card companies, must make investments to upgrade their systems so they can better identify and correct errors in reports and respond to consumer inquiries and complaints.
The warning follows the CFPB's January enforcement action against two major credit-reporting companies, Equifax Inc. and TransUnion, over alleged deceptive marketing and selling of credit scores to customers. The two companies agreed to settle the claims by collectively paying more than $17.6 million in restitution to consumers and $5.5 million in fines, without admitting or denying the CFPB's findings.
Credit-reporting companies track consumers' credit history and produce reports used by financial companies to determine their eligibility to take out mortgages and auto loans, and in some instances even to get a job.
Signaling its intention to police the industry closely, the watchdog agency on Thursday released a report detailing what its examiners look for while conducting examinations and highlighting problems uncovered in the sector. And as a way to improve consumers' access to credit reports, the agency expanded its Open Credit Score Initiative by releasing a list of companies that offer credit-card customers--and sometimes the general public--free access to credit scores.
"The era of 'dispute purgatory,' where consumers have to spend months or even years making repeated efforts to dispute inaccurate, negative information in order to get someone's attention, should become a thing of the past," Mr. Cordray said at a meeting of the bureau's advisory board members representing industry and consumer groups.
The CFPB, established after the financial crisis to improve consumer protection, in 2012 became the first government agency to supervise the national consumer-credit-reporting companies. They are among the financial- servicing companies that cater to banks and other financial firms, where consumers cannot "vote with their feet" by choosing another provider when they are dissatisfied. The CFPB has recently ratcheted up scrutiny of these sectors, including mortgage and student-loan servicing companies.
As of Feb. 1, the CFPB has handled 185,700 complaints from consumers related to credit-reporting firms, accounting for one in six complaints it receives.
SEC Civil Claims Against Texas Attorney General Are Dismissed By Dave Michaels
A federal judge dismissed civil claims that Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton defrauded investors by recruiting them to invest in a technology company without disclosing he was being compensated to promote the company's stock.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 323 of 1177

U.S. District Judge Amos Mazzant dealt the Securities and Exchange Commission a wholesale defeat in an opinion that rejected every claim it made about the legality of Mr. Paxton's conduct. Judge Mazzant found Mr. Paxton didn't have a duty to tell investors he got shares in the company, Servergy Inc., in exchange for raising $840,000 in investor funds.
"Paxton's conduct simply does not give rise to liability under federal securities laws," Judge Mazzant wrote.
"I have maintained all along this whole saga is a political witch hunt," Mr. Paxton said in a written statement. "Today's ruling...confirms that these charges were baseless when the SEC initially brought them."
SEC spokesman John Nester declined to comment.
The alleged violations took place before Mr. Paxton's election as attorney general, dating to a time when he was a state lawmaker representing a suburban Dallas district. Since being elected attorney general in 2015, Mr. Paxton has continued a tradition among Republican state officeholders of suing the U.S. government over federal policies and laws he disputes, such as challenging former President Barack Obama's plan to defer deportation of several million people in the country illegally.
The SEC case against Mr. Paxton turned on the regulator's claim that he had a fiduciary duty to disclose his compensation to people he recruited as investors, including members of a private investment club. The SEC argued Mr. Paxton's relationship with the group--he was a member of it--meant that he should have told fellow members he received 100,000 Servergy shares to find investors for the computer company, which develops secure, cloud-based servers.
The SEC said Mr. Paxton told the group that Servergy was a "great company" and even told one member of the investment group that the offering price would double in the next week if he didn't invest.
However, Judge Mazzant decided that the SEC failed to show that Mr. Paxton's relationship with the group's members meant he owed them a duty to disclose his compensation.
"Whether or not someone thinks he should have done that, it does not justify the SEC bringing a case that has no plausible legal basis," said Matthew Martens, a partner at Wilmer Cutler Pickering Hale and Dorr LLP who represented Mr. Paxton.
Mr. Paxton still faces state criminal charges in Texas related to similar claims. A grand jury in Collin County, north of Dallas, indicted Mr. Paxton in 2015 on charges including two first-degree felonies relating to securities fraud and one third-degree felony related to failing to register as an investment adviser. Mr. Paxton has pleaded not guilty and has said he won't resign, which state Democrats have called for him to do.
'Flash Boys' Exchange IEX Criticizes Nasdaq Order-Type Proposal By Alexander Osipovich
IEX Group Inc. criticized a proposal for a new way to submit stock orders by Nasdaq Inc., saying it would enable "predatory trading strategies" that hurt investors.
In November, Nasdaq unveiled a proposal for an "extended life" order type, which would encourage the posting of
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 324 of 1177

buy and sell orders on the Nasdaq Stock Market that last at least one second.
In return for a commitment to keep the order live for a second or longer, the order would gain priority over others. Nasdaq's proposed order type has been seen as an alternative to IEX's best-known feature, the "speed bump," a delay imposed to thwart certain predatory high-speed trading strategies.
IEX said in a letter to the Securities and Exchange Commission Thursday that the proposal "raises significant concerns about the potential for information leakage." The letter was a fresh salvo against incumbent stock exchanges from IEX, made famous by Michael Lewis' 2014 book "Flash Boys," which cast the firm's founders as advocates of investors fed up with rapid-fire trading.
Nasdaq's extended-life order has also come under fire from big electronic trading firms such as Citadel Securities LLC, which said the rejiggering of the exchange's standard queue priority model was unfairly discriminatory to market makers.
According to Nasdaq, the idea is to give retail investors a better chance of getting trades done at a favorable price. The problem for slower-moving investors is that their orders can get stuck in the back of long queues before being executed, and ultrafast electronic trading firms ahead of them in the queues will quickly cancel their orders if they believe the price of a stock is about to move against them.
So by the time the slower investor's order gets executed, the price of the stock is often about to drop, if they have placed a buy order, or rise, if they were trying to sell--the opposite of what the investor would want.
According to IEX, the problem is that the proposal envisions a special flag identifying extended-life orders that would be visible in a detailed market-data feed that Nasdaq sells to its biggest customers.
The presence of that flag would help sophisticated trading firms figure out which orders were coming from retail investors or from big institutional investors, according to IEX.
A Nasdaq spokesman said the company would respond to IEX's criticism through the SEC's comment process.
Foreign Investors Spurn China's Markets
By Shen Hong, Anjie Zheng and Rachel Rosenthal
SHANGHAI--China is opening its financial markets more than ever to global investors, hoping the charm offensive will attract more money just as it struggles to stem heavy capital withdrawals.
The expected gusher of funds hasn't materialized.
In just over 12 months, China has opened its $9 trillion bond market to overseas investors and launched a trading link between the Shenzhen and Hong Kong stock markets that allows foreigners to trade the shares of some of the country's fastest-expanding companies. This week, Chinese regulators allowed overseas investors in its bond market to buy financial products traded domestically that will let them hedge currency risks.
But while foreigners may have long sought to invest in stocks and bonds in China, where annual economic growth is near 7%, as the last great frontier in global markets, they have so far been hesitant.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 325 of 1177

Overseas investors' Chinese bondholdings dropped to 1.3% of the total outstanding by the end of last year, a fall from 1.4% before the market's broad opening in February 2016. Money flowing into Shenzhen stocks from Hong Kong has been tepid, averaging just 5% of the daily 13 billion yuan ($1.89 billion) quota allowed in February. The trend is similar for a trading link between Shanghai and Hong Kong set up in 2014.
Investors cite several worries, including time-consuming registration processes and confusion over the tax rules on capital gains. Some said markets in China are too expensive. Shares on Shenzhen's small-cap ChiNext board trade at 71 times earnings. The yuan's slide in the past year has put off many, even though the slump has paused recently.
Others refer to regular state interventions in markets, such as the heavy share-buying by government-backed funds whenever Chinese stocks dip. Another worry: whether, given China's tight capital controls, investors will be able to get their money out of China as readily as it is being welcomed in.
"There's a risk that at any point the authorities can step in. That risk must be compensated for foreign investors, for example, by a cheaper market," said Lukas Daalder, chief investment officer at Robeco Investment Solutions in Rotterdam, the Netherlands.
For China, where monthly capital withdrawals are roughly $30 billion to $60 billion, according to Goldman Sachs Group Inc. analysts, there is a big potential prize from further opening up its markets.
Stock-index provider MSCI Inc. has kept mainland-listed Chinese stocks out of its key indexes, citing concerns such as restrictions on capital withdrawals. Some $500 billion could in time pour into Chinese shares, about 10% of the market's total value, if they were included in the MSCI Emerging Markets Index, HSBC Holdings PLC analysts estimated last summer.
Chinese bonds, meanwhile, aren't included in major bond indexes run by banks like J.P. Morgan Chase &Co. and Citigroup Inc. that are commonly tracked by global fund managers, partly because of concerns about issues like market regulation and capital controls. Goldman reckons some $250 billion could eventually flow into Chinese debt markets if the bonds were admitted.
Some investors who have been eager to jump into China said regulators' latest move to give them more ability to hedge risks resolved a big hang-up.
"Now we are ready, we are finalizing" plans to invest in the onshore market, said Jean-Charles Sambor, deputy head of emerging-market fixed income at BNP Paribas Investment Partners in London, which manages [euro]560 billion ($591 billion). "Regulatory issues are gradually being clarified; we are much more comfortable."
Still, few foreign asset managers have created funds dedicated to China's onshore bond market, said Chantal Grinderslev, senior adviser at Z-Ben Advisors, a Shanghai-based strategic consultant, given a lack of demand from investors. Exceptions include U.S.-based hedge fund Bridgewater Associates LP, which has registered seven products to invest in Chinese bonds. A Bridgewater spokesman said the fund is "looking forward to investing in China and are moving forward to do that.".
"No one wants to be at a cocktail party saying they don't have a China strategy," said Ms. Grinderslev. "But for the majority of firms, it's more lip service than action."
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 326 of 1177

U.K.-based Standard Life Investments is typical of major investment funds keeping their China powder dry. A big turnoff is Chinese regulators' lack of transparency, said Mark Baker, an emerging-market portfolio manager at the firm in Hong Kong, adding that currently unfavorable market conditions--from rising inflation, which hurts bondholders by eating away at the value of future payments, to a weakening currency--have taken away any urgency to invest in China.
"It doesn't really feel like a slam-dunk trade at the moment," said Mr. Baker. "We're just not there banging the table asking for access on the basis of the investment opportunity alone."
Wayne Bowers, executive vice president of Northern Trust Asset Management, which manages $942 billion, said another concern is the absence of a level playing field between domestic and foreign firms in the country.
"One of the questions we ask on a regular basis is how I am going to be treated both in terms of liquidity, withholding tax and underlying regulatory oversight," said Mr. Bowers.
WSJ Pro: Market Talk: Daily Analysis Roundup CFPB's Cordray: Judge Gorsuch 'Very Very Capable'
Neil Gorsuch and Richard Cordray may sit on the opposite ends of the ideological spectrum for top legal officials on the government payroll. But the conservative Supreme Court nominee and the Democratic head of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau have a strong common element: As young lawyers, they clerked for the same two Supreme Court justices: Byron White and Anthony Kennedy. So when Cordray was asked to comment on Gorsuch, he offered a generous praise. "I think he is a conscientious, very very capable judge," Cordray said in an interview with CNBC. "Justice White and Justice Kennedy taught me a lot of lessons that I think I carried into my approach to enforcing the law and respecting the law to this day and I am sure at Judge Gorsuch does as well." (yuka.hayashi@wsj.com; @tokyowoods)
Insider Case Against Gambler Walters Will Proceed
A federal judge on Wednesday declined to dismiss the insider-trading case against legendary gambler William "Billy" Walters, rejecting the defense's argument that government leaks about the investigation to the press had unfairly influenced the grand jury. In a 20-page ruling, US District judge said Walters failed to show that he was harmed by any leaks. Lawyers for Walters had moved to dismiss the case in January, after federal prosecutors in Manhattan wrote in court papers that a FBI agent had admitted to sharing secret information about the insider- trading probe with journalists from The Wall Street Journal and the New York Times. (nicole.hong@wsj.com)
China Drags Feet on Consolidating Financial Regulation
China's top leadership is dragging its feet on consolidating financial regulation, as other countries have done in times of heightened risk. Top banking regulator, Guo Shuqing, said that plans to form a "super-regulator" were just rumors, at a press conference Thursday morning in Beijing. Some analysts are expecting a merger between China's banking and insurance regulator that would give more power to Guo, who was appointed to his position as chairman of the China Banking Regulatory Commission just last week. China's central bank has stepped up efforts to streamline regulation of wealth management products, which have been a headache for authorities as issuers and sellers dodge regulatory loopholes. WMPs totaled 29.1 trillion yuan by the end of 2016, up 23.8% from the
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 327 of 1177

previous year. They have become problematic because banks have been hiding them off-balance sheet. Their underlying investments are often unclear. The PBOC move has fueled speculation of further collaboration between China's financial regulators, with the central bank leading the way. (chao.deng@wsj.com)
DOJ Subpoena Adds to MDC's Woes
MDC Partners (MDCA) says in a filing one of its agencies has been subpoenaed by the Justice Department, as the government investigates whether ad agencies have manipulated contract pricing to steer production of commercials to their in-house units. The news comes just weeks after the embattled ad firm agreed to pay $1.5M to settle SEC allegations it misused non-GAAP financial measures and didn't fully disclose the perks provided to its former CEO. MDC didn't admit or deny the SEC findings.(suzanne.vranica@wsj.com; @VranicaWSJ)
MetLife, Awaiting SIFI Verdict, Sends GOP Study to Judges
MetLife (MET) is still awaiting the verdict of a federal appeals court on litigation over whether it should be labeled a "systemically important financial institution" subject to stricter US oversight. But it isn't staying quiet. The company's lawyer sends a letter to appellate judges alerting them to a recent study by House Republicans he believes supports the company's case. A ruling could come any day, as could action by the Trump administration to withdraw the government's appeal. (ryan.tracy@wsj.com; @ryanjtracy)

Crowdfunding Gets Off to a Slow Start, SEC Data Shows
Equity crowdfunding, a new way of raising small amounts of capital that was authorized by Congress in 2012, is off and running. But judging from how much it has raised so far, crowdfunding isn't going to revolutionize the capital markets anytime soon.
The Securities and Exchange Commission published research Tuesday showing that companies raised about $8.1 million using equity crowdfunding last year. That figure was spread over about 28 deals, meaning the average successful raise was about $290,000. More than 130 offerings didn't report raising any money at all, according to the SEC's figures.

The methodology international regulators use to measure capital held by systemically important financial institutions has "several shortcomings," according to research by Sylvain Benoit,Christophe Hurlin and Christophe Perignon for HEC Paris, a French business school. Using regulatory data for 119 U.S. and international banks, the researchers find that "the current scoring methodology severely distorts the allocation of regulatory capital among banks" and say that the current scores are driven too much by factors that are exogenous to the banks, like exchange rates or the actions of other banks. They propose their own methodology "that corrects for these shortcomings."
Repealing Durbin Amendment Would Be 'Massive Wall Street Giveaway'
Sen. Dick Durbin (D., Ill.) and Rep. Peter Welch (D., Vt.) argued against repealing a cap on debit-card swipe fees, known as the Durbin amendment, in an opinion column published by the Hill . They argue that repealing the cap, which cut in half the fees that banks receive when debit cards are used at a point of sale, would be a "gut punch to Main Street merchants who are already paying $18 billion per year in debit swipe fees." They warn that repealing the Durbin amendment would be a windfall for big banks at the expense of merchants and consumers.

Title: Inflation Is Back, But Where It Goes from Here Depends on the Region; A major factor in higher global prices has been oil, but that effect is likely to abate by second quarter
ARTICLE:
Inflation is back around the globe--even in Japan, the poster-child of an economy long beset by falling prices. The big question now is whether it will stick around.
A major factor in higher global prices so far has been oil, which hit a 13-year low in January 2016 and has nearly doubled since. When that is fed into annual inflation rate data, it helps drive up the year-over-year comparisons.
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 331 of 1177
But that effect is likely to start to abate by the second quarter, absent another run-up in oil prices this year. At that point, global inflation trends could start to diverge.
In developed markets like the U.S., Europe and Japan, the impact of tightening labor markets will step in to pick up where oil has left off, economists say. In emerging markets, though, inflation may moderate as a result of weak underlying economic growth.
That could lead to differing policy paths for global central banks, "with less accommodation or even outright tightening needed in developed markets but continued accommodation, if not outright easing, needed to cushion growth in emerging markets" said Frederic Neumann, co-head of Asia economic research at HSBC Holdings PLC in Hong Kong.
On Friday, Japan reported that core consumer prices, which exclude fresh food but include energy, rose for the first time in more than a year in January, up 0.1% from a year earlier. Petroleum inflation accelerated 9.2% from a year earlier, compared with 0.5% in December, according to Capital Economics.
Eurozone consumer prices rose 2% in February, the highest annual rate of inflation since January 2013, largely due to a 9.2% increase in energy costs, according to Eurostat. In the U.S., a 10.8% rise in energy costs drove annual inflation to 2.5% in January, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The trend marks a turnaround from a year ago, when the word "deflation" was closer to economists' lips. The specter of falling prices pushed Japan's central bank into new policy experiments, from setting negative interest rates to setting a target rate for 10-year government bonds.
The European Central Bank started buying corporate bonds in June, and the U.S. Federal Reserve kept interest rates on hold throughout last year.
In Japan, policy makers are growing confident that the inflation rate will accelerate to more than 1% within a year or so--even as oil prices stabilize--as the country rides the tailwinds of stronger U.S. economy and a weaker yen, according to people close to the central bank. A lower yen would drive up import prices, underpinning higher inflation.
Historically, it has taken nine months for currency weakness to show up in inflation readings, said Shuichi Ohsaki, Japan rates strategist at Bank of America Merrill Lynch in Tokyo. He expects the impact of the weakening yen to kick in by April. The yen was last at 114.25 per U.S. dollar.
Bank of Japan officials are also gaining confidence that wages will rise this year. While companies remain cautious about giving base-wage increases to full-time workers, they are seen as more willing to raise their bonuses while increasing hourly wages for part-time or temporary workers, who are in short supply.
In a speech last month, BOJ Deputy Gov. Hiroshi Nakaso pointed to tightening labor market conditions as evidence of Japan's improving "output gap," which measures the difference between an economy's actual and potential output.
This week, the U.S. reported that the number of Americans applying for unemployment benefits fell to the lowest level in nearly half a century. While unemployment is still high in Europe, the figure fell to a seven-year low of 9.6% in December and held steady in January, the latest data available.
Tightening labor markets could lead to "second-round effects," as workers with higher wages spend more and businesses raise prices to cover their costs, giving inflation an extra boost, said HSBC's Mr. Neumann.
In Asia's emerging markets, there are few price pressures beyond fuel. Food prices, which tend to make up a larger share of inflation baskets than energy, have been stable. Moreover, "relatively subdued economic growth will also help keep inflation in check," wrote Capital Economics in a note.
"At this stage, even though we expect growth in Asia to pick up from last year, we don't think the pace is strong enough to create genuine inflation pressures," said Khoon Goh, head of Asia research at ANZ Bank in Singapore.
In China, where the consumer-price index rose 2.5% in January from a year earlier--the fastest pace in more than 21?2 years--many economists believe that inflation will moderate this year as the effects of government stimulus fades and Beijing turns its attention to tamping down potential asset bubbles.
Lucy Craymer and Liyan Qi contributed to this article.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 332 of 1177

Title: Deutsche Bank: Big Capital Call Offers Little Long-Term Reward; The German lender is seeking stability but investors will likely be underwhelmed
ARTICLE:
Deutsche Bank wants another [euro]8 billion ($8.5 billion) from long-suffering investors. The big concern will be that they are throwing more good money after bad since they put in the same amount in 2014.
The bank is promising yet another strategy rethink, reversing several plans put in place in 2015. And while there is the promise of quick, if small, dividends, the headline target of a 10% return on tangible equity in some undated future is underwhelming.
The capital raise has long been expected , but it is coming now with another new strategy. Two big things have happened: Its capital needs have become more clear, and it suffered a
shock loss of revenues last year due to fears over its stability.
On capital, the bank has been waiting with more concern than most for the outcome of global rule changes that threaten to significantly raise its requirements.
These changes are still not fully agreed upon months after they should have been, but one thing is clear: Banks won't have to start implementing them for five years and will have a further five years to meet them. That gives Deutsche Bank a lot of time to adjust whatever the outcome.
Deutsche Bank also has settled most of the costliest regulatory fines that were long hanging over it. But fear over its ability to pay a $14 billion mortgage-related fine initially demanded by the Justice Department was the spark for revenue shock in the final quarter of 2016.
As the bank's shares fell and the cost of insuring its debt against default shot up, it became more expensive for clients to trade with Deutsche Bank. Many took their business elsewhere.
Deutsche Bank's revenues dropped by [euro]3.5 billion last year in a shrinking investment banking market and about [euro]1 billion of that was down to the riskiness of the bank itself rather than simple activity trends.
So Deutsche Bank is seeking more stability. It will now keep Postbank, the domestic retail business it said it would sell at its last strategy plan in October 2015. It will also recombine its global markets business with its investment bank, having only separated them in 2015, and make it more focused on more stable corporate clients.
It also wants to lower the cost for its clients of dealing with Deutsche Bank as a counterparty, for example in derivative contracts. To do that it is bolstering its balance sheet by lifting its target capital ratio above 13% from 12.5% now, which it hasn't yet met and always looked too low. The rights issue should lift it to 14%.
The future Deutsche Bank now looks more like HSBC than Credit Suisse or Goldman Sachs. However much sense that might make, its past strategic missteps and reversals will mean yet another capital raise will be met grudgingly at best.
Get financial insights and commentary on global investing from The Wall Street Journal's Heard on the Street team. Subscribe to the podcast.
Credit: By Paul J. Davies

Title: Why Industry Is Happy About Coming ETF Rules | New Class of Mutual Fund Shares in Limbo | Deutsche Bank to Tap Market | SEC Pick Clears Ethics Hurdle | Ackerman's Take: Prospects for SEC Paralysis--Jay Clayton Edition; The Wall Street Journal's financial regulation newsletter for Monday, March 6, 2017.
ARTICLE:
Ackerman's Take: Prospects for SEC Paralysis--Jay Clayton Edition
Here Come ETF Regulations (and Why the Industry Is Happy About It) New Class of Mutual Fund Shares in Limbo as 'Fiduciary' Rule Is Delayed Chinese Lawmaker Calls for Strong Stock-Market Regulation
Deutsche Bank to Tap Market for $8.5 Billion
Prospects for SEC Paralysis--Jay Clayton Edition
   PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM
Page 339 of 1177
As Securities and Exchange Commission chief, Mary Jo White struggled to advance her agenda through the often- fractious commission , due in part to the agency's depleted ranks last year. Notably, the agency's quorum requirements handed Michael Piwowar, the agency's sole Republican, a veto over action he didn't support.
A similar dynamic is shaping up to potentially stymie Jay Clayton, President Donald Trump's pick to head the SEC, albeit in reverse, politically speaking: Kara Stein, the SEC's sole Democrat, will have a veto over Mr. Clayton's agenda.
That's because once Mr. Clayton joins the commission, the agency will be operating with just three members--two fewer than its full complement. The SEC's quorum rules require all three members to be present for the agency to pass a regulation, bring a civil lawsuit or take virtually any other action not delegated to staff.
By simply refusing to show up to a vote, a dissenting Ms. Stein would be able to block the agency from acting altogether.
For Mr. Clayton, this means trouble for his agenda, which is expected to focus on easing what he sees as unnecessary regulations on raising capital. It's unlikely Ms. Stein, an outspoken supporter of tough postcrisis regulation, would support a deregulatory approach.
(The nomination of Mr. Clayton, a political independent, is pending before the Senate Banking Committee, which has yet to schedule a nominations hearing.)
To be sure, the SEC gridlock theoretically lasts only until the Trump administration has time to nominate, and the Senate confirms, individuals to fill the two other vacancies at the agency. It's unclear how long that will take, but the Trump administration is generally behind the ball in filling key regulatory positions compared to its immediate predecessors. That means it could take many months before the SEC is operating at full strength.
The two commissioner vacancies in question have long gone unfilled in part because Senate Democrats couldn't agree in 2015 on who should fill one of the seats, which formerly belonged to Luis Aguilar. The Obama White House's preferred successor, a well-known corporate attorney, was shot down by Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D., Mass.) and her allies before he could be nominated.
The Obama administration's eventual selection, law professor Lisa Fairfax , had only limited support among Senate Democrats and failed to advance through the chamber in the last Congress. Ms. Fairfax's nomination died along with that of Hester Peirce, a Republican tapped for the second vacancy (to succeed ex-commissioner Daniel Gallagher).
Mr. Trump now has an opportunity to renominate Ms. Peirce, though it is unclear if he will do so. It's also unclear whom the White House will tap to fill Mr. Aguilar's slot, though Mr. Trump could elect to nominate a second Republican or independent to fill Mr. Aguilar's old seat, WSJ Pro Financial Regulation reported last week .
Key Developments in Washington, on Wall Street, and Beyond
Here Come ETF Regulations (and Why the Industry Is Happy About It)
Fund companies are about to go on the regulatory offensive in Washington. And their chances for success are
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 340 of 1177

looking pretty good. For the past five years, it has been a totally different game plan, with asset managers playing defense against the federal government, scrambling to deflect a barrage of new regulations and letting a few get into the goal.
But with Republicans now controlling the White House, Congress and the regulatory agencies, sponsors of mutual funds and exchange-traded funds are gearing up to fight for new regulations of their own--regulations, they say, that would promote growth and innovation. And they expect the next leader of the Securities and Exchange Commission, breaking from Obama-era worries that funds could be a source of systemic financial risk, to favor these measures.
Small Investors Run to ETFs
New Class of Mutual Fund Shares in Limbo as 'Fiduciary' Rule Is Delayed
The delay of a rule that tightens standards on brokerages' retirement-savings advice is disrupting efforts to roll out a new class of mutual-fund shares designed to comply with the regulation.
Work to create these transaction or "T" shares has been delayed or suspended while the Labor Department reviews the rule for repeal or revision, according to some brokerage firms familiar with fund managers' efforts surrounding the shares. The new fund shares would feature uniform sales charges across all fund categories to help eliminate any pay incentive that might cause a broker to recommend a higher-cost fund over a less-expensive similar option in potential violation of the Labor Department's "fiduciary" rule.
WSJ Pro: Chinese Lawmaker Calls for Strong Stock-Market Regulation
A senior Chinese lawmaker called for more robust regulation of China's stock market, starting with raising the quality of listed firms.
"Supervision should be very powerful," said Wu Xiaoling, deputy director of the Chinese legislature's finance and economics committee, on the sidelines of a conference in Beijing Monday. "The most important step in reforming China's capital markets is the completion of a fundamental infrastructure."
Deutsche Bank to Tap Market for $8.5 Billion
Deutsche Bank AG said Sunday it will seek to raise [euro]8 billion ($8.5 billion) through a share sale, a move aimed at shoring up the German lender's capital less than two years into a major restructuring under Chief Executive John Cryan.
The bank is also reorganizing major businesses for the second time in 18 months, in two cases reversing high- profile strategic decisions from 2015. It is keeping the Postbank retail-banking business in Germany it had sought for two years to sell. And it is recombining its corporate-finance and deal-advisory business with its sprawling trading unit, following a costly move to split them in late 2015.
Trump's Pick for SEC Chairman Clears Ethics Hurdle
The federal agency charged with reviewing U.S. officials' conflicts of interest has cleared financial disclosures filed by Jay Clayton, President Donald Trump's pick to run the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to people familiar with the matter.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 341 of 1177

The move by the U.S. Office of Government Ethics on Friday clears a path for the Senate Banking Committee to schedule a nomination hearing for Mr. Clayton, who is a partner at the law firm Sullivan &Cromwell LLP.
China Shifts Stance, Letting Dying Firms Go Bankrupt
Bankruptcies of Chinese businesses have surged in the past two years, in a sign the state is beginning to take painful steps to trim the bloated industrial sector as it tries to rein in debt.
Banking regulator Guo Shuqing signaled Thursday that debt management is high on the NPC agenda. "The government must grab the bull by the nose in disposing of zombie companies," he said, using a Chinese expression to refer to firms kept alive only with state aid.
Analysis: China's Gradualist Reform Approach Reaching Bitter End
For Alexandra Lebenthal, Sale of Family Business Marks End of Difficult Chapter for a Storied Name
Wall Street icon Alexandra Lebenthal is nearing a deal to sell her eponymous financial-services firm as it contends with unpaid bills and lawsuits, a denouement that comes just a decade after the prominent New Yorker resurrected the storied family business.
Lebenthal Holdings LLC is getting a new chapter as Ms. Lebenthal; her brother, James; and their company face allegations that they owe debts totaling millions of dollars, hurt in part by poor timing and missteps in a short-lived wealth-management business. Ms. Lebenthal, 52 years old, said that she hopes soon to resolve outstanding obligations.
WSJ Pro: Market Talk: Daily Analysis Roundup
Read our compilation of concise , timely analysis by Wall Street Journal reporters. U.S. Lawmakers Begin Debate on National Flood Insurance; China Securities Law Changes Likely to Focus on Greater Enforcement Power; OECD Right to Highlight Aussie Housing Risks, Says AMP.
Jacob Schlesinger and the reporters and editors of WSJ Pro Financial Regulation welcome your questions. Send an email to AskFinReg@wsj.com.
The Big Losers From Investment Banking's Shrinking Pie
The European investment banks that were biggest in the past are still struggling most with profitability. It is the second-tier investment banks that are reporting better returns, according to Goldman Sachs analysts: BNP Paribas, HSBC and Socie?te? Ge?ne?rale. One big reason: they are paying out less in penalties for past wrongdoing.
In revenue terms, the picture is more mixed, but one thing is clear: almost all the Europeans are finding it tough to attract business while being stingier with their capital, or taking less risk.
Monday, March 6 8:30 a.m.

Lendit hosts a conference on the future of financial technology in New York with remarks from CFPB Director Richard Cordray.
3:00 p.m.
Minneapolis Fed President Neel Kashkari takes part in a discussion on too-big-to-fail banks at a National Association for Business Economics conference in Washington.

Federal officials, including acting Assistant Attorney General Kenneth Blanco gather in Miami for the American Bar Association White Collar Crime conference
Thursday, March 9 9:00 a.m.
SEC investor advisory committee holds a public meeting 10:00 a.m.
The House Financial Services Committee holds its first meeting of this congress on flood insurance Risk Management in a Volatile Macroeconomic Environment
Risk management programs "may need to increase their ability to anticipate and respond flexibly to new regulatory and business developments and to emerging risks," in the wake of the massive geopolitical changes in the U.S. and European Union, according to Deloitte's annual Global Risk Management Survey . Brexit and the election of Donald Trump have introduced new regulatory and economic uncertainty, the survey finds. Large-scale changes to international trade and regulatory agreements make the "external micro and macroeconomic environment...more volatile." Within this climate, firms are concerned about cybersecurity and managing large amounts of data, as well as the increased importance and cost of compliance, the survey finds.
How Will the U.S. Engage With International Regulatory Bodies?
The Trump administration's antipathy toward international organizations may jeopardize future efforts by regulatory bodies such as the Basel Committee and the Financial Stability Board, writes former United Kingdom Financial Services Authority chairman Howard Davies for Project-Syndicate . In particular, the pending retirement of Federal Reserve regulatory czar Daniel Tarullo, who took an active role in international regulatory bodies, will change how the U.S. engages in such forums. Congressional Republicans, including House Financial Services Committee Vice Chairman Patrick McHenry, have called on the Fed to leave negotiations on international regulatory standards. As a result, "financial regulation has entered a period of high uncertainty," Mr. Davies writes.
A new rule that went into effect at the end of January requires the naming of accounting-firm partners who head the audits of U.S. public companies. Under the move, which had long been in the works, investors can go online and find out with a few keystrokes the person who leads any company's audit.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 343 of 1177

The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission said Friday that embattled Mexican home-building company Desarrolladora Homex SAB has agreed to settle charges that it reported $3.3. billion in fraudulent sales revenue.
Trouble spots linger in global financial markets despite a period of relative calm as tensions emerged in China and other developing economies, according to the Bank for International Settlements' latest quarterly review released Monday.
Aberdeen Asset Management PLC and Standard Life PLC on Monday said they have agreed to the terms of an all- share merger, creating one of the U.K.'s largest asset managers with a combined market value of more than £11 billion ($13.5 billion).
Few in finance have cheered Europe's negative interest rates, especially in Germany. But Deutsche Bank's ultra-low rates have done it a favor.
No stranger to big bets , hedge-fund founder Nader Tavakoli is making perhaps his boldest bet yet--that he can win a $3 billion malpractice suit against a Big Four accounting firm.

Title: NYPD Gets $20.4 Million in Asset-Forfeiture Funds; Most of the funding to support officers in Queens in neighborhood policing initiative
ARTICLE:
The New York Police Department received more than $20 million in asset-forfeiture funds from the Queens District Attorney's office on Monday to equip officers with new vehicles, tools and training equipment.
Most of the $20.4 million will support officers in Queens, including more than $11 million to finance 264 vehicles
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 345 of 1177
for Police Commissioner James O'Neill's neighborhood policing initiative in the borough.
The funding will also provide tablets for police recruits so they can access training material, technology for first responders tasked with treating cardiac arrest and 19,000 gun holsters with an automatic locking system. Officers in Queens will also receive new flashlights. Currently, new recruits must buy their own flashlights after graduation.
"All of this is done with the goal of pushing crime down even further and keeping our public--and our cops--safe at all times," Mr. O'Neill said.
The funding comes from a deferred prosecution agreement in 2012, in which U.K. banking company HSBC Holdings PLC and its affiliated branches forfeited $1.26 billion to the U.S. Department of Justice. The company illegally made transactions for customers in countries that were sanctioned by the government. The U.S. unit, HSBC Bank U.S.A. NA, failed to maintain an effective antimoney laundering program, officials said.
The Queens District Attorney's Office received $116 million from the Department of Treasury for its role in investigating the case.
The more than $20 million transferred to the NYPD can't be used to supplant the police department's existing budget as a result of federal guidelines, according to District Attorney Robert. A. Brown, but rather fund new law- enforcement initiatives.
Mr. Brown said he wanted the funding to strengthen the neighborhood policing model, in which some officers spend about one-third of their day establishing community relationships and addressing low-level offenses as opposed to responding to emergency calls. The initiative is still being rolled out across the city.
"These initiatives are extremely important," Mr. Brown said. "And will help enhance overall policing strategies and police-community relations while optimizing officer and public safety."
Write to Zolan Kanno-Youngs at Zolan.Kanno-Youngs@wsj.com
Credit: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs

Title: China Foreign-Exchange Reserves Vault Back Above $3 Trillion; PBOC says forex reserves rose by $6.92 billion in February from a month ago, beating economists' forecast of a $28 billion drop
ARTICLE:
BEIJING--China's foreign-exchange reserves rose last month for the first time in eight months due to Beijing's concerted effort to stanch capital outflows as well as valuation changes in the stockpile's assets.
The reserves--the world's largest--increased by $6.92 billion in February to $3.005 trillion, following a drop of $12.31 billion in January, according to data released by the People's Bank of China on Tuesday. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal had expected a $28 billion decrease in February.
The gain lifted the reserves back above the $3 trillion mark, after their fall below that level in January. Economists
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 349 of 1177
attributed the increase to the government's broad-ranging measures to stem the flow of money moving offshore, prop up a yuan weakening against the U.S. dollar and bolster sagging confidence in the economy.
"All outflow channels have been basically closed, so it is not too shocking to me," said HSBC economist Ma Xiaoping.
Chinese authorities have stepped up scrutiny of foreign-exchange activities by companies and households. The measures include controls on Chinese companies seeking to invest overseas, restrictions on converting the yuan into foreign currencies and a crackdown on underground banks often used to evade controls to move money offshore.
Also helping the February reserves tally, some assets in the portfolio gained in value, offsetting the depreciation of other major currencies against the U.S. dollar, China's State Administration of Foreign Exchange said in a statement after the data release.
The weakening of the euro and pound against the U.S. dollar last month likely resulted in a negative valuation effect on China's reserves, but February's rebound in major government-bond prices also likely yielded a sizable valuation gain, said economists at UBS Securities Asia. They estimated February's total valuation gain at about $5 billion.
Beijing kept the yuan steady against the U.S. dollar in February, when the yuan rose about 0.1%. UBS economists said that likely helped to ease pressures to send money offshore.
Outflow pressures may pick up soon, as the Federal Reserve is set to raise interest rates either in March or June, said HSBC's Ms. Ma. Beijing will unlikely follow the Fed's footsteps to raise benchmark rates, as it still needs to stabilize domestic economic growth, she said.
"Stability is clearly a message policy makers want to send now," she said.
Economists have said that authorities are focused on stabilizing economic growth and the yuan exchange rate to ensure a smooth transition ahead of a Communist Party leadership shuffle later this year.

Title: Why Central Banks Are Stockpiling Foreign Reserves; 'External reserves are a form of insurance for sovereigns against crisis and defaults,' says an analyst
ARTICLE:
Central banks around the world are loading up on foreign-currency reserves, highlighting the fragile underpinnings of the global economic recovery despite a more buoyant mood in financial markets.
In emerging economies, reserve levels have stabilized after two years of big declines. Two-thirds of the 30 biggest emerging markets grew their reserves last year, and foreign-currency holdings in Israel, Vietnam and the Czech Republic recently reached all-time highs.
China's foreign reserves also rose by $6.9 billion in February compared with the previous month, rebounding for the first in eight months. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal had expected a $28 billion drop but the gains pushed China's reserve total back above the $3 trillion mark.
Rising reserve balances are often a reassuring sign for investors, because they show individual nations have the capacity to deal with market shocks or economic downturns that hit their currencies. Foreign reserves, which are used to pay for imports and service foreign-currency debt, are especially important for fast-growing but volatile emerging markets.
"External reserves are a form of insurance for sovereigns against crisis and defaults," said Chia-Liang Lian, head of emerging-market debt at Western Asset Management.
Even some central banks in Europe, where big spikes in reserves are usually associated with periods of intense global stress, have been padding their coffers . Switzerland's holdings of foreign assets jumped last month at their fastest pace in more than two years, while Denmark has also stepped up its foreign-currency purchases.
But many investors and analysts worry that underlying the reserve buildup are global trade and capital imbalances that could make the world vulnerable to a fresh crisis should they be disrupted by political or economic unrest. Another period of U.S. dollar strength, which some analysts are predicting if the Federal Reserve keeps pushing interest rates higher, is one potential shock. During the global market selloff early last year, a strong dollar and rising dollar-denominated debt levels in the developing world prompted a rout in emerging-market assets.
The rising reserve totals also suggest that bank officials are accumulating dollars because they have concerns about the global economy, despite a bullish investor mood that has lifted the Dow Jones Industrial Average to record highs this year as it soared above 21000 .
The pace of economic growth is picking up in the U.S. and Europe, and analysts say that if President Donald Trump pushes through his corporate tax overhaul and deregulation plan the U.S. economy could expand faster.
The increase in emerging-market reserves reflects in part a rally in commodities prices , which rose about 28% last year and comprise a big part of the developing world's exports. Capital inflows, which in emerging markets excluding China were up nearly 60% last year to $192 billion, have also bolstered reserve levels for these countries. Reserve levels for emerging markets peaked at $8 trillion in 2014, according to the International Monetary Fund. Then they fell sharply after central banks churned through about $1 trillion of reserves to support faltering currencies.
But that cash drain stopped last year. Excluding China's holdings, reserves in the 30 biggest emerging markets held steady at $3.9 trillion in 2016, Fitch Ratings estimated.
The overall figure obscures the fact that two-thirds of the countries grew their reserves last year. The broad number was unchanged largely because several governments in the Middle East dipped into foreign-currency holdings to meet budget needs during the oil-price rout.
China had been another major exception before reserves grew again last month. Economists attributed the increase to the government's broad-ranging measures to stem the flow of money moving offshore, prop up a yuan weakening against the U.S. dollar and bolster sagging confidence in the economy.
"All outflow channels have been basically closed, so it is not too shocking to me," said HSBC economist Ma Xiaoping.
In much of the rest of the developing world, reserves were already on the rise. They grew substantially in Egypt, Nigeria and Thailand in recent months. In January, Russia added $13 billion to its $390.6 billion in reserves, its largest monthly increase in more than four years.
Many central banks also accumulate foreign reserves when they purchase assets denominated in other currencies,
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 352 of 1177
using freshly created money. They do this to weaken their currencies, protecting exports and giving a boost to inflation. The Czech central bank intervened in January on a massive scale to maintain its currency target against the euro.
The Swiss National Bank said Tuesday its foreign-exchange reserves swelled nearly 25 billion Swiss francs ($24.63 billion) last month to 668 billion francs, the biggest rise since December 2014, the month before the Swiss abandoned a cap on the franc's value. The pile of foreign reserves is greater than Switzerland's entire gross domestic product.
The franc is regarded as one of the world's safest currencies given Switzerland's stable economy and low debt, meaning its value usually increases when investors seek safety instead of returns.
Analysts cited elections in France this spring, in Germany this fall and continued political uncertainty in Italy, the U.S. and U.K. as reasons for the relentless demand for the franc and other safe-haven currencies.
"Such phases of increased political uncertainty are problematic for us because the Swiss franc is considered a safe haven," Swiss Central Bank Chairman Thomas Jordan said in a Swiss newspaper interview on March 4. Liyan Qi and Grace Zhu contributed to this article.
Write to Carolyn Cui at carolyn.cui@wsj.com and Brian Blackstone at brian.blackstone@wsj.com

Title: Central Banks Ratchet Up Foreign-Currency Reserves; 'External reserves are a form of insurance for sovereigns against crisis and defaults,' says an analyst
ARTICLE:
Corrections &Amplifications The change in Israel's foreign-currency reserves is shown with a blue line in a chart accompanying this article. An earlier version of the chart incorrectly labeled Israel's data as light green in the legend. (March 15, 2017)
Central banks around the world are increasing foreign-currency reserves, highlighting the fragile underpinnings of the global economic recovery despite a bullish mood in financial markets.
In emerging economies, reserve levels have stabilized after two years of big declines. Two-thirds of the 30 biggest emerging markets increased reserves last year, according to Fitch Ratings. Foreign-currency holdings in Israel, Vietnam and the Czech Republic recently reached new records, their central banks have reported.
China's foreign reserves rose by $6.9 billion in February compared with the previous month, rebounding for the first time in eight months and pushing the reserve total back above the $3 trillion mark.
Some central banks in Europe also have been padding their coffers . Switzerland's holdings of foreign assets jumped last month at their fastest pace in more than two years, while Denmark has also stepped up its foreign- currency purchases.
There are likely several reasons for the concurrent increases.
Reserves rise when central banks buy foreign currencies to keep their own currencies from appreciating too fast, which can hurt their exporters and undermine economic growth.
In Europe, big increases in reserves are often associated with periods of intense global stress. Some analysts suggested that elections this year in France and Germany, as well as political uncertainty in the U.S. and U.K., may be prompting investors to seek safety in currencies like the Swiss franc, putting upward pressure on the currency. That has led the Swiss central bank to buy foreign currencies to keep the franc from strengthening too much. Emerging-market countries also stockpile reserves in an effort to fortify their markets and economies against sudden shocks that could cause foreigners to pull out money.
"External reserves are a form of insurance for sovereigns against crisis and defaults," said Chia-Liang Lian, head of emerging-market debt at Western Asset Management.
Rising reserve balances can be a reassuring sign for investors, because they show individual nations have some capacity to deal with market shocks or economic downturns. The value of many nations' reserves has risen recently as the U.S. dollar has declined.
But many investors and analysts worry that underlying the reserve buildup are global trade and capital imbalances that could make the world vulnerable to a fresh crisis should the flow of capital be disrupted by political or economic unrest.
Another period of U.S. dollar strength, which some analysts are predicting if the Federal Reserve keeps pushing interest rates higher, is one potential shock. During the global market selloff early last year, a strong dollar and rising dollar-denominated debt levels in the developing world prompted a rout in emerging-market assets.
The rising reserve totals also suggest that bank officials are accumulating dollars because they have concerns about the global economy, despite a rally that has lifted the Dow Jones Industrial Average to records this year as it soared above 21000 .
The pace of economic growth is picking up in the U.S. and Europe, and analysts said that if President Donald Trump pushes through his corporate tax overhaul and deregulation plan, the U.S. economy could expand faster. That could lead the Fed to raise interest rates more aggressively, triggering a reversal of capital flows from emerging markets back to the U.S.
The increase in emerging-market reserves reflects in part a rally in commodities prices , which rose about 28% last year, according to the S&P GSCI Index, and comprise a big part of the developing world's exports. Capital inflows, which in emerging markets, excluding China, were up nearly 60% last year to $192 billion, have also bolstered
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 357 of 1177
reserve levels for these countries.
Globally, total reserves rose in last year's third quarter to $11.01 trillion, up from $10.97 trillion a quarter earlier, according to the latest data available from the International Monetary Fund. The level was below the peak of $12 trillion in mid-2014.
Reserve levels for emerging markets peaked at $8 trillion in 2014, according to the IMF. Then they fell sharply after central banks churned through about $1 trillion of reserves to support faltering currencies, a process by which they buy their currency using U.S. dollars or other major currencies.
But that cash drain stopped last year. Excluding China's holdings, reserves in the 30 biggest emerging markets held steady at $3.9 trillion in 2016, Fitch Ratings estimated.
Despite the fact that two-thirds of the countries increased reserves, the broad number was unchanged largely because several governments in the Middle East dipped into foreign-currency holdings to meet budget needs during the oil-price rout.
China had been another major exception before reserves rose again last month. Economists attributed the increase to the government's broad measures to stem the flow of money moving out of the country, prop up a yuan weakening against the U.S. dollar and bolster sagging confidence in the economy.
China's reserves fell by $320 billion last year, according to the Institute of International Finance. Some analysts said the return to reserve growth last month could signal a notable shift after the central bank burned through $1 trillion in foreign currency over the past few years.
"All outflow channels have been basically closed, so it is not too shocking to me," said HSBC Holdings PLC economist Ma Xiaoping.
In much of the rest of the developing world, reserves were already on the rise. They increased substantially in Egypt, Nigeria and Thailand in recent months. In January, Russia added $13 billion to its $390.6 billion in reserves, its largest monthly increase in more than four years.
Many central banks also accumulate foreign reserves when they purchase assets denominated in dollars and other hard currencies. They do this to slow down the appreciation of their currencies, protecting exports and giving a boost to inflation. The Czech central bank intervened in January on a large scale to maintain its currency target against the euro.
The Swiss National Bank said Tuesday that its foreign-exchange reserves swelled nearly 25 billion Swiss francs ($24.7 billion) last month to 668 billion francs, the biggest rise since December 2014, the month before the Swiss abandoned a cap on the franc's value against the euro. The pile of foreign reserves is greater than Switzerland's entire gross domestic product.
The franc is regarded as one of the world's safest currencies given Switzerland's stable economy and low debt, meaning its value usually increases when investors seek safety instead of returns.
Analysts pointed to the elections in France this spring and Germany this fall as reasons for the demand for the franc.
"Such phases of increased political uncertainty are problematic for us because the Swiss franc is considered a safe haven," Swiss Central Bank Chairman Thomas Jordan said in a Swiss newspaper interview on March 4.
Liyan Qi and Grace Zhu contributed to this article.
Write to Carolyn Cui at carolyn.cui@wsj.com and Brian Blackstone at brian.blackstone@wsj.com
