Title: Bharara's Probes Likely to Continue Post-Exit | CFPB, Justice Poised to Square Off in Court | SEC Rejects Winklevosses' Bitcoin Fund | Credit Reports to Exclude Certain Negative Data | Rubin's Take: Crisis Vets Urge GOP to Keep Bank-Resolution Tool; The Wall Street Journal's financial regulation newsletter for Monday, March 13, 2017.
ARTICLE:
Rubin's Take: Crisis Vets Urge GOP to Keep Bank-Resolution Tool Bharara's Probes Likely to Continue After His Exit
CFPB, Justice Department Poised to Square Off in Court
SEC Denies Winklevoss Application for Bitcoin ETF
Italy's Monte dei Paschi to Jettison $30 Billion in Bad Loans in Fire Sale
Crisis Vets Urge GOP to Keep Bank-Resolution Tool
Ben Bernanke, Lawrence Summers and other top crisis-era policy makers have a message for congressional Republicans and the Trump administration: if you don't want bailouts, keep a key provision of Dodd-Frank.
The alumni of the meltdown and its aftermath are urging lawmakers to preserve Title II of the 2010 regulatory- overhaul law. The section lays out orderly liquidation authority, a process that empowers the federal government to take over and wind down a failing financial firm in emergency situations. Trump administration officials, including White House National Economic Council Director Gary Cohn and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, have criticized OLA for failing to preclude the need for bailing out failing banks.
"We are going to probably at some point talk about whether OLA works and whether OLA should ever be triggered, because no one thinks that we really solved 'too big to fail,'" Mr. Cohn said in a Wall Street Journal interview last month.
The GOP is in a rare position of strength given its control of both chambers of Congress and the White House. But without a filibuster-proof majority in the Senate, much of the party's deregulatory wish list will have to go through the budget reconciliation process. That means that in many cases, Republicans will be able to make changes only to regulations that have a budgetary impact, such as OLA (as my colleague Ryan Tracy laid out in detail ).
Messrs. Summers and Bernanke, in essays published in January and February, respectively, argue that gutting OLA would be a terrible mistake.
"This repeal, if enacted, will exacerbate moral hazard, impair financial stability, increase economic vulnerability and in all likelihood increase the national debt," Mr. Summers, who was director of the NEC under President Barack Obama, wrote in the Washington Post .
Mr. Bernanke, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, echoed Mr. Summers's dire language about the importance of OLA.
"It is an essential tool for ensuring that financial stress does not escalate into a catastrophic crisis," Mr. Bernanke wrote in a blog post for the Brookings Institution . He argued that bankruptcy proceedings--as laid out in Title I of Dodd Frank--aren't capable of speedily resolving a firm in turmoil during a "period of high financial stress." He also defended OLA against criticisms that it is a "thinly disguised, taxpayer-funded bailout." As part of OLA, the Federal
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 383 of 1177
Deposit Insurance Corp. is authorized to use Treasury Department funds to provide temporary liquidity to a firm undergoing resolution, but Mr. Bernanke noted that all costs are ultimately borne by private actors like the stakeholders of the failing firm.
As with other aspects of financial deregulation, it remains to be seen whether a repeal of OLA has the support necessary to pass the Senate, even with a simple majority. But the old guard clearly wants to make sure the idea is shelved.
Key Developments in Washington, on Wall Street, and Beyond
Bharara's Probes Likely to Continue After His Exit
By Nicole Hong, Erica Orden and Peter Nicholas
The sudden departure of the top U.S. prosecutor in Manhattan raises uncertainty about the federal government's approach to trying financial crimes and global terrorism cases, even as it isn't likely to change the course of several high-profile investigations.
Preet Bharara was fired as Manhattan U.S. attorney on Saturday, a day after the Justice Department asked the 46 remaining U.S. attorneys appointed by ex-President Barack Obama to step down.
While it isn't unusual for a new administration to fire holdover U.S. attorneys, Mr. Bharara's refusal to resign is extremely rare, and it was surprising given that then-President-elect Donald Trump had invited him to Trump Tower in late November and asked him to stay on as Manhattan U.S. attorney, Mr. Bharara told reporters at the time.
The Manhattan U.S. attorney has wide jurisdiction in prosecuting financial crimes and other white-collar cases, and prosecutors in that office have been particularly aggressive in charging and arresting people outside the U.S. for federal crimes like terrorism, sanctions violations and cybercrime. Mr. Bharara, who has served in the role since 2009, had become prominent with a string of insider-trading and public-corruption investigations.
Mr. Trump had tried to phone Mr. Bharara on Thursday--two days before the firing--to thank him for his service and "to wish him luck," a White House aide said Sunday.
After receiving the message that Mr. Trump was trying to reach him, Mr. Bharara called Joseph "Jody" Hunt, chief of staff to Attorney General Jeff Sessions, to say it was inappropriate for the president to be contacting U.S. attorneys, "particularly ones that have jurisdictions over important matters," according to a person familiar with the call.
Mr. Hunt agreed it was inappropriate, and Mr. Bharara suggested that Mr. Hunt convey that information immediately to Mr. Sessions, the person familiar said. A spokeswoman for the Justice Department declined to comment on the call.
The White House appears to be unhappy with Mr. Bharara's handling of the situation. In reference to Mr. Bharara's ouster, the White House aide said: "The U.S. attorneys are political appointees, and all 46 of the holdovers from the Obama administration received the same resignation letter. It's fair to say that 45 of the 46 behaved in a manner befitting the office."
The aide added: "As much as Preet wants everything to be about Preet, everyone was treated the same way."
Mr. Bharara, in response to the White House's comments, said: "It was my understanding that the president himself has said anonymous sources are not to be believed."
The firings don't force pending investigations across the country to be put on hold, as U.S. attorney's offices have career prosecutors who will fill in until new ones are confirmed. In Manhattan, Mr. Bharara's departure is unlikely to have a significant impact on continuing probes, largely because the interim leader of the office, Joon Kim, is a close friend and longtime colleague of Mr. Bharara's.
Since 2013, Mr. Kim has served in various leadership roles within the Southern District of New York, including most recently as deputy U.S. attorney.
"We anticipate that the work of the office will continue for the foreseeable future with minimal disruptions," said a lawyer within the Manhattan U.S. attorney's office.
Most notably, Mr. Bharara leaves behind his office's yearlong probe into New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio , a Democrat, and his aides in connection with a corruption investigation into the mayor's fundraising operations. That
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 384 of 1177

probe has escalated in recent weeks, with federal prosecutors questioning both the mayor and one of his top aides, according to people familiar with the matter.
The mayor has said he and his allies have done nothing wrong and have followed the law.
It is also unclear whether the office's pursuit of white-collar crime, an enforcement area where the Southern District has been a pioneer since the 1960s, might shift. Mr. Bharara's office secured more than 80 insider-trading convictions in recent years, exposing webs of improper tips and favors that reached across Wall Street to some of the most successful and wealthy hedge-fund managers. Along the way, Mr. Bharara has been criticized for not holding individual executives accountable for actions related to the financial crisis.
Mr. Bharara's departure will be closely watched in financial circles because he oversaw the increased use of wiretaps and confidential informants in white-collar cases--basically treating them no differently than drug cases. This was a successful but controversial approach, and it is unclear whether his successor would employ similar tactics amid pressure by some defense lawyers and others.
Spokespeople for the Justice Department and the White House declined to comment on when Mr. Trump would name a permanent successor to Mr. Bharara.
Messrs. Bharara and Kim both joined the Southern District in 2000, where they sat near each other as entry-level line prosecutors and often went out drinking, according to a person familiar with their relationship. Mr. Bharara was the one who brought Mr. Kim back to government in 2013, after Mr. Kim had spent seven years working at law firm Cleary Gottlieb Steen &Hamilton LLP.
To this day, their families are friends, the person familiar said.
Mr. Kim returned to the office just as Mr. Bharara was preparing to prioritize public-corruption cases, his handling of which has upended politics in Albany and New York City in recent years.
Mr. Kim has been personally involved in those investigations. The office has convicted both one-time state legislative leaders, brought charges against nine people with close ties to New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo and is handling its probe of Mr. de Blasio and his aides.
Last fall, Mr. Kim was present at the questioning by federal prosecutors of Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat, according to a person familiar with the matter, and he also attended the questioning of Mr. de Blasio by assistant U.S. attorneys in recent weeks.
Mr. Cuomo hasn't been charged with wrongdoing. The case against Mr. Cuomo's longtime top aide Joseph Percoco and others close to the governor is expected to go to trial by the end of the year.
Mr. Bharara's firing comes amid a tumultuous start to Mr. Sessions's stint as U.S. attorney general. On March 2, Mr. Sessions said he would recuse himself from any investigations into Russian attempts to interfere in the 2016 presidential elections. He did so after his office said he had met twice with the Russian ambassador to the U.S. during the presidential race, despite testifying at his confirmation hearing in January that he did not have "communications with the Russians."
Beyond the next few months, it remains to be seen how the Southern District's priorities might change under Mr. Sessions and the Trump administration. The Southern District has long had a reputation for operating independently of Washington, which has sometimes been a source of frustration for the Justice Department and for other U.S. attorney's offices, according to former federal prosecutors.
In his first month leading the Justice Department, Mr. Sessions has made lowering violent crime a priority and is traveling to Richmond, Va., on Wednesday to speak about the issue with law enforcement. Whether the emphasis on violent crime trickles down to U.S. attorney's offices like the Southern District is an open question.
One person long seen in the New York City legal community as a possible successor to Mr. Bharara under a Trump administration is Marc Mukasey, a white-collar defense lawyer who works at Greenberg Traurig LLP, the law firm that also employs longtime Trump adviser and former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani. Mr. Mukasey's father is former U.S. Attorney General Michael Mukasey, who sat near Mr. Sessions during his confirmation hearing and testified on his behalf.
The younger Mr. Mukasey declined to comment.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 385 of 1177

Mr. Sessions has already made comments that could signal future disagreements between the Justice Department and the Southern District. In a recent radio interview, he expressed concerns about trying international terrorists in federal courts in New York, saying he preferred using the military commissions at Guantanamo Bay in Cuba.
Both the Manhattan and Brooklyn U.S. attorney's offices have a long history of securing convictions from international terrorists in federal court. The Manhattan U.S. attorney's office, in particular, pursued some of the earliest terrorism prosecutions in the 1990s and was at the heart of the debate after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks about whether terrorists captured overseas could be tried in civilian courts.
During Mr. Bharara's tenure, there were several high-profile terrorism trials in Manhattan federal court, including one that led to the jury conviction and life sentence of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, the son-in-law of Osama bin Laden. Manhattan federal prosecutors have also been particularly aggressive in charging and arresting individuals outside the U.S. At a 2015 speech, Mr. Bharara said: "Somebody once made the mistake of asking me, 'What again is your jurisdiction exactly?' And I said, 'Are you familiar with Earth?' "
These international cases have required significant cooperation from law enforcement in other countries. That level of cooperation may be affected by the arrival of the Trump administration, given the president's emphasis on an "America first" posture in foreign affairs, according to former federal prosecutors.
WSJ Pro First: CFPB, Justice Department Poised to Square Off in Court
By Yuka Hayashi
WASHINGTON--A court case questioning the structure of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is about to take an unusual turn, with the Trump administration's Justice Department expected to oppose the independent watchdog agency--one of only a few instances in recent decades where two federal entities square off in court. Justice Department lawyers indicated earlier in March that they would side with PHH Corp., the mortgage lender challenging the CFPB's structure, as they requested an extension of the deadline for submitting briefs weighing in on the case.
The court has extended the deadline to Friday. Oral arguments are scheduled for May 24.
The PHH case has gone through various twists and turns in recent months, as a federal appeals court ruled the CFPB's structure unconstitutional and gave the president power to remove its director at will. The holding was invalidated four months later by the same court, paving the way for a rehearing. Meanwhile, the case has become part of a thorny political battle as Republicans look for ways to weaken the CFPB, which they have long criticized as an example of regulatory overreach.
In the request to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, the Justice Department lawyers led by Chad Readler, acting assistant attorney general, didn't specifically say they would oppose the CFPB, but alluded to their position by saying that "the views of the U.S. on matters involving the president's removal power are not always entirely congruent with the view of independent agencies."
"It would be a significant development if you have the Department of Justice arguing that a federal statute is unconstitutional," said Joe Palmore, co-chairman of the appellate and Supreme Court practice group at law firm Morrison &Foerster LLP, who works with trade groups critical of the CFPB. "The members of the court would certainly pay attention to what the U.S. says."
Trump administration officials have indicated they want to install new leadership at the CFPB but have acknowledged the pending court case is an obstacle. A White House representative said last month that President Donald Trump believed the CFPB was unaccountable and that the initial decision made by the three-judge panel at the D.C. Circuit court was correct.
In a Friday filing related to the rehearing, PHH said the CFPB was plagued by "many constitutional problems" and that giving the president power to remove the director at will won't be enough to resolve the case. "The appropriate remedy is to strike down the CFPB in its entirety," lawyers representing PHH wrote. "There can be no remand to an unconstitutional agency."
Legal experts say court cases in which two government entities confront each other are extremely rare.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 386 of 1177

Among them, 1988's Morrison v. Olson stands out owing to its similarity to the current case. That case involved a dispute between the House Judiciary Committee and the Justice Department over the appointment of an independent counsel to investigate an Environmental Protection Agency program. A Justice Department lawyer argued that naming an independent counsel who couldn't be removed by the president was a violation of the Constitution's separation of powers clause. The lawyer, whose claim was rejected by the Supreme Court, was Theodore Olson, then assistant attorney general for the Office of Legal Counsel, who now represents PHH in the case against the CFPB.
Among other big cases that involved government agencies facing off is 1990's Metro Broadcasting Inc. v. Federal Communications Commission, in which the Justice Department sided with the company that challenged the FCC's policy giving preference to minority broadcasters in obtaining licenses. The Supreme Court sided with the FCC.
In general, agencies in the executive branch speak with a single voice on legal questions. But it is possible for the Justice Department, which is run by an attorney general who answers to the president, to take a legal position opposing the head of an independent agency who doesn't, said Aditya Bamzai, an assistant professor at University of Virginia School of Law. "The very nature of independence creates this possibility, which might happen in the PHH case," he said.
The court's February decision to throw out the panel's ruling and rehear the case came after the Obama administration's Justice Department requested such a step.
Once the D.C. Circuit court hands down its ruling, more unusual questions will arise, this time about the role of the Justice Department in the possible appeal proceedings to the Supreme Court. The CFPB is authorized to defend itself in federal appeals court but must be represented by the Justice Department at the Supreme Court. Arguing that the CFPB wouldn't be adequately defended by Mr. Trump's Justice Department, Democratic lawmakers and consumer groups earlier asked the court for permission to intervene in the case. The request was rejected.
(This article is available to Pro Financial Regulation subscribers first, before being published to wsj.com.)
SEC Denies Winklevoss Application for Bitcoin ETF
By Dave Michaels and Paul Vigna
The Securities and Exchange Commission denied an application for the first exchange-traded fund that would track the price of bitcoin, a high-profile rejection for the digital currency and the Winklevoss brothers behind the proposal.
Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss and their Winklevoss Bitcoin Trust first applied for approval of the product nearly four years ago. The bitcoin industry had been hoping an exchange-traded product would make the currency attractive to Wall Street and retail investors. The denial sets that back, at least momentarily, and sent the price of bitcoin tumbling.
The price, which traded as high as $1,326 on Friday in anticipation of a possible approval, plummeted to as low as $1,022 after the SEC decision on heavy trading volume that reportedly led to delays on some bitcoin exchanges. It was most recently trading at $1,108.
The SEC's judgment, posted in an order on the regulator's website, marks the end, for now, of a long and drawn-out odyssey to package bitcoin into an exchange-traded product that could create a broader investor base for the virtual currency. The shares would have traded under the symbol COIN on the Bats BZX Exchange, operated by CBOE Holdings Inc..
"We remain optimistic and committed to bringing COIN to market, and look forward to continuing to work with the SEC staff," said Tyler Winklevoss, the chief financial officer of Digital Asset Services, LLC. "We began this journey almost four years ago, and are determined to see it through."
The SEC provided two main reasons for the denial, both related to bitcoin itself and the markets in which it trades. That could mean other proposed bitcoin products will face the same objections.
Under the law, the exchange listing the bitcoin product--in this case, Bats--must have agreements with significant exchanges that monitor trading in the commodity. The SEC said the only agreement Bats had was with the Gemini Exchange, which trades bitcoin, and that it didn't pass muster because it isn't sufficiently regulated.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 387 of 1177

Most bitcoin exchanges aren't regulated, and are spread across the globe from the U.S. to Europe to China. That means that Bats would simply be unable to enter into any kind of surveillance agreements with those exchanges that would satisfy the rules, the SEC said.
"We agree with the SEC that regulation and oversight are important to the health of any marketplace and the safety of all investors," Mr. Winklevoss said.
Bats declined to comment.
"The SEC is essentially saying that until significant bitcoin markets are regulated, the listing exchange really can't address concerns about the potential for manipulative trading," said Michael Mundt, a partner at law firm Stradley Ronon Stevens &Young LLP who formerly regulated exchange-traded products at the SEC.
The decision comes at a time when SEC officials have voiced concern about the growing complexity of some exchange-traded products and how volatile they can be during market routs. Trading in hundreds of ETPs was halted during a wild trading session on Aug. 24, 2015, when the market value of their shares diverged widely from the underlying holdings.
Bats and CBOE could appeal a staff denial, and they also could rewrite the proposal based upon feedback that could make the product more acceptable to regulators.
There are two other applications for similar bitcoin products on the SEC's desk, from Grayscale Investments LLC and SolidX Management LLC. The deadline on the latter, March 30, is fast approaching.
Representatives from both firms declined to comment.
Grayscale's product has an interesting wrinkle, in that it already trades publicly on an over-the-counter exchange to accredited investors. The firm is seeking to also list it on the New York Stock Exchange. It closed up 6.3% on Friday, moments before the SEC ruling was released, at $135.
Former SEC Chairman Mary Jo White in a May 2016 speech said, "Despite the popularity and broad success of these funds, their history is not without some turbulence," She at the time announced a task force that would focus on concerns about how some ETPs trade.
Corrections &Amplifications
The Securities and Exchange Commission decided to deny an application for the first exchange-traded product that tracks the price of bitcoin. An earlier version of this article incorrectly stated that the SEC is denying an application for an exchange. (March 10)
Credit Reports to Exclude Certain Negative Data, Boosting FICO Scores
By AnnaMaria Andriotis
Many tax liens and civil judgments soon will be taken off people's credit reports, the latest move to omit negative information from the powerful financial scorecards.
The decision by the three major credit-reporting firms-- Equifax Inc., Experian PLC and TransUnion--could help boost credit scores for millions of U.S. consumers, but could pose risks for lenders. The reports and scores often help decide how much consumers can borrow for a new house or car as well as determine their credit-card spending limit.
The unusual move by the influential firms comes partially in response to regulatory concerns. The three reporting bureaus rarely tinker with the information that goes on credit reports and that lenders consult to gauge consumers' ability and willingness to pay back debts.
Equifax, Experian and TransUnion recently decided to remove tax-lien and civil-judgment data starting around July 1, according to the Consumer Data Industry Association, a trade group that represents them. The firms will do so if those data don't include a complete list of at least three data points: a person's name, address and either a social security number or date of birth.
Many liens and most judgments don't include all three or four. This change will apply to new tax-lien and civil- judgment data that are added to credit reports as well as existing data on the reports.
The result will make many people who have these types of credit-report blemishes look more creditworthy.
The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau earlier this month released a report citing problems it found while
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 388 of 1177

examining credit bureaus and changes it is requiring. Issues the agency cited included improving standards for public-records data by using better identity-matching criteria and updating records more frequently.
Inaccurate information on credit reports, especially if it is negative information, can derail consumers from being able to gain access to credit and even lead to other setbacks like not being able to rent an apartment or get a job. One in five consumers has an error in at least one of their three major credit reports, according to a 2013 Federal Trade Commission study mandated by Congress. The three credit bureaus received around eight million requests disputing information on credit reports in 2011, according to the CFPB.
In 2015, the credit-reporting firms reached a settlement with New York's attorney general over several practices, including how they handle errors. This was followed by one with another 31 states. One more state, Mississippi, followed last year.
The state settlements already had prompted the credit-reporting firms to remove several negative data sets from reports. These included non-loan related items that were sent to collections firms, such as gym memberships, library fines and traffic tickets. The firms also will have to remove medical-debt collections that have been paid by a patient's insurance company from credit reports by 2018.
Such changes might help borrowers and could spur additional lending, possibly boosting economic activity. But it could potentially increase risks for lenders who might not be able to accurately assess borrowers' default risk. Consumers with liens or judgments are twice as likely to default on loan payments, according to LexisNexis Risk Solutions, a unit of RELX Group that supplies public-record information to the big three credit bureaus and lenders. "It's going to make someone who has poor credit look better than they should," said John Ulzheimer, a credit specialist and former manager at Experian and credit-score creator FICO. "Just because the lien or judgment information has been removed and someone's score has improved doesn't mean they'll magically become a better credit risk."
Removing this information from credit reports also will lead to changes in people's credit scores. Roughly 12 million U.S. consumers, or about 6% of the total U.S. population that has FICO credit scores, will see increases in those scores as a result of this change, according to the company that created the FICO system, which is used by lenders in most U.S. consumer underwriting decisions.
For most of these consumers, the score increase will be relatively modest. FICO projects that just under 11 million people will experience a score improvement of less than 20 points. FICO scores range from 300 to 850. The higher the score, the more creditworthy a consumer generally is.
Scores are projected to rise by at least 40 points for around 700,000 consumers, according to FICO. In many cases, that can mean the difference between getting approved for credit or denied it.
Civil judgments include cases in which collection firms take borrowers to court over an unpaid debt. Ankush Tewari, senior director of credit-risk assessment at LexisNexis Risk Solutions, says that nearly all judgments will be removed and about half of tax liens will be removed from credit reports as a result of the changed approach. He says LexisNexis will continue to offer the data directly to lenders.
In addition, if public court records aren't checked for updates on lien and judgment information at least every 90 days, they will have to be removed from credit reports.
Lenders will still be able to check public records on their own to find this information.
Analysis: It's Time for a Revolution in Investor Disclosures
By Jason Zweig
As far as most investors are concerned, the standard warning in prospectuses -- "past performance does not guarantee future results" -- might as well read "Wjxsndf omv gyjrhubji qmta gjq ek blgy zbq oynru."
A new initiative at the Securities and Exchange Commission could be one small step in the right direction. On March 10, the SEC is holding its first "evidence summit" on how to simplify and clarify financial disclosures.
"The SEC does a good job of providing disclosure of all the information that the most sophisticated investors would find useful," says Rick Fleming, the agency's investor advocate. "But with this new program we're looking to do a better job of making disclosure more useful to the average person."
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 389 of 1177

Financial disclosures need more than a tweaking. "The idea that you can just give people some paper and change their behavior is absurd," says George Loewenstein, a behavioral economist at Carnegie Mellon University.
Millions of Americans get heaps of prospectuses, proxy statements and periodic financial reports for mutual funds and other investments every year. In a world of multisensory, electronic information, these dead-tree documents still arrive by snail mail, dozens of impenetrable pages that can only be described as chloroform in print.
And, for all their detail, these disclosures don't even inform the people who receive them.
A recent survey of 750 wealthy investors by Natixis Global Asset Management found that 71% believe that index funds are "less risky" than other investments.
However, nearly all index funds are designed to be as risky as the markets they invest in. If the S&P 500 goes down 30% in a year, for instance, an S&P 500 index fund charging 0.1% in annual expenses will lose 30.1%.
In a study just published in the Journal of Behavioral Finance, graduate business students chose among four index funds identical in all respects except fees. Students who didn't review standard SEC disclosures about the importance of minimizing fees put an average of 50% of their money into the more-expensive funds. Those who got the information about fees still put a wealth-wasting 47% into the higher-cost portfolios.
"We thought the disclosure would mitigate the problem," says co-author Nathan Mauck, a finance professor at the University of Missouri-Kansas City, "but it didn't."
People are not stupid. What they are is busy and lazy. Pressed for time, with countless stimuli tugging at our attention, not many of us want to bother spending hours, days or weeks focusing on a decision -- no matter how much is at stake.
Many experiments have shown that the harder a risk is to understand, the less it will seem likely to occur. Paradoxically, then, financial documents that discuss every conceivable risk in highly technical detail may end up making the investment seem safer.
What can be done?
Moving away from paper to interactive, online displays would create "a format that is comparable and consistent across investments," says Eric Johnson, a professor at Columbia Business School who studies consumer decision- making. Instead of reading that your fund charges 1.13% in annual expenses, for instance, you could see 1.13% placed on a spectrum from the cheapest fund in its category to the most expensive.
Daniel Goldstein and Jake Hofman are behavioral scientists at Microsoft Research, a unit of the computer giant. They have shown that numbers become much easier to grasp -- and remember -- when the words "to put this in perspective" are coupled with a familiar reference.
Today's prospectuses show cumulative fees on a $10,000 investment over one, three, five and 10 years. Instead, an investor should be able to see those fee totals for any amount or time period she chooses.
If stocks gained an average of 6% annually over the next 30 years, someone who invested $25,000 and paid a 1% yearly fee would cumulatively forgo more than $35,500 in gains. "To put this in perspective," the disclosure might say, "that difference is greater than the amount you started with."
Simulations -- video-game-like displays animating the range of outcomes based on past experience -- could convey risk and return more memorably than words or numbers can do.
Ultimately, disclosures could become "more like a teaching tool," says Prof. Loewenstein of

Title: HSBC: Fresh Eyes Give Investors Hope for Change; AIA chief Mark Tucker will bring an outsider's view to chairman role
ARTICLE:
HSBC is stepping out of its comfort zone in picking its first chairman from outside its executive ranks. In Mark Tucker, the hard-charging, entrepreneurial chief executive of insurer AIA, it has chosen someone of a very different breed.
Investors will hope the bank has found a chairman who can pick up the pace at an institution whose privileged history --it was for decades Hong Kong's de facto central bank--has at times slowed it down. HSBC has become good at returning capital, but partly because it is struggling to find profitable growth.
Mr. Tucker will be a nonexecutive chairman, but he will be an engaged and demanding one for HSBC's mostly Hong Kong- and London-based executives. The bank needs a tune up and Mr. Tucker has the potential to make some people's lives uncomfortable. That is undoubtedly part of the plan, but a shake-up isn't without risks.
For HSBC, much will depend on who he puts up as chief executive when Stuart Gulliver retires next year. For clues, look at what HSBC needs to do better.
The biggest issue is getting more juice out of its global commercial and investment banking businesses. HSBC
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 401 of 1177
does a huge amount of corporate lending at low returns, but struggles to turn those relationships into more capital markets, advisory and other ancillary business. That holds back its return on equity.
The next chief executive will need to bring expertise and fresh ideas there. Internally, that could point to another relative outsider like Matthew Westerman, a recent recruit from Goldman Sachs who is co-head of global banking, HSBC's name for traditional investment banking.
Two outsiders at the top of HSBC really would be radical. Fresh minds without attachments to the way things have always been done could revitalize the bank.
The bank has had to change already: it has endured real discomfort after misbehavior at its Swiss, Mexican and other arms exposed it to penalties and very public reprimands. Mr. Tucker, who has long experience of financial services in Asia and the U.K. as well as serving on Goldman Sachs's board since 2012, will have to manage the legacy of this and sharpen up the rest. His biggest challenge will be working out just how hard to push.
Write to Paul J. Davies at paul.davies@wsj.com
Get financial insights and commentary on global investing from The Wall Street Journal's Heard on the Street team. Subscribe to the podcast.
Credit: By Paul J. Davies

Title: Kuwait Launches $8 Billion Bond Sale; Persian Gulf state is the latest to turn to debt markets to make up for oil revenue slide
ARTICLE:
DUBAI--Kuwait intends to raise $8 billion in its debut international bond sale, bankers familiar with the deal said Monday, the latest Persian Gulf state to turn to the debt markets to offset a slide in oil income.
Kuwait, one of the world's largest oil exporters, launched the two-tranche bond sale after receiving about $29 billion worth of orders, the bankers said. Final pricing was tighter than the initial guidance at 0.75 percentage point above U.S. Treasurys for the 5-year, $3.5 billion tranche and 1 percentage point above U.S. Treasurys for the 10- year, $4.5 billion portion.
The oil exporters of the Persian Gulf are issuing bonds at their fastest clip since last year as governments across the region seek fresh funds to shore up their coffers. Lower oil revenues have also pushed the Gulf nations to introduce far-reaching economic reforms such as raising taxes and cutting spending to counter widening budget deficits.
Oman raised $5 billion earlier this month, while Saudi Arabia sold a mammoth $17.5 billion bond in 2016. Qatar, Abu Dhabi and Bahrain all tapped international markets last year.
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 403 of 1177
Both Kuwait and Oman tapped the debt market ahead of a U.S. Federal Reserve meeting this week where policy makers are expected to raise interest rates, lifting borrowing costs.
Like its Gulf neighbors, Kuwait's government relies heavily on crude exports for its budget financing needs. Following the drop in oil prices since the middle of 2014, Kuwait last year for the first time posted a budget deficit. Government efforts at pushing through fiscal reforms have met with resistance in the country's parliament. Kuwait nevertheless boasts the lowest break-even oil price among the Gulf countries and is also home to one of the world's largest sovereign-wealth funds, the Kuwait Investment Authority. It is rated AA with stable outlook by both Standard &Poor's and Fitch.
"The decision to borrow from external markets will mean less withdrawals from KIA (Kuwait Invest Authority)," said Giyas Gokkent, an economist covering the Middle East and North Africa at the Institute of International Finance. "With global interest rates still at low levels, it makes sense for Kuwait to borrow particularly since KIA could generate higher returns on its own funds," Mr. Gokkent said.
Kuwait's Finance Minister Anas al-Saleh last year said the country was considering a $10 billion bond sale. Fixed-income analysts at Dubai-based Mashreq said the final amount Kuwait is raising is lower than previously announced because of a rebound in oil prices after the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed on a production cut in November, resulting in lower projected external financing needs for the country.
Citi, Deutsche Bank, HSBC, J.P. Morgan, NBK Capital and Standard Chartered are bookrunners on Kuwait's bond sale.
Write to Nicolas Parasie at nicolas.parasie@wsj.com
Credit: By Nicolas Parasie

Title: Demanding and Direct: HSBC's New Chairman Mark Tucker; Bank's new chairman could lead a major shake-up of the British lender's culture
ARTICLE:
Corrections &Amplifications
Mark Tucker led AIA Group Ltd. as it became the second-largest life insurance company in the world by market
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 405 of 1177
capitalization. An earlier version of this article incorrectly stated it had become the second-largest insurance company by market capitalization.
Mark Tucker, the first outsider tapped as chairman of HSBC Holdings PLC, is a savvy businessman with intimate knowledge of the U.K. and Asian markets where the bank principally operates.
But people who know the hard-driving Mr. Tucker say one of his biggest effects on the 152-year-old British lender could be a shake-up of what some describe as a bureaucratic, clubby culture.
Mr. Tucker, 59, ran Hong Kong-based insurer AIA Group Ltd. for seven years, taking it from a unit of American International Group Inc. to the second-largest life insurance company in the world by market capitalization. He has been described by people who work with him as demanding and direct--someone who keeps staffers constantly on their toes.
Associates say he emails at all hours, responds to others quickly and keeps track of who delivers on commitments--and who doesn't.
Those qualities could stir things up at HSBC, which critics say has resembled the civil service, filled with employees who feel they are guaranteed jobs for life. HSBC also has admitted to having too many layers of management.
"He doesn't suffer fools, that is for sure," said one Asia-based business associate of Mr. Tucker, who asked not to be named because he wasn't authorized to speak on the record. "You have to pass a bit of a sniff test before he'll give you the time you need."
Mr. Tucker declined to comment for this article. A spokeswoman for HSBC declined to comment.
The hiring of Mr. Tucker is a big departure for HSBC, which for decades promoted its chief executive into the chairman role, usually at the end of a lifetime career at the bank.
At HSBC, one of Mr. Tucker's most important tasks will be appointing a new chief executive to replace current CEO Stuart Gulliver, who expects to step down in 2018. Some candidates are HSBC's global retail banking head John Flint, who has been at the bank since 1989, and HSBC Bank PLC CEO Antonio Simoes, who joined in 2007.
But external candidates will also have a strong shot and could be the preference of the bank's investors. One successful recent outside hire has been former Goldman Sachs banker Matthew Westerman, who a year ago was brought on as co-head of global banking. Mr. Westerman restructured the group, clearing out a cadre of senior managers and raising internal performance standards.
Established in 1865, HSBC was formed to finance trade after the Hong Kong and Shanghai ports opened up in the wake of the First Opium War. HSBC long functioned as Hong Kong's de facto central bank. When the territory was under British control, HSBC's chairman often held Hong Kong political appointments as well.
By 2009, the bank was in 88 countries and creaking under an outdated structure in which dozens of country heads reported directly to the CEO. It had to adapt to higher capital requirements and spent billions of dollars improving its systems after U.S. authorities said its money-laundering checks had failed.
Recently, HSBC has pared businesses and exited countries but it is still far from meeting a return on equity target of more than 10%, and reported worse than expected fourth-quarter results. There are also question marks around its plan to invest more in China retail banking and a domestic securities business, which analysts say could take a decade or more to pay off.
"Bringing an outsider's view and an innate sense of urgency will be immensely helpful" to turning around HSBC, said Jonathan Larsen, a former senior Citigroup executive who worked closely with Mr. Tucker on an insurance distribution deal.
A former professional soccer player in the U.K., Mr. Tucker expanded Prudential PLC's business across Asia in the 1990s, and worked as the finance director at British lender HBOS PLC while it was on a lending binge in the mid- 2000s.
Mr. Tucker joined AIA in 2010 when AIG was readying it for a listing in Hong Kong. Under his leadership, the insurer's share price has more than doubled and its new-business value, a key measure of insurers' profitability, has quadrupled to $2.75 billion in 2016. The company has expanded into new markets and built its business in
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 406 of 1177

China even as economic growth there slowed.
Mr. Tucker has served as a board member of Goldman Sachs Group Inc. since 2012, a role he will give up. Between 2009 and 2012, he was a nonexecutive director at the Bank of England.
Mr. Tucker is hands-on when it comes to striking deals, say people familiar with his management style, sending emails with detailed questions about agreements and negotiations that in other deals are often sent by bankers. He pulled the plug on bids for Dah Sing Financial Holdings Ltd.'s life-insurance businesses and Ageas NV's Hong Kong life insurance business while at AIA, according to people familiar with the matter, balking at the high offers put forth by others.
Write to Julie Steinberg at julie.steinberg@wsj.com and Margot Patrick at margot.patrick@wsj.com
Related
* Heard on the Street: Fresh Eyes Give Investors Hope for Change
* HSBC Says AIA CEO Mark Tucker Will Be Next Chairman
* Heard: History-Making New Chairman Is a Wise Choice
Credit: Julie Steinberg, Margot Patrick

Title: The 10-Point. A personal, guided tour to the best scoops and stories every day in The Wall Street Journal, from Editor in Chief Gerard Baker.
ARTICLE:
Good morning,
Republicans' Health Arithmetic
The number of Americans without health insurance would grow by 24 million over the next decade under a House Republican proposal to replace most of the Affordable Care Act, according to a nonpartisan report that is likely to complicate GOP lawmakers' efforts to unite around the plan. The Congressional Budget Office projections were disputed by the bill's backers, but rattled some centrist Senate Republicans who have said they won't support legislation that leaves a large number of people without coverage. President Trump campaigned on a pledge to cover all Americans. The CBO also projected the legislation would reduce the federal deficit by $337 billion over the
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 408 of 1177
next decade and initially cause premiums to be higher than under current law, though by 2026 they would be lower. See how the House GOP plan compares to the ACA here.
Autonomous Autos
Chip maker Intel has agreed to buy Israeli car-camera pioneer Mobileye for $15.3 billion--one of its biggest acquisitions ever--in the latest Silicon Valley bet on a vision of cars as turbocharged computers on wheels. The purchase would give Intel a widely used technology in the rapidly emerging business of computer-assisted driving, as well as Mobileye's customer relationships with auto makers including GM, Volkswagen and Honda. Having largely missed the smartphone revolution, Intel is paying 62 times forward earnings--all its offshore cash and then some--to join the accelerating autonomous-vehicle race , which has sparked bidding wars for companies that specialize in self-driving gear or software.
Air War
We report that Mr. Trump has given the CIA secret authority to conduct drone strikes against suspected terrorists, changing the Obama administration's policy of limiting the spy agency's paramilitary role--and reopening a CIA- Pentagon turf war. The new authority, not previously disclosed, represents a significant departure from the practice that had become standard by the end of former President Barack Obama's tenure: The CIA used drones and other intelligence resources to locate suspected terrorists but left the actual strikes to the military. The agency first used its new authority in late February on a senior al Qaeda leader in Syria, U.S. officials said.
Snowed Under
"I'm busy" has long been code for "I'm feeling overwhelmed" or "life is chaotic." Yes, we're legitimately busy, working more than ever, both in and out of the office, writes our Bonds columnist Elizabeth Bernstein, but most of us aren't truly too busy to make time for our loved ones--yet that is the impression we give. We brag about being busy, wrongly seeing it as the opposite of lazy, and use it as an excuse when we drop the ball or simply don't want to be bothered. So what to do? Banish the word, says one marriage and family therapist. Schedule less, knowing that something will always pop up. And drop the shame.
Today's Video
March Madness Gets Trumped
President Trump may be snubbing the NCAA bracket challenge this year, but that didn't stop the star-studded March Madness broadcast team from talking about wiretapping locker rooms, repealing and replacing basketball rules and "Making March Mad Again."
TOP STORIES
U.S.
White House Back-Pedals on Claim Obama Wiretapped Trump's Phones
Bomb Threats Reshape Jewish Centers
WORLD
U.K. Parliament Clears Way to Brexit
South Korean Prosecutors to Question Former President Park Geun-hye
BUSINESS
AstraZeneca Gives Rejected Drugs a Second Life
One Lawyer, 6,905 Hours Leads to $1.5 Million Bill in Sprint Suit
MARKETS
U.S. 10-Year Bond Yield Closes at Highest Since September 2014
Demanding and Direct: HSBC's New Chairman Mark Tucker
Number of the Day
$4 billion
The approximate loss William Ackman's Pershing Square Capital Management took when it sold its stake in drugmaker Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, bringing a tortured saga to a close.
Today's Question
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 409 of 1177

Returning to our story above, what are your thoughts on the CBO report? Send your comments, which we may edit before publication, to 10point@wsj.com . Please include your name and location.
--Compiled by Margaret Rawson
Reader Response
Responding to yesterday's question on pension-risk transfer, Augusta Era Golian of Texas said: "Some companies have made inflation adjustments to their pensioners to keep them whole, even though not legally required. It's doubtful that insurance companies will do so--increasing pressure on retirees just as the federal government seems to be thinning the safety net." Bill Sanders of Colorado wrote: "There are basically three factors in pricing the liability (cost) of a pension-risk transfer: expenses, mortality and investment return. In assuming this liability, the winning insurance company is projecting these factors decades into the future. Better make sure the insurance company is solid and will be around to make these pension payments." And Jerome Schmid of South Carolina commented: "Sad to see defined-benefit plans slip away into history. But employers no longer care about employee welfare (despite volumes of acclamations in various mission statements), as once-paternalistic corporations have been reduced to financial schemes, manipulated like exotic derivative securities. It is probably a very good idea to turn over the plans to insurance companies who are staffed with people who are (thought to be) competent risk managers, and who are far more likely be around 10 years from now."
This daily briefing is named "The 10-Point" after the nickname conferred by the editors of The Wall Street Journal on the lead column of the legendary "What's News" digest of top stories. Technically, "10-point" referred to the size of the typeface. The type is smaller now but the name lives on.

Title: Why Analysts Missed the Fed's Signals on Raising Rates; Markets now see it as a near-certainty, but many thought the bank would hold off because of its previous moves and Trump's plans
ARTICLE:
Investors rely on analysts to tell them how the Federal Reserve is likely to move interest rates. Until just a few days ago, however, many of those experts missed signals that the central bank would lift borrowing costs on Wednesday.
Strong hiring, firming inflation, buoyant stock markets, a placid global economic outlook and Chairwoman Janet Yellen's upbeat congressional testimony last month didn't fundamentally alter Wall Street's view that the Fed would hold rates steady until later this year. This despite Fed officials saying they anticipated three moves in 2017. Neither did it seem to matter to the markets when, three weeks ago, minutes of the Fed's most recent meeting on Jan. 31-Feb. 1 showed that officials thought they'd likely move "fairly soon."
It wasn't until Feb. 28, when Fed officials launched a barrage of public comments clearly signaling an imminent rate increase, that analysts and markets began expecting the move on Wednesday, which markets now see as a near-certainty.
"We have completely flipped our position," Brett Ewing, chief market strategist for First Franklin Financial Services, wrote in a note to clients Tuesday.
How did so many get it wrong?
Analysts point to a number of reasons. Some say they were expecting the Trump administration to impose trade curbs that could stifle economic growth. Others thought Fed officials would prefer to sit tight until they got a clearer picture of the new president's policies. And several pointed to the experience of 2015 and 2016, when the cautious central bank delivered fewer rate increases than it had projected. Officials penciled in three rate increases for 2015 and four for 2016, but delivered just one in each year.
That left investors feeling "burned," Mr. Ewing said.
Before each of the rate increases in 2015 and 2016, Fed officials used the statement released at the preceding meeting to send a strong signal that an increase was coming, but they didn't do this on Feb. 1 after the latest meeting concluded.
"It appeared there was a pattern developing," said Michael Feroli, chief U.S. economist at J.P. Morgan. Mr. Feroli originally predicted the Fed would raise rates twice in 2017, with the first move coming in May.
"There was no signal like that in the February statement, so I think we and many others concluded, well, there's an economic case for March but they're just not saying it," he said. "That's why we went to May."
After hearing the recent comments from Fed officials, Mr. Feroli revised his forecast to include three rate increases for 2017-in March, June and September.
Michael Gapen, chief U.S. economist at Barclays, said he thought the Trump administration would put in place tariffs or other trade restrictions early in the year. That would cause a short-term boost to inflation but also curb growth, he said. Mr. Gapen predicted the Fed would look past that temporary inflation increase and focus on lower growth as a reason to hold off on raising rates in March.
"We were actually in the process of thinking about revising the U.S. outlook because the delays in enacting immigration reform and health-care reform, in our minds, were pushing the ability to get trade policies enacted this year down," he said. "Then all the messaging came in from the Fed. Well, this saves us some trouble."
Mr. Gapen has now upped his forecast from two rate increases this year to three, "leaning towards four."
Kathy Bostjancic, head of U.S. macro investor services at Oxford Economics, said she originally thought the uncertainty surrounding fiscal policy would stay the Fed's hand. She thought officials "would want to wait to get some sense about how growth was going to line up for the end of 2017 and 2018."
Jose Rasco, chief investment strategist at HSBC, said his bank didn't think the economy was strong enough to justify a move this month. Then came the rally that brought multiple record-setting days in equity markets.
"What has changed is that the Fed governors came out and said they saw this 'release of animal spirits,'" Mr. Rasco said.
One analyst who entertained the idea of a March rate increase is Roberto Perli, a partner at Cornerstone Macro. In a note following the Feb. 22 release of the Jan. 31-Feb. 1 meeting minutes, Mr. Perli wrote that a March move
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 412 of 1177
"should not be dismissed out of hand."
In the end, Mr. Ewing said, there is only so much a forecaster can anticipate.
"Nobody knows the future," he said. "We put our best guesstimate out there and we live with that." Write to David Harrison at david.harrison@wsj.com
Credit: By David Harrison

Title: Trump's Currency Conundrum Risks Fueling G-20 Trade Tensions; The president thinks the dollar is too high, but his key economic proposals are boosting its value
ARTICLE:
Corrections &Amplifications
In 1985, other nations agreed to appreciate their currencies after the dollar's strength fueled protectionism in the U.S. An earlier version of this article incorrectly stated how the nations responded.
BADEN-BADEN, Germany--U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, meeting the world's top financial leaders in Germany on Friday, faces a currency conundrum.
His boss, President Donald Trump, thinks the dollar is too strong while China's yuan and Germany's euro, in particular, are too weak, giving those countries an unfair trade advantage. Yet Mr. Trump's key domestic economic proposals--and rising interest rates in the U.S.--are boosting the dollar's value.
Failure to solve this contradiction could escalate global trade tensions .
"Trump faces an impossible combination of policies if he truly wants a weak dollar," said David Bloom, global head of currency research at global bank, HSBC. "Most of his ideas point to a stronger dollar," he said, which will raise manufacturing costs and crimp demand for U.S. products overseas.
Mr. Mnuchin will push finance ministers from China, Japan, Germany and other Group of 20 largest economies to abide by existing currency vows. G-20 nations have pledged not to use their exchange rates for competitive gains. Mr. Trump has repeatedly criticized China's yuan policy, accusing the country of keeping its exchange rate artificially low, helping drive a $350 billion annual U.S. trade deficit with China. The administration is drafting plans to sanction countries that devalue their currencies.
European Central Bank President Mario Draghi last week said it is the dollar that is overvalued, not the euro that is undervalued. And China's premier Li Keqiang said Wednesday Beijing wouldn't devalue its currency and didn't want a trade war.
Some analysts suspect the administration might be trying to talk the greenback down .
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 414 of 1177
"The administration is trying to pretend that if countries were to stop manipulating their currency, U.S. trade would move closer to balanced," said Steven Englander, head of G10 FX strategy at Citigroup Inc. "The problem is the attractiveness of the U.S. as a place to put capital makes it hard to get that outcome."
Mr. Mnuchin has reaffirmed a strong-dollar policy but said short-term strength is a concern, compounding the uncertainty over the administration's approach.
Still, many investors are betting the dollar will continue strengthening as the Federal Reserve raises interest rates and the administration pursues corporate tax cuts and infrastructure spending. Hedge funds and other speculative investors currently hold roughly $16 billion in bets on a rising dollar.
Mr. Englander said the dollar could weaken in the near-term if the U.S. signals it will take an aggressive stance on trade negotiations at the G20 meeting, given worries about a trade war. But early signs are that Mr. Mnuchin may play a moderating role.
Adding to Washington's currency challenges, if Beijing were to stop controlling the yuan's value right now, most economists say the country's weakening growth prospects would mean the exchange rate would plummet. The country has burned through $1 trillion dollars propping the yuan up.
"The U.S. doesn't want China to depeg now," said Brad Setser a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations and a former top U.S. Treasury official in the Obama administration. A "free float would see devaluation that could boost Chinese exports, widening the U.S. trade deficit."
That's the exact opposite of what Mr. Trump says he wants.
When China devalued its currency in August 2015, markets tumbled across the globe as investors feared the widespread repercussions of a slowdown in the world's second-largest economy.
And too strong a dollar could also roil markets. Emerging economies have stocked up dollar-denominated debt, and a surge in the greenback could trigger severe capital outflows from some of them. Since investors would most likely put their cash into U.S. assets, the dollar would rise further in a dangerous feedback loop.
The International Monetary Fund, the world's currency cop, said last year the dollar was already 10% to 20% over the value market fundamentals warrant. Since then, the greenback has risen by 7% against a basket of currencies. The IMF is worried that a further widening of that imbalance could spur more protectionist pressures in the U.S. and invite retaliation by other nations.
Some experts think a new global exchange-rate accord could be one way to relieve tensions. In 1985, other nations agreed to appreciate their currencies after the dollar's strength fueled protectionism in the U.S.
Ted Truman, a senior fellow at Peterson Institute for International Economics and a former top Treasury official, sees a small but rising probability that this could happen again.
"Compared with a trade war, which would damage everyone a lot more, some adjustment in the currency might be a better alternative," Mr. Truman said.
Write to Ian Talley at ian.talley@wsj.com and Chelsey Dulaney at Chelsey.Dulaney@wsj.com
Credit: By Ian Talley and Chelsey Dulaney

Title: Mnuchin Says U.S. Is Seeking to Avoid Trade Wars; Treasury secretary expected to face pressure at G-20 over 'America First' policy
ARTICLE:
BERLIN--U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, facing growing anxieties President Donald Trump's "America First" economic platform could trigger a damaging series of retaliatory sanctions around the world, said Thursday the administration doesn't want to start any trade wars .
Rather, Mr. Mnuchin said Washington is trying to rebalance unfair trade relationships that are harming growth in the world's largest economic engine. Fixing those inequalities, such as when countries like China manipulate their exchange rates to gain a competitive trade advantage, actually will spur global growth, he said.
But the Treasury secretary, who will be making his first appearance on the global stage Friday at a gathering of the world's finance chiefs from the Group of 20 industrialized and emerging economies, is facing a tough sell. Besides fears of unilateral sanctions sparking retaliation, Mr. Trump's policies are set to strengthen the dollar, a key sore point for the administration. Failure to solve this currency conundrum could ratchet up global trade tensions.
"Our focus is creating economic growth that is good for the United States and for the rest of the world," Mr. Mnuchin said after a meeting with German Finance Minister Wolfgang Scha?uble. "It is not our desire to get into trade wars, it is our desire to deal with where there is imbalance in certain trade relations," he said.
Trump administration threats to level unilateral currency sanctions, vows to rewrite international trade deals and jabs at the World Trade Organization have spooked G-20 nations . Ahead of the G-20 meeting in the resort town of Baden-Baden, Germany, the International Monetary Fund warned that the U.S., China and other large economies risk derailing the global economy if leaders fail to fight a growing protectionist tide.
But the Treasury secretary dismissed those concerns, saying the U.S. is one of the most open markets in the world. "The president is interested in making sure that our agreements are reciprocal," he said. "He wants free and fair trade."
Mr. Scha?uble, whose administration has criticized the Trump administration's trade rhetoric, sounded a note of optimism. Berlin is particularly concerned about the U.S. introducing a border-adjusted tax and the White House rolling back some financial regulations.
"We won't solve all problems in Baden-Baden, but the process will continue in a constructive and positive way. That's a very good message," he said.
But G-20 delegates were struggling late Thursday to hammer out a consensus on whether to accept a U.S. proposal to adopt a commitment to "free and fair trade," rather than past G-20 vows to avoid all forms of protectionism, an official from one of the countries said.
The U.S. administration is facing a policy contradiction. Mr. Trump says he thinks the dollar is too strong while
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 417 of 1177
China's yuan and Germany's euro, in particular, are too weak, giving those countries an unfair trade advantage. Yet Mr. Trump's key domestic economic proposals--and rising interest rates in the U.S.--are boosting the dollar's value. Failure to solve this contradiction could escalate global trade tensions.
"Trump faces an impossible combination of policies if he truly wants a weak dollar," said David Bloom, global head of currency research at global bank, HSBC. "Most of his ideas point to a stronger dollar," he said, which will raise manufacturing costs and crimp demand for U.S. products overseas.
The Treasury Secretary tried Thursday to present a more moderate position than his boss, saying that while a strong dollar may cause the economy problems in the short term, in the long term, it is a sign of confidence in the world's currency reserve.
"What I am focused on is the long-term aspects of the currency and the importance of it as a stable reserve currency around the world," he said.
That is why Mr. Mnuchin will push finance ministers from China, Japan, Germany and other G-20 countries to abide by existing currency vows to not to use their exchange rates for competitive gains.
Drafting plans to sanction countries that devalue their currencies, the Trump administration repeatedly has targeted China's yuan policy, accusing the country of keeping its exchange rate artificially low and driving a $350 billion annual U.S. trade deficit with the country. And Germany's record-breaking trade surplus, the largest in the world, has put it in U.S. sights also.
"What can I as German finance minister do to reduce the surplus?" Mr. Scha?uble said Thursday. Economically struggling eurozone countries don't make an attractive destination for investors and need to overhaul their economies, Berlin says.
European Central Bank President Mario Draghi last week said it is the dollar that is overvalued, not the euro that is undervalued.
And China's premier, Li Keqiang, said Wednesday that Beijing wouldn't devalue its currency and didn't want a trade war.
"The administration is trying to pretend that if countries were to stop manipulating their currency, U.S. trade would move closer to balanced," said Steven Englander, head of G10 FX strategy at Citigroup Inc. "The problem is the attractiveness of the U.S. as a place to put capital makes it hard to get that outcome."
Still, many investors are betting the dollar will continue strengthening as the Federal Reserve raises interest rates and the administration pursues corporate tax cuts and infrastructure spending. Hedge funds and other speculative investors currently hold about $16 billion in bets on a rising dollar.
Adding to Washington's currency challenges, if Beijing were to stop controlling the yuan's value right now, most economists say the country's weakening growth prospects would mean the exchange rate would plummet. The country has burned through $1 trillion propping up the yuan.
"The U.S. doesn't want China to depeg now," said Brad Setser, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations and a former top U.S. Treasury official in the Obama administration. A "free float would see devaluation that could boost Chinese exports, widening the U.S. trade deficit."
That is the exact opposite of what Mr. Trump says he wants.
When China devalued its currency in August 2015, markets tumbled across the globe as investors feared the widespread repercussions of a slowdown in the world's second-largest economy.
And too strong a dollar also could roil markets. Emerging economies have stocked up dollar-denominated debt, and a surge in the U.S. currency could trigger severe capital outflows from some of them. Since investors most likely would put their cash into U.S. assets, the dollar would rise further in a dangerous feedback loop.
The International Monetary Fund, the world's currency cop, said last year the dollar was already 10% to 20% over the value market fundamentals warrant. Since then, the dollar has risen by 7% against a basket of currencies. The IMF is worried that a further widening of that imbalance could spur more protectionist pressures in the U.S. and invite retaliation by other nations.
"Above all, we should collectively avoid self-inflicted injuries," IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde said
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 418 of 1177

Tuesday. "This requires steering clear of policies that would seriously undermine trade, migration, capital flows and the sharing of technologies across borders."
Write to Ian Talley at ian.talley@wsj.com , Andrea Thomas at andrea.thomas@wsj.com and Chelsey Dulaney at Chelsey.Dulaney@wsj.com

Title: CMO Today: Inside Politico After Split With Jim VandeHei; Here's your morning roundup of the biggest marketing, advertising and media industry news and happenings.
ARTICLE:
INSIDE POLITICO: It has been over a year since Politico's former CEO and co-founder, Jim VandeHei, said he was departing the beltway publisher amid growing tensions with owner Robert Allbritton. Since then, Mr. VandeHei launched rival venture Axios with $10 million in funding and support from three executives who also exited Politico along with star reporter Mike Allen. According to executives who spoke with The Wall Street Journal, Politico has withstood the upheaval . Mr. Allbritton, who is now CEO of the site, has made a conscious effort to reverse or pare back some of his predecessor's initiatives, including a push to launch versions of the site in state capitals. And he's tried to focus on things he felt had fallen through the cracks. "If it was interesting to Jim, it would get done. If it wasn't, it didn't," Mr. Allbritton told the Journal. Mr.
VandeHei's backers dispute that critique and say he handed off a successful and growing company. While Politico wouldn't divulge detailed financials, subscription revenue for Politico Pro was up 30% last year and site traffic in January was nearly double that of a year ago. But advertising is still "soft" as businesses wait to see what sort of legislation emerges during the Trump presidency. Some Politico staffers worry Axios will become a head-to-head threat, going after their advertisers and subscribers.
GOOGLE DILEMMA: Google said it plans to offer advertisers better controls over where their content appears after major U.K. marketers said they would be pulling their spots from YouTube and the Google Display Network because their ads appeared next to offensive or extremist content. Google is reviewing its policies and planning to ask advertisers and ad agencies what additional controls they want , reports WSJ. Brands in the U.K., including HSBC, Lloyds Bank, the Royal Bank of Scotland, Vodafone, Sky and Barclays have pulled their ads or are considering it , reports Campaign. The British unit of ad holding company Havas made waves when it said it was suspending all advertising with Google for clients in the U.K., including Domino's Pizza and mobile firm O2. The agency said it was taking precautions to assure that the "environment is safe, regulated to the degree necessary and additive to their brands' objectives." Havas later said the policy was "a temporary move made by the local team" and didn't mean the firm was changing its use of Google globally. Not one to miss out, Martin Sorrell, CEO of the largest ad holding company WPP, told Business Insider that Google and Facebook have the same responsibility as other media companies. "They cannot masquerade as technology companies, particularly when they place advertisements."
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 420 of 1177
TICK TOCK: Chief marketing officers are under mounting pressure to reach increasingly elusive customers while investing in new technologies and digital mediums. Now, add a ticking clock. The infamously short tenure of a CMO is getting even shorter , according to a study from executive search firm Spencer Stuart. The study of CMOs from 100 of the top U.S. ad spenders found that the average tenure for marketing leaders fell to 42 months in 2016, from 44 months in 2015, reports CMO Today, the second year in a row that tenures have shrunk. "Tough business headwinds, new technologies and pressures to change quickly" are among the many reasons for the turnover, said Greg Welch, a consultant in Spencer Stuart's marketing officer group. "It's the perfect storm." Changes in the C- suite role can also have major implications for Madison Avenue, as new CMOs tend to change up a company's marketing strategy and potentially its ad agencies. The study also shows that the diversity problem in advertising exists beyond agencies. Of the marketing chiefs in the study, about 23% were women, and only 9% were African- American, Hispanic or Asian.
MARCH MADNESS: If there was ever a time for advertisers to flex their creative muscle, it would be the NCAA men's basketball tournament. Team branding, coaches, mascots and former players are all fair game for the more than $1 billion in TV ads, but the stars of the basketball tournament--the players themselves--are off limits . So what's a creative to do? According to the New York Times, LG Electronics USA is airing TV spots featuring mascots from various teams using its appliances. Buffalo Wild Wings put an actor in a Louisville uniform to resemble a player in its commercial, and Pizza Hut tapped former Duke star Grant Hill to hawk its pizza-ordering shoes. The NCAA prohibits student athletes or their likenesses from appearing in any advertising. The strict stance that has been controversial as some think the athletes deserve a slice of the dough they are raking in for CBS and Turner, while the NCAA argues it's designed to protect student athletes.
Elsewhere
Hulu has added NBC cable networks like Bravo and E! to a test of its upcoming live-streaming service. However, NBC, a part-owner in Hulu, has yet to strike a deal for its channels, including the NBC broadcast network, to be part of the lineup when the Hulu live offering officially launches. [Bloomberg ]
Music industry veteran Irving Azoff and his business partner, Tim Leiweke, are buying up music trade magazines, but not necessarily for their ad revenue. Thus far, they've purchased Venues Today and are in talks to buy Pollstar, both of which cover the live-music business and are seen as a way to help break into the conference business. [WSJ ]
The Russian government has called for an audit of U.S. media, including Radio Liberty, the Voice of America and CNN. The audit is a response to what Russia sees as American attacks on state-sponsored media like RT News in the U.S. [USA Today ]
Chance the Rapper tweeted that Apple Music paid him $500,000 to place his new album on Apple Music for two weeks, offering a glimpse into the workings of Apple's exclusive deals with artists. [Recode ]
Netflix was among the TV pioneers that eliminated commercials. Now, the live-streaming platform is testing a button that lets users skip the introduction that tends to open each show. [CNN ]
Today's more digitally oriented ad business is fraught with talkers who are "pushing their personal brands with New Age airy marketing babble about engaging consumers." What it really needs, reports Digiday's Shareen Pathak, is more doers. [Digiday ]
Time Inc.'s shift from selling ads based on its titles to one based on ad categories has been met with mixed results. For some advertisers, it simplifies the process and reduces the number of sales reps with whom they must work. But for an advertiser who wants to buy from one print title for multiple clients in multiple categories, "it's confusing at best," according to one agency. [Digiday ]
About Us
