Transcript: Fed's Evans Discusses Inflation, Interest Rates, Balance Sheet; Chicago Fed President Charles Evans answers questions on a variety of issues facing the central bank
ARTICLE:
Chicago Fed President Charles Evans sat down with Wall Street Journal reporters on Tuesday in New York and discussed a variety of issues facing the central bank, including the outlook for interest rate rises and the Federal Reserve's balance sheet at a time of weak inflation. He also took answered questions on banking sector issues, productivity and Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen's performance in office.
Here is a transcript of the exchange, lightly edited for length and clarity -- By Michael S. Derby
Q: So I was just asking about inflation and the weakness of inflation that we've seen over the last few months, and, you know, whether or not that calls into question whether the Fed will be able to deliver on its forecast of around one more rate rise. How long do you need to see the inflation trend pick up from where we are right now before you could support another rate rise this year?
MR. EVANS: Well, I think it's very important that, you know, the Federal Reserve support the economy and support inflation rising to our 2% objective. We have said that we've got a 2% objective going back to 2012 January, our Policy Strategy Statement, and everybody sort of understood 2% for a longer period of time is our objective. We have not hit it in that time period. There have been a lot of reasons why: aftermath of the great financial crisis and disinflationary tendencies. But more recently, inflation has been moving up from, you know, below 1% at one point, core inflation started moving up, and, you know, we've increased the funds rate by 100 basis points. And so we've, you know, come off the zero floor and, you know, moved up to, you know, 1 1/8 average.
So that's good, but that's all premised on an outlook where the economy is doing well. Unemployment's 4.3%. Looking for growth in the 2 1?4% range, which is above trend - trend is more like 1 3?4, and that's been enough to drive unemployment down. But inflation--which had been moving up off of its 1 1?4, 1.4 year over year--was moving up. And now, most recently, the last three months have been quite disappointing. There's no other way to describe
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 621 of 1177
that, I would say. Some of it looks like it's seemingly one-off effects from cellphone company data plans and things like that. So maybe it's explainable, and maybe next month and the month after that we'll revert back to better inflation. I think that means--for me, I know it means--you know, it's time to assess, you know, what the state of inflation is and whether or not we're really going to move up to 2%.
So the premise of your question was does this mean that we can continue raising rates. You know, the median of the (Summary of Economic Projections) is for three rate increases this year. We've done two. I think that, you know, we're now at a point where, you know, we can--we can afford--having raised the rate twice, we can afford to sort of wait a little bit and see how the data play out. There's a lot going on with uncertainty, the economy--global economy's doing better--but to see if inflation's going to move up.
I think we could wait until the end of the year. December is another SEP round, press conference, and that would be the time where we could decide three rate increases, two rate increases. To get to four, we'd have to do something before that, obviously. And for me, I think, boy, you know, if we saw better inflation and the unemployment rate, you know, continuing to move down, yeah, OK, I could see that. But that's not in my outlook at the moment.
Q: OK. So, I mean, you're willing to wait awhile to see if the inflation data do perk back up? I mean, I guess what you're saying is the Fed definitely has time to make a call on its next rate move.
MR. EVANS: I think so. And that's also--you know, that's also in the median SEP projection. You know, the median is for three rate increases. We don't say when they're going to take place. That's not the nature of the exercise. And if we got that in in December, that would be three. But it also affords the optionality of, in December, kind of seeing, gee, you know, unemployment--inflation's not picking up, there's something else going on. If unemployment continues to move down, there's this tension between a very strong labor market, history with inflation likely around the corner, maybe it's going to come. It's just that we've had a bit too many experiences of forecasting an upturn in inflation, having a good reason for forecasting that, and it hasn't taken place.
Q: If you did wait until the end of the year--if conditions cause you to wait until the end of the year, would that affect the balance-sheet plan? Because that--you know, in the new agenda, it's hopefully this year you're going to do that. But if you wait until December to raise rates because that's what the economy calls for, would that push the balance-sheet plan into 2018?
MR. EVANS: Doesn't have to. So the chair has spoken well on this at her press conference. We've released, you know, an addendum to our normalization guidelines, you know, on this. And so now we've indicated that, you know, we've looked at this, you know, quite carefully, and the current expectation is we put together--we have this plan, and when we decide it's time to start reducing our balance sheet that we'll begin taking $10 billion of assets off our balance sheet each month--basically, that's what the cap means: 6 Treasury, 4 MBS--for the first quarter, and then that would increase by 10 billion each quarter until we get to 50 billion. That's enough to start reducing the balance sheet in a meaningful, noticeable way, but not too quickly. And, you know, we can do that at any point.
I personally think, and I think most people think, that once this starts it can be running in the background. Markets will understand. They understand the plan now. Most of the action on the term premia, I think, comes from understanding the plan. It's all priced in, and you can see it run off.
One way to do it, you know, (New York Fed President William) Dudley...has said, you know, maybe we make an action on the balance sheet at a meeting where we don't have to change the funds rate. That would be a way to take the balance sheet, get that started, and position ourselves for a December rate increase. That's one possibility. There are others. But this is one that allows that optionality that, at the moment, I prefer.
Q: And when officials say that -- (the process of shrinking the balance sheet will)--start when interest rate normalization is "well under way," what is implied by "well under way?" Are we there now with this latest rate increase?
MR. EVANS: "Well under way," obviously, came to be a heavily laden term. Whenever you do qualitative guidance, it sort of takes that on. I know a number of people have thought about what's the level of the funds rate at which it must obviously be well under way, and you can go through a number of thought exercises on that. And they might
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 622 of 1177

be somewhat north of where we are. But I think, in general, we've increased the funds rate by 100 basis points. The first time we did it, events didn't work out; that is, uncertainty internationally in 2016. An awful lot of things happened: Brexit, China volatility, and all of that. So, you know, we delayed until last December. Now we've done three in a row.
I mean, you know, things are pretty in train at the moment. I recognize that's not the same term. But I think we're at the point where we can make a decision to start adjusting the balance sheet at any time at this point.
Q: And in September it seems like there's a prospect, again, for...fiscal collisions in Washington, debt-limit high jinks. Would that affect your timing at all if you got into September and, you know, there was uncertainty over what's going to happen there?
MR. EVANS: That's a good question. I'm not an expert on the exact interactions of what we do with the Treasury markets. Obviously, we care about well-functioning Treasury markets, and so, you know, if there are concerns we'd have to think about that. But, you know, at the moment, I'm, you know, not really that aware of exactly how that would play out. At some point, once--you know, once Congress and the president get talking about the debt ceiling, sometimes this goes on for quite some period of time, sometimes it's resolved more quickly. So, you know, it's just difficult to--you know, if you let that, you know, stop you, then you almost stop planning or whatnot. So I think we can continue to plan along these lines.
I think, as it turns out, rolling off $10 billion -- $6 billion of Treasurys, those are actually assets that markets would like to have available to them during, you know, times where they value safe assets. So I don't think it presents too many problems. But, again, I'm not expert, and I do know that people are concerned about that.
Q: You mentioned one-off factors sort of dragging down inflation over the last few months. Do you expect all those one-off factors to sort of go away altogether? Or is there ever a circumstance in which there are not one-off factors that are weighing on inflation or otherwise?
MR. EVANS: It's a good--yeah. So once you start picking apart pieces of the price index--you know, I think it was (former Cleveland Fed President) Jerry Jordan who way back in the '90s had some comment like, you know, once you start diving into the elements of the price index, you begin to convince yourself that the price report creates its own inflation or whatnot. I mean, you can just, you know, pick out what you like. Back when tobacco prices were going up a lot due to the legal settlement, there used to be, you know, core, eggs, food, energy and tobacco prices. And so it's easy to do this.
I think there's a good case that these are one-off. How many times are the, you know, phone companies going to change the data plans and things like that? Maybe it's a once and for all type of change. I'm a little more--you know, I'd like to reflect on this a little bit more because, you know, the same technology, you know, at the moment is changing all the time. It's changing in ways that are not easy to understand. It's not exactly the late '90s, when durable goods manufacturing technology was roaring along, and, you know, digital technology was finding its way on the factory work floor and offices in a big, big way in a very positive, broad fashion.
Now, it's more disruptive. More corporations are choosing to merge, ones that you wouldn't have thought of necessarily. You could have been farsighted and seen that, but others, you know, not so much. And it makes you wonder if competition is beginning to take place along lines that haven't been contemplated. Competition, you know, in many forms would adjust price margins. Price margin adjustment would lead to lower price levels for-- relative prices. But you get enough of these relative prices and it finds its way into the price index, unless the stance of monetary policy is sufficiently accommodative to overcome that.
And so that would be the what if it's not exactly one-off. Well, globally inflation has been low. One of the commonalities across the globe--now, we've all suffered from the great financial crisis, OK. Governments haven't responded full force with fiscal actions in many cases, OK. I mean, there are common approaches that have been taken that could account for it. But technology is affecting the global economy as well, and demographics. And so it's a--it's a very challenging time to say with certainty, yeah, I know it's one-off.
Rather, it's really more--I mean, in fairness to the other viewpoint, I think it's that labor markets are doing quite well. Unemployment rate's 4.3%. Labor force has been--participation rate has been declining. And there are a lot of
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 623 of 1177

demographic reasons for that. Maybe we'd all prefer more people in the workforce so that we could grow faster, but people are voluntarily making these choices and people are getting older, and a whole host of demographic reasons. So I mean, I think that's kind of what we face. The unemployment rate's falling.
And, you know, historically vibrant labor markets, accommodative Fed, go back to the '70s and you kind of recoil with fear over that. I think it's a very different world. I think the state of inflation expectations are very different now. But, you know, you'd have to be not really thinking very carefully to be oblivious to that possibility. So I think there are risks on both sides.
Q: What do you view as banks' role right now in the economy? Are they lending enough? Are they overregulated? Would you advise any tweaking there to get better economic performance?
MR. EVANS: Well, I mean, I--you know, I think bank lending is taking place, you know, reasonably well. I don't think that--you know, so at the moment, you know, banks have had a chance to rebuild their capital. The demands on them to have capital in place are stronger, higher than they were before the financial crisis. You know, you can argue over exactly how limiting that is for bank lending. You know, there is some research that indicates that banks that have more capital end up being more profitable and do more lending. That's not your first reaction, I think, to the fact that more leverage usually ends up with more lending. But I think the current circumstances are, you know, pretty good for the financial sector.
Regulatory burden, yeah, I mean, it's definitely higher than it was before the crisis. It was probably, you know, given the fact that we got ourselves into a financial crisis, it was probably too low. It could easily be, you know, higher now, and then part of the question would be what type of adjustments. I think community bankers have always feared that Dodd-Frank, even with certain carve-outs, you know, the attitude of regulators and supervisors would be to just, you know, wash all of that across the spectrum of the size of banks, and that they would end up being more regulated than even their expectations, you know, from the law.
I was always, you know, a little, frankly, skeptical of that. But, you know, in fact, I've heard more and more and, you know, I think that that is sort of an issue. So, you know, the Fed has started, you know, tailoring some of these requirements so that the community banks aren't affected to the same degree. But, you know, it's a judgment call and certainly some things, you know, could be done. But I do think that for the largest financial institutions that, you know, are systemically important more and better capital serves everybody better. You know, having the appropriate liquidity on hand in the face of difficult liquidity times, I think, is important.
And I think that the stress tests have served us all pretty well. Part of the stress test involves doing horizontal reviews, and then sort of sharing the outcomes of that, having feedback with the supervisors. I know it's painful, but at some point a little more gets shared about, you know, I think ways to have some capital in place or some liquidity in place against certain alternatives that help people think about that. But you can certainly go further than his ideal.
Q: Your banks that you supervise, do any go through the stress test?
MR. EVANS: Yeah. Yeah, they're not part of the highest (Large Institution Supervision Coordinating Committee) banks. But they're the large financial banking organizations, the next tier down. And over 50 billion. And also with a global presence, custody banks, Northern Trust. We supervise HSBC as well. And Allied Bank.
Q: You seemed to hint at the question of productivity just a little bit earlier. Where do you come out on the productivity paradox? Any new evidence that says, so, it's there we just can't see it, or the opposite side of the question?
MR. EVANS: Productivity's always difficult to measure. So it's definitely possible that there's stronger productivity likely to emerge in certain areas more narrowly than broadly, you know, everywhere. I think that, you know, the 10- year period from '95 to 2005 was just an extraordinary period for productivity. We had a productivity slow down before that. There are two different five-year periods in that 10-year period. The '95 to 2000 period was one where capital embodied technology really improved a lot. It's that durable goods manufacturing, computers, you know, finally finding its way into offices. The computer had been around for quite some time before that. And you saw noticeable acceleration of productivity.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 624 of 1177

And then after Y2K, you didn't see that same type of productivity, but you saw what economists refer to as total factor productivity, which is the residual, after accounting for capital and labor input, growth. And that's just business process and improvement. Businesses that--things had done so well in the previous five years, they left a lot of things, inefficiencies dangling because they were too busy doing other things. And so they cleaned that up and we saw that, you know, really improve for five years. For 10 years, that was a great productivity period.
Then, you know, somewhere, and the financial crisis gets--you know, confuses things as to when the real slowdown was. So now we're stepping back down to something probably a little higher than the productivity slowdown in the areas of 73 to 95, but not nearly like the previous 10 years. Maybe it's better. Maybe it's improving. But at the moment it's disruptive. So in the places where you see a lot of productivity increase, you see other capital investments just depreciate, because they're not profitable in the same way.
Q: Do you guys talk about driverless cars?
MR. EVANS: Us guys who? I mean, you know, at the (Federal Open Market Committee) level? Yeah, you know, somebody might make a comment, but not very much at the--at my board-of-directors level, a little bit more; at a business advisory group, a lot more. And in Chicago, we've had a couple of gatherings with people engaged in startups, the technology incubation centers in Chicago and what not. They'll talk a lot about driverless cars.
Q: Detroit's in your region.
MR. EVANS: Oh, sure. Yeah, Detroit's in our region. You know, everybody's thinking about driverless cars; insurance companies. It's going to be so safe. Who's going to have an insurance policy? There are just a whole bunch of things I don't understand; just the mere fact that you've got some driverless cars on the same road with people who are driving, who like driving.
Q: Yeah, but one day--if you take that, one day it will be illegal to drive a car as a person.
MR. EVANS: This - this is a country of freedom and liberty. (Laughter.) And I don't really understand that. But OK.
Q: No, one day, however many decades out from here. You're too much of a danger.
MR. EVANS: In Oklahoma is that going to be the case? I mean, there's an awful lot--I mean, in a city, I understand this.
Q: So, just given where you think productivity is, where do you think trend (gross domestic product growth) is going to be?
MR. EVANS: A nice round number I usually say is 1 3?4. Some people are now at 1 1?2, which is a very politically fraught discussion. I mean, I--you know, I gave a speech--beginning of last year? No, I think it was two years ago--a bankers' group in Wisconsin. And I started rolling out the, you know, have you heard about the demographics in the labor force? And, you know, this is meaning--this means that labor input's just not going to grow as much as it did before. And then productivity isn't so good. So, you know, we're kind of thinking that growth is likely to be 1 3?4.
And then in the audience afterwards there was somebody from the state government, not at the highest levels, and, you know, the person said afterwards, you know, you know, I heard what you said, and it made a lot of sense. I just wish, instead of 1 3?4, you could have said 4%, to which I said me too, because, you know, growth solves an awful lot of problems. And it would be good if we could get 4%. But where does it come from? We're talking about two very difficult areas. One is productivity. I'm sorry--I think last night we were talking about our poor state of inflation forecasting or things that we don't know so well; you know, inflation dynamics.
You know, economists--you know, you could stump--you could get them to admit under oath that--not even under oath; in a conversation--that we don't understand a lot of things in productivity, where it comes from. You know, (economist Robert) Solow said that Solow residual was the measure of our ignorance about productivity, after accounting for capital and labor growth.
Research and development helps, OK, but the relationship is, you know, probably about up there with the Phillips curve and things like that. So we'd all like to see stronger productivity growth. And I think if you let people innovate, you know, don't get in their way too much, that you get better results. But, I mean, you're probably only going to get so much. And it's really the labor input that is the most limiting of all of this.
Go back to the '80s, when we saw very strong trend growth, over 3% probably, and there were a lot of people
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 625 of 1177

coming into the workforce, continuing to come in. And that just added to the growth numbers. Now that's not likely to continue, and especially as you adjust immigration policies and things like that. That only makes it more difficult.
So you put those two things together, and 1 3?4, you know, is a very realistic estimate. Could it be 2 1?4? Could be, but it probably requires an awful lot of lift.
Q: How worried are you about restrictive immigration and trade policies even creating further headwinds to getting a better GDP number?
MR. EVANS: Yeah, I think--I think--yeah, I'm nervous about that. I mean, I think that we need--we need a vibrant labor market. We need an economy where we're adding to labor-force growth, however we get there. But, you know, we need to get that. I think that most of the people who've left the labor force for demographic reasons--you know, men, as they get older, have less of an attachment to the labor force. You know, every five-year bucket as they get older, they, you know, sort of choose randomly or however not to participate, you know, quite as much. And, you know, you go through all of that. You're just not likely to see the strong growth rates that we saw in the '80s, and even the '90s, unless some other spark is introduced.
Q: What are you hearing from businesses in your district about immigration?
MR. EVANS: We don't--we don't really hear a lot of comments about immigration, not per se.
Q: So you're not hearing anything about sort of, you know, restrictions and a lot of the stuff that's happening? Particularly in the Chicago area, it seems like there's been some activity.
MR. EVANS: Yeah, that topic just doesn't come up very much. I'm sure that pharmaceutical companies, others-- they're probably H-1B visas or, you know, probably resource-constrained. But people don't really talk about that. You do--you do always hear that it's just hard to find skilled workers, high-skilled workers, that type of thing. That's been going on for a long time; continues to go on. And some of it's probably forecastable; I mean, people who say that we've known for a long time that welders were going to be retiring and nobody really beefed up the pipeline of training welders. Nobody was interested in the details of that. But the higher-skilled digital technology, I think it's very challenging. And the interaction with immigration, visas, is not helpful.
Q: Just on the unknowns side of things, just to come back to the balance sheet, how much time do you think you need to give the market between some kind of reveal that things are going to get, you know, started, versus we are now starting? I think this--I don't think Chair Yellen answered the question about whether the announcement and something forthcoming would be a month apart or maybe three months apart. And I know there's been some discussion of the phasing in of that. I just wondered how much time you feel you need to give the market between point A and point B, particularly the mortgage market, which may need a little bit more time than the Treasury market.
MR. EVANS: Yeah. I read her transcript. I guess I didn't take strong note of the issue that you're pointing to.
For me, I think that we've laid out as much detail on this as anybody needs to sort of understand what they would be facing in terms of additional supply coming on the market from us, not reinvesting fully everything that matures. We've announced that it's going to be a very slow start. Treasurys, I think, are the easiest. The (mortgage- backed securities) is more complicated. There's a lot of (inaudible) action and things like that.
But I think that, you know, the New York desk will have additional commentary looking at the, you know, maturity structure of Treasurys. I, you know, had to even ask my staff sort of like, when we talk about reinvesting or rolling over, and how does that get distributed? And one of the answers I got back was, oh, it's the same way we're doing now, it's just a little bit less of it. Which kind of reminded me I hadn't be paying attention to all of the details of three- to five-year, you know, notes maturity and things like that. So I think the markets probably, you know--I can't imagine why the markets don't understand on the basis of what we've already laid out.
Q: They do, but I think there's, like, another--there's another widening that might come when you actually get started, so.
Q: I mean, like, let's say you start--let's say you decide you're going to start on November 1st. When do you say-- when do you tell folks, hey, we're going to start this on November 1st? Is that sort of what you're trying to get at?
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 626 of 1177

Q: It's sort of the--whether it's flush, in the same meeting, or whether there's like a month's gap or even two months of a gap, bearing in mind there's, you know, a potential rate increase in December and you might not want to do two things overlapping in the same meeting.
MR. EVANS: Oh, you know, some things are--some things, in my mind, are a little bit more of a detail orientation, and I trust the New York Desk, you know, to keep people--to be, you know, advertising and consulting with, you know, big--you know, a whole bunch of people who are affected by this. I think that a lot of work has already been done. Speeches have been given.
I think that it could be done just by we go into a meeting and then we say we've just decided that we're going to do this, and, you know, perhaps it begins, you know, whatever the 1st of the next month is, something like that. Or it could be that it's decided and then we say, you know, a couple of months. I guess if we found ourselves in--unsure about the Treasury discussions over the debt ceiling, it could be that we make an announcement and then it's, you know, got a little bit of a delay. But I'm not quite sure why that would have to be very long.
Q: There's a high bar to not continuing the rate rising campaign, but is there as much of a high bar to not continuing the balance-sheet actions? I mean, what would make you hold off this year--from this year?
MR. EVANS: Yeah, I think of it this way. I'm not really expecting--oh, people involved in the markets, it's definitely going to be a change from what they've been doing. But in terms of the overall financial situation and the way the economy and pricing is going to be, I just don't think it's a very big effect quickly. And the fact that it's going to take place over more than three years I think people can understand, and how it's going to build.
According to our estimates of term premia, which have gone down due to the size of our balance sheet, we've got some estimates--the balance sheet is only going to change slowly. It's not going to be in a surprise fashion. So, you know, one would think the taper tantrums that happened back in the spring and summer of 2013, nobody should be wrong-footed, you know, because they didn't expect this. I mean, if they weren't paying attention, somebody-- you know, people have to be accountable for things like that. But I think that there's been enough talking and planning over this that it should go smoothly. And I think that it's the kind of thing that can run in the background and not have a tremendous effect on adjusting the stance of financial restrictiveness. So I think that it could take place.
The hurdle for not doing that, I think, could be quite high, given that we've said, you know, we expect to do this this year. The hurdle for not making a funds rate adjustment, that I think is actually the live option if you think that something is happening with the economy or inflation that you weren't expecting. Having said that, I think everybody's forecast expectation for the economy is strong fundamentals, continued growth, continued improvement in labor markets, and, you know, two, three, maybe four rate hikes this year.
Q: So when the balance-sheet action does start happening, you're not necessarily expecting to see, say, yields start to just push up higher? That's not something you necessarily expect to see happen?
MR. EVANS: I would not expect that. I do not expect that. Can't rule anything out, of course.
And, you know, I mean, the challenges with financial markets and yields--you know, last night there was the question about the 10-year Treasury rate's come down a lot and, you know, what do you think about that. And you have to stop and remember that the Treasury--10-year Treasury rate was, you know, quite low until the election, and then the election, and then optimism from the business community about, you know, tax plans and regulatory relief and things like that, and, you know, 10-year rates shot up by a considerable amount, and they continue to build for a while. You know, then you have, you know, more British discussions about Brexit, elections, things like that; U.S. is a safe haven; people have slightly different expectations of legislative activity in Washington; and, you know, 10-year rates move down.
Now, how much of that is because of our actions? Probably not much, if any. How much of it is everything else going on? I'm in the everything else going on camp. But that's a big bucket, so.
Q: It seems like there's an effort to--you know, once this thing is put into motion, to have it go sort of automatically in the background. Is there sort of--what would have to happen to kind of take the balance-sheet reduction off this automated path?
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 627 of 1177

MR. EVANS: Yeah, so once we get started--you know, and we expect that it can take place in the background--as we, you know, find ourselves confronting different expectations for the economic growth, the labor market, or inflation, our first tool, I would say, is adjusting the funds rate. So, if we see more inflation and we can go a little-- need to go faster, unemployment rate goes down lower, we can, you know, adjust upwards the funds rate path. If we're not seeing progress on inflation, we don't go as fast.
You know, if something more unexpected and negative happened and we needed to provide more accommodation, you could--you could first think about reducing the funds rate. Now, this is not my expectation at all; you know, not the most likely event. But you could still adjust the interest rate and not necessarily make any adjustments to the balance sheet. But if you think that you're at risk of something much deeper than that and you expect that you might hit the zero lower bound--because we're only at 1 1/8 right now--then, yeah, you could easily stop the balance sheet, and you could even choose to add assets if you were in very unfortunate circumstances. But, of course, that's the full toolkit on display, not what I'm expecting.
Q: Do you reckon whenever the next recession comes around that there's going to be the balance sheet--adjusting the balance sheet is going to be part of the reaction?
MR. EVANS: So I spend most of my time speaking in public about how difficult the risks of the zero lower bound are for monetary policy. I think that when we get down to zero, it's a very challenging environment. I think that when other government actors don't choose to take actions which help provide additional aggregate dem

Title: China Companies to Get Greater Global Scrutiny After MSCI Lays Out Red Carpet; Inclusion of mainland China markets in major benchmark indexes is expected to lead to global investors focusing on corporate governance
ARTICLE:
Correction Kevin Anderson is head of investments for Asia-Pacific at State Street Global Advisors. An earlier version of this article incorrectly called the firm State Street Global Investors. (June 21)
MSCI Inc.'s decision to include mainland Chinese shares in its global benchmarks for the first time could prompt changes to how companies are run, even if the initial amount of capital inflows won't be enough to effect a sizable shift in the country's markets, analysts and brokers said.
One of the world's leading index providers, MSCI said it would admit 222 Chinese stocks to benchmarks such as its Emerging Markets Index, which is tracked by funds with some $1.6 trillion of assets under management world- wide.
The approval--which came prior to the start of Chinese stock trading Wednesday, and followed three years of rejections by MSCI--
drew a muted reaction from mainland investors . The Shanghai Composite Index closed up 0.5%, while its Shenzhen counterpart gained 0.4%.
The tepid response was viewed in the market as a reflection of the relative caution apparent in MSCI's decision. After discussions with major fund managers including BlackRock Inc., the index provider said it would admit roughly half the largest number of companies it had considered including in past years.
MSCI estimates some $17 billion will flow into Chinese markets--both from passive funds that automatically track its indexes and active fund managers--when the country's stocks are included a year from now. That is a fraction of the Shanghai and Shenzhen markets' combined $7.5 trillion market capitalization.
Still, the decision was heralded by market participants who have long salivated over the prospect of gaining greater access to the world's second-largest economy . The move could change the way that global investors look at China, said Chin-Ping Chia, head of research for Asia-Pacific at MSCI.
"It's about the opening of a new phase of emerging-market investing," he said. "The opening of the Great Wall, so to speak."
Including Chinese stocks in MSCI benchmarks will have "far-reaching implications" for global equity investors, said Rakesh Patel, head of equities for Asia-Pacific at HSBC. He said some $500 billion could flow into Chinese markets in time, as they become more accessible and companies such as MSCI and FTSE Russell give a full weighting to Chinese stocks in their indexes.
The country's stock-market regulator, the China Securities Regulatory Commission, said in a statement that the decision reflected confidence from global investors in the Chinese economy and financial markets.
The regulator also pledged to further revamp its capital markets. "The Chinese capital market must welcome foreign investors more openly," it said.
In the year since MSCI's most recent rejection of Chinese stocks' inclusion in its indexes, the country has further opened up the Shenzhen market to global investors via a trading link with Hong Kong. It has also overhauled the rules governing share suspensions, making it more difficult for companies to halt trading in their shares.
One question for investors is whether having more shareholders from overseas will encourage greater transparency and better corporate governance at Chinese companies.
"Now that China's domestic stock market has become a member of the international family, it has become easier for us to have a dialogue with companies and regulators to express our views," said Victoria Mio, Hong Kong-based chief investment officer for China at asset manager Robeco.
Following MSCI's decision, global investor attention will focus on improvements in the quality of management at Chinese companies, said Kevin Anderson, head of investments for Asia-Pacific at State Street Global Advisors. "There will now be a lens shone on Chinese companies, with an eye on improving shareholder value, corporate
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 630 of 1177
governance and returns from those companies," he said.
Yet others were less upbeat. Chinese stock markets "still suffer from serious institutional shortcomings as well as heavy political influence," according to analysts at research firm Eurasia Group.
Since China's market crashes in 2015 and early 2016, the presence of state-backed investment funds in the market has risen in importance. Local traders say such funds often step in to buy or sell shares during periods of market volatility.
In addition, China's market regulator continues to exert strong control over the pace of initial public offerings. Despite recent revamps, the country's tight capital controls can still make it difficult for investors to move money across the border.
The MSCI decision is unlikely to lead to huge inflows of capital from abroad until China makes further changes to the structure of its capital markets, said Liu Weiming, Beijing-based chief investment officer at Fuxi Investment Management Co.
"Has MSCI given China a chicken wing to help it fly higher or is it just chicken ribs that carry little meat or value? I think it's chicken ribs," he said. "If you don't make your home clean and tidy enough, how do you expect your guests to come for a visit?"
Chao Deng and Shen Hong contributed to this article.
Write to Gregor Stuart Hunter at gregor.hunter@wsj.com
Credit: By Gregor Stuart Hunter

20 Years After Handover, China Looms Ever Larger Over Hong Kong Markets; Two decades after the handover, Chinese influence over Hong Kong's markets is far more striking than foreign investors' clout in China
ARTICLE:
HONG KONG--When China regained sovereignty over Hong Kong in 1997 , the flourishing financial center seemed set to become a gateway for foreign investors to the then-largely closed mainland economy.
Two decades on, Chinese influence over Hong Kong's markets, rather than foreign investors' clout in China, is far more striking.
From the ever-rising activity of China's traders to the plethora of mainland companies listing on Hong Kong's stock exchange, China looms over Hong Kong's markets in a way few expect to dissipate in the coming years.
At the time of the handover, Beijing pledged to keep the former British colony as a largely independent entity for half a century. Less than halfway through that arrangement, Hong Kong--still one of Asia's leading financial markets, despite the rise of mainland rivals such as Shanghai--is increasingly being molded in China's image.
"The influence of the mainland is ubiquitous," says Paul Gruenwald, Asia-Pacific chief economist at S&P Global. One sign of China's importance to Hong Kong's markets is the shift in the largest constituents of the city's stock benchmark, the Hang Seng Index. Back in 1997, the index's biggest companies were either conglomerates owned by local tycoons or traditional British colonial firms, such as banking giant HSBC Holdings PLC.
Of the index's 10 biggest constituents by market capitalization then, only HSBC remains in its same form. Hutchison Whampoa and Cheung Kong Holdings, two companies 20 years ago, have since merged into CK Hutchison Holdings Ltd., which is in the top 10.
Today, the Hang Seng is dominated by state-owned lenders such as China Construction Bank Corp., Industrial &Commercial Bank of China Ltd. and Bank of China Ltd., which are also listed in Shanghai.
Chinese technology and telecom companies are a big presence, too. Tencent Holdings Ltd., the owner of China's largest social network, WeChat, holds the Hang Seng's largest weighting at 11%.
It isn't just the market leaders that have changed. In 1997, mainland Chinese companies, including those incorporated offshore, made up less than 20% of Hong Kong's market capitalization, according to Hong Kong Exchanges &Clearing Ltd., which operates the city's stock market.
Today, that number has ballooned to north of 60% and looks set to rise, given the high level of new listings in Hong Kong accounted for by mainland companies. Some 92% of the total volume of initial public offerings in the city was from Chinese companies last year, according to Goldman Sachs, helping Hong Kong retain its mantle as the world's most-popular venue for listings for the second consecutive year.
This trend has proved controversial. Companies from the mainland often have high investment from so-called cornerstone investors, who buy up large amounts of the company's stock ahead of the IPO, pledging to hold on to the shares for a few months. When state-owned Postal Savings Bank of China Co. raised $7.4 billion in its IPO in September, 80% of the shares were preordered by six other, mostly state-owned firms.
The presence of cornerstone investors makes it easier for companies to launch their IPOs. But critics say such deals are diluting the quality of the Hong Kong market.
"Hong Kong has essentially become a China growth derivative," says Kinger Lau, chief China strategist at Goldman Sachs.
   PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 636 of 1177
China is also changing the way Hong Kong stocks are traded.
The advent of the Stock Connect trading links between Hong Kong and the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock markets on the mainland in recent years has allowed mainland investors to buy shares of Hong Kong-listed securities via the link. Foreigners, in turn, can buy shares in China more freely than before.
While many predicted a rush of foreign money into Chinese stocks when the links were launched, so-called southbound trading, or money coming from mainland China, has become a vital source of inflows into Hong Kong. Trading volume measured by southbound net buying via the Shanghai Connect link made up almost 10% of Hong Kong's overall market in June, according to Jefferies, near its high since the program launched 21?2 years ago.
In turn, mainland traders are influencing which sort of stocks outperform in Hong Kong, analysts say. Mainlanders often buy into big Chinese companies with listings in Hong Kong, such as state-owned banks.
"The composition of Hong Kong's market is only becoming much more China-driven and China-exposed," says Ben Luk, global macro strategist at State Street Global Markets.
Write to Steven Russolillo at steven.russolillo@wsj.com

* Hong Kong's Tycoons Bet The Future Is on Mainland (July 1, 1997)

Title: Financial Institutions Lead Gains in Stock Markets; Shares of banking giant HSBC surge 3.9% in Hong Kong; Standard Chartered rises 3.2%
ARTICLE:
Equity markets in Asia were higher Thursday, with finance stocks broadly leading gains after all major U.S. financial institutions received approval from the Federal Reserve to ramp up dividend payouts and share buybacks. This is the first time since the annual tests began after the 2008 financial crisis that all firms got passing grades, a sign, analysts say, of resilience in big banks and the U.S. financial system.
It paves the way for U.S. banks to increase dividend payouts and share buybacks to their highest levels in years, providing investors with confidence to invest in high-growth assets like technology stocks.
Australia's S&P/ASX 200, coming off its best day in two weeks, was up 1.1%, with large banks among the big gainers: Macquarie Group and Westpac rose 2.1%; National Australia Bank, 2%.
Big banks boosted Hong Kong shares as well, helping the Hang Seng Index to a 0.9% gain at the midday break. HSBC surged 3.9% to a 22-month high after a 20% price-target upgrade by Morgan Stanley, in anticipation of the lender's plans for its excess capital. Standard Chartered was up 3.2%.
Overnight gains in U.S. technology shares were also lifting shares of their key Asian counterparts on Thursday.
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 638 of 1177
Korea's Samsung Electronics rose 1.1%, SoftBank Group gained 1% in Tokyo and Hong Kong index heavyweight Tencent rose 0.7%.
In China, share gains were more modest, with brokers pointing to reduced liquidity, following the sixth consecutive session that the People's Bank of China has stopped liquidity injections to the market. The Shanghai Composite Index was up 0.3% in the morning session.
Crude-oil prices rose despite an increase in U.S. stockpiles. The front-month futures for Brent crude, the international benchmark, gained 0.3% in Asia.
"You know you are back in a market with a bullish bent when [U.S. oil-inventory data] is ignored," said Greg McKenna, chief market strategist at AxiTrader.
Japan's Nikkei Stock Average was up 0.5% despite giving up some early gains on a stronger yen. The dollar was down 0.1% at Yen 112.26, tracing back on early gains.
The U.S. dollar broadly extended earlier declines in morning Asian trade, with the euro and the pound gaining 0.2% against it. Overnight, the dollar pulled back in New York action, sending the WSJ Dollar Index a broad gauge of the currency's value to its second-lowest level of the year.
The dollar's decline comes as central bankers from Europe, the U.K. and Canada hint that they are moving closer to withdrawing their massive stimulus programs . Analysts said there was also speculation that weak U.S. inflation would stay the Fed's hands in raising rates.
"The markets are inclined to believe that the Fed is likely to be on hold," said Sean Callow, a senior strategist at Westpac in Sydney.
While comments from the central banks indicated improving economic conditions and a global pickup in demand, it would take them some time to actually raise real rates, said Colin Graham, chief investment officer of multiasset solutions at BNP Paribas Asset Management.
For now, "central banks may be seeking to reduce the leverage in the market," said Mr. Graham.
John Wu contributed to this article.
Write to Kenan Machado at kenan.machado@wsj.com
Credit: By Kenan Machado

Title: Inside the Push to Reclaim a Texas School's Gold Stash; The state is building its own depository and it wants a university and other investors to bring their gold home
ARTICLE:
The University of Texas owns roughly $861 million in gold bullions locked in a bank vault in Manhattan. Now, Texas wants to bring that gold home.
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 640 of 1177
The state is moving ahead with plans to create its own depository--the first state-regulated gold vault in the nation- -in the hopes of persuading the university and other investors to keep their gold in the Lone Star State.
The depository has cleared years of political hurdles, and now must overcome a regulatory challenge to bring UT's gold to Texas.
The University of Texas said it would consider moving its gold under certain conditions, though negotiations with the state haven't started yet.
That hasn't stopped Texas from pressing forward. This month Texas Comptroller Glenn Hegar announced the state tapped Lone Star Tangible Assets, which stores and trades precious metals, to build and operate a bullion depository in Austin.
Mr. Hegar said the depository would serve as an alternative stash for gold and other precious metals in place of federally regulated banks or smaller, unregulated storage facilities.
Gov. Greg Abbott, who signed a 2015 bill to create the depository, and others have called for the "repatriation" of Texas gold.
Mr. Hegar said the state has bigger plans beyond claiming UT's gold.
State officials say they also envision expanding the depository into a commodities exchange for natural resources such as oil and natural gas, potentially challenging the existing commodities marketplaces in Chicago and New York City.
"Once the depository is up and running and people see how easy it is to make transactions there, I think it's just a natural progression of things that we'll be working with other commodities as well," said Republican state Rep. Giovanni Capriglione, who wrote the 2015 bill.
Construction on the Texas Bullion Depository is scheduled to start this September, a Lone Star spokesman said. The depository is slated to open in December 2018.
The security at the facility--which dubs itself "The Fort Knox of Texas"--will be up to par with "military installation," Lone Star Chairman Matthew Ferris said.
Mr. Capriglione first proposed a depository run entirely by the state in 2013.
That bill came with a hefty price tag for the state--$27.6 million over five years--and didn't pass. Mr. Capriglione tried again in 2015, this time proposing a public-private partnership in which a private entity would own and operate the facility under oversight from the state.
Under the 2015 law, the Texas Bullion Depository would function as a state agency contracted with Lone Star to build and run the vault facility.
Lone Star would get 90% of the revenue from fees, and the state would receive 10%, which would be used to offset administrative costs, a state spokeswoman said.
 PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 641 of 1177

Motivated by the 2008 financial crisis, Mr. Capriglione said he is calling for Texas' "independence and sovereignty" from Wall Street banks and the Federal Reserve, but isn't advocating a complete break.
"I don't think that we should blow away with the existing system, but there's nothing wrong with having a plan B," Mr. Capriglione said. "That's what our depository does."
For years, Texas Republicans have championed a currency system backed by gold and other precious metals. In its 2016 platform, the Republican Party of Texas called for a return to "precious metal standard for the United States dollar" and abolishing the Federal Reserve.
A spokeswoman for the University of Texas said the school will "seriously consider" moving the gold from its HSBC vault to the new depository in Texas if the state meets two conditions.
First, the depository would have to be a member of the Comex commodities exchange, which requires member institutions to be within 150-mile radius of New York City for inspection.
Mr. Ferris said Lone Star is in talks with a number of "third-party banks" to provide liquidity for assets in the depository, which would exempt it from the geographical requirement.
Second, cost of storing the gold in Texas would have to be less than what UT currently pays to HSBC Holdings PLC. The school pays $606,000 a year to store the gold in New York, the university said.
HSBC declined to say how much it charges for storage, and wouldn't disclose whether UT is a client. A spokeswoman for the bank said it doesn't reveal its clients.
Lone Star said storage fees for over $50 million is "negotiable" and no more than 0.15% of the asset value a year. Mr. Capriglione didn't specify what the Texas depository would charge UT, but said the depository would "absolutely" meet UT's needs.
"That gold belongs in Texas. Period," Mr. Capriglione said. Credit: By Covey E. Son

Title: HSBC Wins Approval to Operate Majority-Owned Joint Venture in China; HSBC becomes the first foreign bank granted such a setup in the country
ARTICLE:
HSBC Holdings PLC has received regulatory approval to operate a majority-owned joint-venture securities company based in China, the first foreign bank to win such a setup.
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 643 of 1177
The joint venture with Qianhai Financial Holdings Co. Ltd., a state-owned financial company, will be called HSBC Qianhai Securities Limited and will be based in Shenzhen, HSBC said Friday. The U.K. lender had been waiting since November 2015, when it announced plans for the joint venture , for approval from the China Securities Regulatory Commission.
The joint venture will conduct stock research, underwriting of stocks and bonds and advising on domestic and outbound mergers and acquisitions, HSBC said, and is expected to launch by the end of the year.
Foreign banks generally aren't allowed to have majority control of their joint-venture businesses with local brokerage firms in China. They are capped at 49% of such ownership and most are restricted from trading domestic securities. Banks, including Goldman Sachs Group Inc., have clamored for years to get control of the businesses, hoping to reap more of the profits and be able to make more decisions on a local level.
Beijing has signaled it is open to gradually allowing investment firms to have greater stakes, but so far the cap has remained in place. HSBC was able to secure a majority stake under an arrangement between Hong Kong and mainland China designed to encourage trade and economic cooperation.
Under that arrangement, Hong Kong-funded financial institutions such as HSBC that satisfy various criteria are allowed to set up one such company each in Shanghai, Guangdong Province and Shenzhen. The Hong Kong- funded financial institutions can own up to 51% of the joint venture.
HSBC has been deploying capital to fund growth in the Pearl River Delta, an area of southern China adjacent to Hong Kong.
Separately, Bank of East Asia Ltd. also said Friday it had received approval to operate its own joint-venture, East Asia Qianhai Securities Company Limited. Bank of East Asia will have a 49% stake in the company, which will also be based in Shenzhen.
Write to Julie Steinberg at julie.steinberg@wsj.com Credit: By Julie Steinberg

Title: Hong Kong-Mainland China Bond Link Gets Off to Quiet Start; After fanfare of opening ceremony, Chinese bond prices were mostly steady in the morning session
ARTICLE:
SHANGHAI--China's bond market showed little reaction as Beijing and Hong Kong opened a trading link giving global investors additional access to the world's third-largest debt market.
Despite fanfare at the opening ceremony in Hong Kong for the so-called Bond Connect link, Chinese bond prices were mostly steady throughout the trading day. The yield on China's benchmark 10-year government bond dipped 0.04 percentage point to 3.53%, while on the one-year it was down 0.005 percentage point at 3.46%.
"I am sure there's champagne and balloons at the ceremony in Hong Kong, but here in Shanghai it's just another trading day. I don't feel a thing," said a Shanghai-based senior bond trader at an Asian bank.
The link allows investors based in Hong Kong to trade directly in China's $9 trillion market. Its launch follows last
    PDF GENERATED BY SEARCH.PROQUEST.COM Page 645 of 1177
year's landmark opening of the bond market to global investors with trading accounts inside China, and is modeled in part on the stock-market links between Hong Kong and Chinese exchanges in Shanghai and Shenzhen.
Unlike the stock-market links, the bond-trading connection is one-way: Foreigners can buy bonds in the mainland market, but Chinese investors can't do likewise in Hong Kong. China has been fighting to stem capital outflows and reduce downward pressure on its currency.
Few expect a huge rush of foreign money into Chinese bonds as a result of the new trading link, given that investors can already buy bonds in China. Chinese bonds aren't yet included in major bond indexes, so the many investment funds that track those indexes don't have to enter the market. And analysts say concerns about frequent bouts of volatility and the reliability of local credit ratings could keep investors away.
"The bond connect will at best serve to improve investor sentiment now, but given the less-than-convenient arrangements regarding clearing and so on, its positive impact will only become material in the medium to long run," said Tang Yue, an analyst at Industrial Securities. Market participants say that in addition to the paperwork, there are also concerns about currency conversion and hedging to offset exchange-rate risks.
Asked at the opening ceremony whether Beijing will make the link two-way, the deputy governor of China's central bank, Pan Gongsheng, said "not at the moment." He said it would depend on the amount of trading activity and initial demand from the market.
To showcase the new trading link, one of China's biggest banks, Agricultural Development Bank of China, on Monday issued 15 billion yuan worth of bonds that will be available to both domestic and global investors. China Development Bank will follow with 20 billion yuan worth of bonds Tuesday.
International banks including Citigroup and HSBC said Monday they had concluded their first deals as market makers for trading via Bond Connect.
Chinese bond investors are preoccupied less with the link than with what the People's Bank of China will do next in the money market and how the economy will perform in the coming months, said the Shanghai trader.
After injecting a large amount of funds into the financial system in mid-June to meet a seasonal surge of cash demand, the PBOC hasn't used its money-market liquidity operation during the past seven business days. The inaction is widely interpreted as a signal from policy makers in Beijing that they wish to continue their campaign to reduce debt and leverage in China's financial markets.
Foreign investors' share of China's interbank bond market remains low. At the end of March, the total amount of Chinese domestic bonds they held was around 830 billion yuan ($122.42 billion), or around 1.4% of the market, according to Goldman Sachs.
"Foreign money accounts for very little in our market, and it won't change much just because of the Bond Connect," the Shanghai trader said. "The local players will continue with their own game."
Gregor Stuart Hunter in Hong Kong contributed to this article.
Write to Shen Hong at hong.shen@wsj.com
